mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means angle.

You have a sword that has a drop of something on it. That drop is a drop of blood. Sure, a sword will cut someone to spill some blood, but all you really need is any kind of blade to cut someone. Sword, knife, whatever, as long as it's a blade.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means half.
You have something old on your head that's standing up. What is this thing? An awesome mohawk. You've had it so long it's looking pretty old... but still awesome.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means next.
This radical is the same as the kanji, but "number in a series" is too long. Let's shorten it to number.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means peace.
If you're writing while looking at the moon, you can bet someone else is doing it too. People have a habit of looking at the moon simultaneously.

Your mama is carrying some kind of elaborate weapon. You look closely and see that it's a spear. The pointy end is to the right, and there are some decorations hanging off it. It's a very fancy spear, and you wonder where your mama got it.

The life of a shellfish is filled with blame. They take the blame for everything from food poisoning and allergies, to cutting people's feet on beaches. Just imagine an innocent little shellfish, living its quiet little life, while everyone's heaping blame on it. It hides in its little shell and tries to deflect all that blame. What a life!
mnemonics.reading: When those poor shellfish aren't having blame piled on them, they're being eaten, because shellfish are thought to make for a very sexy (せき) meal.  Imagine trying to look sexy as you slurp up those saucy little shellfish.

mnemonics.meaning: A winter tree is only a winter tree due to a clause in its tree contract. The clause states that it cannot be a tree in the summer, because that is the summer tree's territory. Same goes for autumn and spring trees. Go ahead and look at the winter tree's contract, if you want (they're nailed to every tree). There's the clause that says it can only be a tree in the winter.
mnemonics.reading: This clause was written into all trees' contracts by Jourm (じょう), the large farmhand.  Jourm noticed that the trees were getting too crowded, so he wrote up these clauses and added them to the trees' contracts. Now, the forests are less crowded, thanks to the little clause. Makes sense that a farmhand like Jourm would do this too. The fewer trees, the more farmland. It's good for folks like Jourm.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a tsunami that's simultaneous (with another tsunami, I assume) and you know the world is about to come to an end. Imagine a tsunami simultaneously happening as the world comes to an end. Oh no, isn't there any way to stop this!?
mnemonics.reading: Just as the world is about to come to an end, your cyborg (さい) appears and blocks it with its cyborg body! So the world won't come to an end this one time, thanks to the cyborg you made. Though it doesn't look very good. The cyborg is beaten up and full of water. This might be the end for it...

mnemonics.meaning: Women who get together to talk about grains are a committee. They're the Committee of Women for Grains (tm tm tm). What does this committee discuss, you wonder. Imagine what this committee of women could be coming together to discuss. Aren't grains just grains? Why do they need a whole committee?
mnemonics.reading: Well, grains need a committee because the eagles (い) have been eating them all. The women know this, so they're meeting and trying to come up with a way to stop these pesky eagles from eating all the grains and leaving none for the humans. Imagine a committee of women standing together in a field of grain, watching eagles swooping around. They take notes and mutter to one another about their options.

mnemonics.meaning: You only have a few eyes so you need to conserve what's left. You only have like, three eyes left. If you conserve them .
mnemonics.reading: You're trying to conserve your eyes, when the Shougun (しょう) marches by. He stops, sees you, and demands you give him your remaining eyes! But sir, I'm conserving what little I have left! The Shougun stares down at you, eyes blazing, and you hand over all but one of your eyes. Now you really have to conserve, or you'll be blind. Thanks Shougun. I bet he has plenty of eyes, he didn't need yours.

mnemonics.meaning: Cows, using nothing more than towels and knives, have taken control of the world. Their system of control is brutal—payback for how us humans have treated them I guess. Imagine this new cow-controlled world—there are cows on every street corner, armed with towels and knives, intimidating all us humans into following their system.
mnemonics.reading: It's time to take control back from the cows! Pull out your saber (せい) and fight back!  The cows' towels and knives won't stand a chance against your saber!

mnemonics.meaning: If you use your fingers to point when you compare things you're really just throwing around criticism. You should never need to point fingers when you're just comparing things. If you're pointing and picking and being mean, that's criticism. Some criticism is okay, as long as it's constructive and it helps the person get better. But when you start pointing fingers, it's time to step back and try to not be such a jerk.
mnemonics.reading: If you're having trouble not giving out criticism, just think about how you would react if someone criticized you. You'd feel an embarrassed heat (ひ) rise throughout your body. That heat will cover your whole face. Before you throw criticism around, imagine that embarrassed heat. You don't want to feel that way, so why would you do it to someone else?

mnemonics.meaning: A lion harvesting rice uses an axe to cut off the tops of the stalks. The lion is roaming the rice fields using his axe to harvest the rice. He does so by cutting off the part of the rice stalks he needs. Picture this lion on his hind legs, walking through a rice field. He’s holding an axe in one hand and acting like a human. See him cut off the plants and hear the whoosh of the axe as he cuts.
mnemonics.reading: The lion will cut off rice stalks until dawn (だん). But at the first light of dawn, it will run and hide in the shade of the trees, cut off from the rice. When dawn comes in Africa (it's a lion, so that's where he is) it gets too hot to be in the sun, so the lion gets cut off from his job of cutting things off.

mnemonics.meaning: Both a leader and a king have a duty to protect their people. A good leader always protects his followers, and a good king always protects his subjects. This is their duty. Imagine yourself being protected by your king and leader. They don’t really like you, but it is their duty to protect you. See them fighting off evil doers and taking bullets for your sake.
mnemonics.reading: You’re the village nincompoop (にん), but the king and the leader still have a duty to protect you. Even a nincompoop is important to the kings and leaders of the world. You’re a nincompoop. Even though you’re so nincompoopy, your king and leader still have a duty to protect you. Feel happy and content, despite your nincompoopery.

mnemonics.meaning: The life thread is an element essential to all living things. This thread of life joins all things together, providing an essential relationship between all life. This element is all that holds this world together. Visualize this element of life, interconnecting all living things. Without it, everything would fall apart and into chaos.
mnemonics.reading: You need to keep this element clean, so you make sure to wash it with soap (そ) every single day. This turns out to be pretty hard because the element is an invisible thread, but you do your best. Imagine grabbing hold of the element that holds all life together and trying to wash it with soap. It's slippery so you keep dropping it and soap keeps going in your eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: Seeing a mohawk in the winter means the enemy is nearby. You are from the dreadlock tribe and the mohawk tribe is your enemy. You’re deep in the heart of battle and winter has fallen. Now is the time to take out the enemy. Picture yourself holed up in a winter encampment, waiting to strike at the mohawk wearing enemies. Feel the cold around you as you scan the horizon for mohawks.
mnemonics.reading: You’re kind of a techie (てき), so you have an advantage over your enemy. You’re armed with night vision goggles and other cool tech gear as well. Being a techie certainly has its advantages. Imagine yourself all teched out like the techie you are. Hear the beeps and boops of all the technology you have at your disposal as you search for more mohawk enemies.

mnemonics.meaning: Sheep are always looking at the next animal, full of envy and jealousy.  Picture a sheep comparing itself to the next creature, and feeling deep envy and jealousy. Why does it feel that way?
mnemonics.reading: The reason the sheep feels such envy and jealousy is that the next creature is a centaur (せん)! Who wouldn't be jealous of a creature as noble as a centaur? Being a centaur is every sheep's dream, so they can't help feeling terrible jealousy when they see one.

mnemonics.meaning: If you say a new weapon idea out loud, then it will be established immediately. Try it out: I want a stabbing weapon with extra weapons that can pop out on the sides. *POOF* You've established a new weapon. And it's been added to the official weapon wiki of the world.
mnemonics.reading: Weapons have to be established in sets (せつ). So you have to make another one that goes with it. Make them cohesive please. Establish weapons in sets or the people who use them won't be able to match each other.

mnemonics.meaning: You should say "peace" before you evaluate a situation. That way everyone will know where you’re coming from. If you’re honest and say "peace" before you evaluate a situation out loud, everyone will know where you stand. What situation would you like to evaluate? Be sure to say "peace" before doing so. Imagine yourself doing this out loud and think of what you would say.
mnemonics.reading: When you say "peace," you end up making a really bad pun and you hear somebody say “Heyo!” (ひょう) You look at the people around you and try to evaluate who said heyo, but you can’t tell. You start talking again when somebody exclaims “That’s what she said” and another person shouts “Heyo!” once again, but you still can’t evaluate who’s saying these things. Imagine yourself trying to explain a situation you’re about to evaluate and your audience keeps shouting “Heyo!” every other sentence. Imagine how frustrating that would be. Get angry at your rude audience and how much they shout “Heyo.”

mnemonics.meaning: You see a tree with a squid on it, so you get closer to examine it. As you examine the tree and the squid in it, you think, "Huh, nope still weird." You should examine it further to find out what's going on.
mnemonics.reading: You're sticking your face in really, really close to examine this little squid in the tree when Ken (けん) the samurai appears behind you. "There you are, squid! Thank you citizen, I've been looking all over for my little chum." Imagine how many trees Ken examined before he found you both. Picture him putting his face really close to each one, then shedding a single tear when he realized this squid wasn't in it.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a scene going on inside your head. It is of a pair of horns on the ground atop a mountain. No. It is not just one pair of horns. It is many. So many that they create a giant hill atop the mountain, which is already pretty high. Imagine this hill of horns on top of this mountain. This hill of horns makes it possible for you to get just high enough to touch the top of the sky.
mnemonics.reading: How was standing atop this hill of horns on top of a mountain to touch the sky? Eh. It was okay (おか), but that's about it. Feel indifferent about this hill of horns on top of the mountain. It's all in your head anyways.

mnemonics.meaning: The dirt mask is a mask which, when put on, will greatly increase the amount of dirt. Imagine putting it on, and suddenly the dirt around you increases by quite a bit.
mnemonics.reading: Use the dirt mask to increase the dirt around you. The zombies (ぞう) are trying to escape, so you just keep increasing the dirt on top of them so they can't get out. Zombie hands keep coming out of the ground, but as long as you wear the mask and increase the dirt on top of them, they won't be able to escape their earthly prison.

mnemonics.meaning: If a tree is growing out of a top hat you need to inspect it to find out why and how this happened. You should probably investigate the area too. I mean, how could a tree grow out of a top hat anyway? Seems suspicious. Inspect the tree. Inspect the top hat. Did you find anything?
mnemonics.reading: In the middle of your inspection you realize you need to saw (さ) the tree open to come to a good conclusion. This seems a bit unnecessary, but no! No! For the sake of this investigation you must saw the tree in half! Imagine stopping to inspect the tree after each minute of sawing. You'll find out why it's growing out of a top hat! Eventually!

mnemonics.meaning: You're about to enter a roof that has your number on it so you can face the judge. You've been sitting here for what feels like hours, waiting for your number to come up. Finally the time has come—the judge will see you now. Picture the judge sitting under the roof. Your number is sitting on his big desk, next to the gavel.
mnemonics.reading: The judge is not happy with you. He tells you to come closer and when you do, he takes his gavel and hits you in the shins (しん). Ouch! You try to ask the judge what his ruling is, but he just hits you on the shins again!

mnemonics.meaning: "I'll cut that baby in half with a knife if you don't figure out custody," says the judge. Ah, the oldest judge trick in the book. Since you two can't make a decision on who gets custody of the baby, the judge now has to step in and judge for you. Will you figure it out for yourself, or let the baby get cut in half? What an effective judge.
mnemonics.reading: This judge is Han (はん) Solo, so you know he's not going to back down. Han Solo the judge isn't a bad person... but he isn't so good either. He'll cut that baby in half if you don't figure things out. That's the kind of judge Han Solo is.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of the cow tribe is too important to deal with small matters and trivial affairs. Picture this hoity-toity cow leader who thinks he’s too good for small matters and affairs. See him acting all fancy like he’s better than everyone else. The cow even moos with a fake British accent. How pretentious.
mnemonics.reading: All of his affairs are taken care of by Ken (けん) the samurai, who he hired as his underling. Picture Ken the samurai scooping poop for the leader of the cows, because that's a matter of poop and state.

mnemonics.meaning: Buildings hold festivals on special occasions. A festival can't be happening all the time. Then it wouldn't be special, it would just be a party building, so they can only happen on special occasions.
mnemonics.reading: The occasion this time is to celebrate your wonderful cyborg (さい). It's about time you did something nice for it. Your cyborg has been really great lately. Your wife loves it. It saved the world. It's nice of you to take this occasion to show the cyborg how much it means to you all with a festival.

mnemonics.meaning: The hat comes to a stop, thinking of a plan. The hat had been pacing around for a while, trying to think of how to get off the head he's resting upon and back into the house where it's nice and cozy, and came to the sudden realization of a plan. This caused the hat to stop. Imagine a hat walking about on your head, pacing back and forth deep in thought. See the hat stroke its chin in contemplation as it tries to think up a plan to get off your noggin and back inside.
mnemonics.reading: The plan that made this hat stop right in its tracks was very simple. First, obtain the key (き) to the house. Then, use the key to get in the front door. How simple! Watch as the hat begins to grin. This plan is so simple it’s sure to work. Now watch as the hat obtains the key and enters the locked door. What sort of mischief will the hat get into once inside?

mnemonics.meaning: If there’s grass on the ground and fins in your hand, you need to raise that hand up to the sky. You’re in the middle of a fisherman’s ritual, which can only be performed on grassy ground. You take fish fins from the previous year, and raise them up to the sky in order to ensure a good fishing harvest. Feel the grass in your toes and the fins in your hand as you raise them up to the sky. See the sun glistening off the fins as you raise them up in the air.
mnemonics.reading: This ritual only works in one part of the world however. It absolutely must be performed in Little Kyoto (きょ). The way Little Kyoto lines up with the sun and the sky and all that astrological junk makes it the best place for you to raise fish fins up in the air. Imagine yourself going through the same process as before, only this time imagine yourself in Little Kyoto. Little Kyoto is really little, so make sure you're in the right spot.

mnemonics.meaning: What people say to you will be carved by a blade into your heart, and the next time you see them, you'll immediately recognize them. Sometimes your brain won't recognize someone, but your heart will. That's because what they say draws that blade across your heart and leaves a mark, for better or for worse, forever.
mnemonics.reading: You recognize places, names, and even games this way. But the thing that has the most real estate on your heart, the thing you recognize the most, is Nintendo (にん). There's just something about Nintendo—you'd recognize them and their games anywhere.

mnemonics.meaning: The next shellfish will be yours, but this shellfish will be mine. These are the resources we have to share and distribute. Our resources are based around a system of trading shellfish. It's not that weird, plenty of ancient societies used shellfish as their main resource!
mnemonics.reading: You save up all of your resources so you can buy a sheep (し). You bring a big sack of your shellfish resources to the market and finally get to pick out that sheep you've had your eyes on for months. Of course you're going to use your resources to get a sheep. You're living in a time when shellfish are used to trade for goods and services!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the radical are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. If you know the radical, you will know the kanji as well!
mnemonics.reading: Such righteousness! Well, at least according to the king who thinks he's being righteous. His version of righteousness is to send anyone who disagrees with him to the guillotine (ぎ). "THIS IS NOT RIGHTEOUSNESS!" you yell, just before the guillotine comes down on your neck.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the tree lies a turkey with a broken arrow in it. It doesn't have rights like humans, so people can just shoot turkeys with arrows and no one is punished. Imagine if humans didn't have any rights, like this turkey. People could just gun each other down in the street and no one would be punished for it... oh wait. :/
mnemonics.reading: "You have rights, so I won't shoot you like this turkey," says the voice of Ken (けん) the samurai, from above you in the tree. He jumps down and picks the turkey up, the broken arrow sticking out of its neck. "Turkeys do not have rights, my friend. Just let this one go."

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami is coming for the cliff made of tofu, but there is a special sect that protects tofu cliff. This sect of the tofu-lovers club takes their duties very seriously and they must protect this tofu cliff at all costs.
mnemonics.reading: All of the members of the sect are standing on the cliff, their hands raised, and right as the tsunami is about to collide with them, they shout, "Ha (は)!" and it's repelled! The tsunami sinks and rolls back out to sea, the tofu cliff is safe! Oh, do you want to be a member of the tofu sect? HA! Don't make me laugh. If you ask to be a member of a sect, you'll never get in. Never ask for a sect.

mnemonics.meaning: You use a special spear in winter to give yourself the power to do all of your tasks. It's hard to get a task done in winter. That's why you have this spear to power and motivate you.
mnemonics.reading: Your task is to spear this cow. "Moo (む)!" it yells at you and runs away. You need to make dinner though... that's your task, so you better catch up to that cow and put an end to its mooing. The moo haunts you as you finish your task. Luckily this spear is helping you keep going even though this task is really difficult.

mnemonics.meaning: A guard is at your door and wants some of your grains. This is the tax you pay for living in this town. Back in the day, grains were used like currency, so it makes sense that there was a grain tax in the olden days. Can you imagine a guard coming to your door and demanding you pay your grain tax?
mnemonics.reading: You have to pay this tax, because if you don't the guard will cut you down with his special German saber, a zeiber (ぜい). "Don't you hear vat I zei? Pay ze tax or I vill zlei you!" he shouts. You don't want to be sliced with the zeiber, so you listen to vat he zei zei zei's and pay the tax.

mnemonics.meaning: Angle your sword correctly at a cow to untie it without hurting it. This is actually a pretty tough angle to get your sword, so in order to solve this cow puzzle you have to be really smart and careful. Picture the cow looking up at you with her big, brown eyes. She doesn't want to be tied here anymore, so you have to solve this and untie her.
mnemonics.reading: You're trying to untie this cow from the kayak (かい) you're both currently in. Some jerk tied the cow to this kayak and sent it toward a waterfall. If you don't solve this riddle fast, you'll both go with the kayak over the falls! Picture it: you're standing in a kayak with this cow, trying to untie the rope around their neck by getting your sword to cut it at the right angle. You can't hurt the cow or knock over the kayak. Can you solve it in time?!

mnemonics.meaning: Taking out your thread, you sew together the public's hearts to make them whole again. The world has been in turmoil and the public has been suffering, but it's time to stop splitting our hearts apart and fighting. It's time to be whole again.
mnemonics.reading: Once their hearts are whole, the public's soul (そう) becomes one! Suddenly people who were fighting for years are crying and holding one another. Their souls recognize each other, they're healed, and the whole nation is finally seeing eye to eye.

mnemonics.meaning: A truth occasion is reality. This word is also used a lot as an adverb (with or without the particle に) to mean actually or really.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The つ is shortened to っ.

sentences: 今現在、実際にトーフグは何名の顧客を抱えているのですか？
How many clients does Tofugu actually have at the moment?

mnemonics.meaning: You know how 宇宙 is space? Well, a person from space is an alien.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help to know how to read the word 宇宙 on its own, too.

sentences: コウイチの写真は、火星で干ばつと大恐慌の犠牲となった宇宙人たちを正直に、かつ同情を込めてとらえている。
Koichi’s photographs honestly and sympathetically portray aliens who were victims of drought and the Great Depression on Mars.

mnemonics.meaning: Your big enemy is your worst enemy. Your arch enemy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 分かっていると思うけど、油断大敵だよ。「猿も木から落ちる」って言うだろう？
As you all know, overconfidence is man’s greatest enemy. People say "even monkeys fall from trees," right?

mnemonics.meaning: You have rights to profit! This is a right you have!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私たちには反対する権利があります。
We have the right to object.
これは国民の権利です。
This is a citizen's right.
今日本では選きょで投ひょうする権利を20才から18才に引き下げるか議論しています。
In Japan they currently are debating whether the eligible age for voting rights should be lowered from twenty to eighteen.

mnemonics.meaning: With the whole body. Do it as a whole instead of as a part, or something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 我々は、お客様に総体的に満足して頂けるよう努力しています。
We are concentrating on the overall satisfaction of our customers.

mnemonics.meaning: A tribe that runs wild (暴走) is what the Japanese call a biker gang. Just imagine them riding around on their bikes, running wild. They're also close, like a family. How nice!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ビエトさん、あなたが暴走族をしていた頃のエピソードについて、早急にお返事いただけると幸いです。
Mr. Viet, I would be grateful if you could reply as soon as possible about your time spent in a biker gang.

mnemonics.meaning: A writing that has been evaluated has gotten a book review.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その本についての批判的な書評があまりにも多いので、買う気が失せたよ。
There were so many critical reviews of a book I was thinking of reading that I lost my desire to buy it.

mnemonics.meaning: Take all the separate parts. Now untie them, unraveling the connections between the two parts. In this way we can do a breakdown. We're dismantling or disassembling something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: アルコールの分解を進めてくれます。
It promotes the breakdown of alcohol.
小さいころ、よく時計を分解してあそんでいました。
When I was little, I would play with watches by disassembling them.
電気分解の分解効率を向上させることはできる、お父さん？
Can you improve the decomposition efficiency of electrolysis, dad?

mnemonics.meaning: With time your body will acquire a certain type of character. It shows your true nature as a person. Note: We almost always use this word in the phrases 得体が知れない/得体の知れない, so check out the context sentences to see what kind of "character" we're talking about.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

sentences: こんな得体の知れないもの、食べられないよ。
I can’t eat something so strange.
得体の知れない男がさっきからこっちを見ていると思ったら、トーフグのコウイチだった。
I thought a mysterious man was looking at me, but it turned out to be Koichi from Tofugu.
得体の知れない何かが、猛スピードで迫ってくるような感覚に襲われ、冷や汗が止まらなくなりました。
I suddenly felt as if something unidentifiable was coming towards me at furious speeds and I started sweating with fear.

mnemonics.meaning: We're going to need to examine and inspect you for our annual checkup, mmk? Now drop your pants and cough, please.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 病院で検査を受けました。
I received a checkup at the hospital.
検査の結果、エンジンには何のいじょうも認められませんでした。
Upon inspection, we could not find anything wrong with the engine.
北米でギョウ虫検査があまり一般的ではないなんて、驚きです。
I was surprised that pinworm tests aren’t commonly administered in North America.

mnemonics.meaning: Cloth from the earth is still cloth, just a little dirty.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, you've learned them both already!

sentences: レースを布地にたたきつけた。
I stitched lace into cloth.

mnemonics.meaning: I've untied all the reason and made it even simpler, making it easier to understand. This increases my comprehension and understanding by quite a bit!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチのアイデアは、いつもみんなの理解をこえています。
Koichi's ideas are always beyond everybody's comprehension.
油と水が混じらないということは理解しています。
I understand that oil and water don't mix.
愛してるよ、ソファー。お前だけは俺のことを理解してくれる。
I love you, sofa. Only you understand me.

mnemonics.meaning: They have strong control over us. That's why they can make us do all this compulsory stuff. We have to do it. They're too strong!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 母は、フグと私がこのアール・デコ様式の建物に引っ越すよう強制しました。
My mother forced Fugu and I to move into this historic art-deco property.

mnemonics.meaning: A clause in the matter complicates things. It adds conditions, terms and requirements to an otherwise simple matter.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: フグ、金曜の夜の飲み会に行ってもいいけど、一つだけ条件があるわ。お酒は飲まないでね。
Fugu, you can go to the drinking party on Friday night, but on one condition - you can’t drink alcohol.

mnemonics.meaning: Just be sure to make certain that you recognize him. We need confirmation and verification, so make certain again, please.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 確認画面が出たらIDとパスワードを入力してログインをしてください。
When the confirmation screen shows up, please enter your ID and password to login.

mnemonics.meaning: Build and establish. To do this, you'll need to do lots of construction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私はかつて古代ローマが建設された丘の近くに住んでいた。
I used to live near the hills on which the ancient city of Rome was built.

mnemonics.meaning: It is correct you have solved the answer, getting the correct answer. You'll see this on Japanese game shows a lot. 正解！！！
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 正解です！
That's correct!
クイズ大会で難しい問題に正解したので、とてもはなが高いです。
I managed to give the correct answer to a difficult question during the quiz competition, so I'm really proud of myself.
コウイチには内緒にしておいて、正解だったね。
We were right about keeping it a secret from Koichi.

mnemonics.meaning: A group that has power using violence? Sounds like a crime syndicate to me, probably the Yakuza or some other gangster organization .
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 暴力団と関東連合の違いは何ですか？
What’s the difference between the Yakuza and Kanto Rengo?

mnemonics.meaning: A criticism is when you judge. It is still just a criticism.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 批判の的となっても仕方がないと思っている。
Sometimes you can’t help but be the subject of criticism.

mnemonics.meaning: Evaluate my theory. Then, when you evaluate, please give me critique and criticism to help me get better?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 映画の中で十歳の女の子が評論をしているのが可愛いのよね。
It’s so cute to see a ten year old girl make a critique in a movie.

mnemonics.meaning: You know how いい加減 is unfounded or pointless? Because if you add and then decrease you haven't really done anything? Well, this is like saying "do the pointless!" Okay, that doesn't make any sense. This is a phrase that means something similar to cut it out or cut the BS!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as いい加減, which you (hopefully) learned earlier.

sentences: ビエトはあまりにも怒っていたので、コウイチを殴って「いい加減にしろ！」と叫ばずにはいられなかった。
Viet was so angry that he couldn’t restrain himself from punching Koichi and screaming, "Cut it out!"

mnemonics.meaning: Please determine what righteousness means. I want the definition for it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: スパムメールの定義は何ですか？
What’s the definition of spam mail?

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 飲酒 is "drinking alcohol" and 運転する is "to drive", so it makes sense that this word means drunk driving, or drinking and driving.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 飲酒運転は犯罪です。
Drunk driving is a crime.
飲酒運転はしたくないから、タクシーで帰るよ。
I don't want to drink and drive, so I'll go home by taxi.
自転車でも飲酒運転とみなされるとは知りませんでしたが、なるほどと思いました。
I didn't know it was considered drunk driving with a bicycle, but that makes sense.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a duty. You have a task. You have both a duty and a task to do.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 任務完了前に撤退することは許されないとコウイチに言われました。
Koichi told me that I’m not allowed to leave before the job is done.

mnemonics.meaning: When a passage of time comes to an end, you look back on it and see how well you did. Did we make more money? Did we make less? That's all economics, baby (that's money, baby!).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The さい changes to ざい, though, so watch out for that.

sentences: コウイチが大統領に就任してからというもの、アメリカの経済は急ピッチで回復している。
Since Koichi was inaugurated as President, the US economy has continued to recover at a rapid pace.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to choose someone and raise them up to office. This is an election.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチは、選挙演説中にブルースを歌って声がつぶれた。
Koichi lost his voice from singing the blues during his election speech.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. No enemies here!

sentences: 「フグ、あなたはどっちの味方なの？私の敵なの？」「僕は君の味方だよ、サーモン。」
"Which side are you on, Fugu? Are you my enemy?" "I’m on your side, Salmon."

mnemonics.meaning: Envy consumes your hope turning it all to envy and jealousy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: ハチは、犬界での羨望の的だ。
Hachi is a target of jealousy in the dog world.
彼は、あまりにも美味しそうなカレーパンを食べていたため羨望の視線を浴びた。
He was eating such delicious-looking curry bread that he attracted envious stares.
ゴードンへの羨望の気持ちが抑えきれず、料理の道へ進みました。
I couldn't ignore my envious feelings toward Gordon and I decided to pursue my career in cuisine.

mnemonics.meaning: I will judge and inspect you. This is an examination, so we'll see if you pass.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この論文はもう一度審査にかけるべきだ。
We should review this paper again.
私のパスポートに上陸許可の判子を押してくれた入国審査官は、コウイチにそっくりでした。
The immigration inspector, who stamped my passport with the landing permission seal, looked just like Koichi.

mnemonics.meaning: When you untie a theory for someone, you're taking it apart and making it more understandable to them. You are doing an explanation of something for them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの先生の解説はとても分かり易いね。
The teacher’s explanation is really easy to understand.

mnemonics.meaning: You know how 履く is to put on shoes or put on boots, right? Well, what are those things called? How about footwear or shoes?
mnemonics.reading: The reading is that of 履く and 物 put together. Just know those separately and you should be able to figure this one out as well.

sentences: 日本語で、屋内の履き物は「上履き」、屋外の履き物は「外履き」と呼ばれます。
In Japanese, indoor footwear is called "uwabaki" and outdoor footwear is called "sotobaki."

mnemonics.meaning: The main resources are the funds and capital we're getting. Everything else can be gotten using said funds, which is why they're the main resources we have!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ベンチャー・キャピタル、いわゆる冒険資本が不足するには、わけがあります。
There’s a reason for the venture capital shortage.

mnemonics.meaning: The resources of gold that we have are our current funds. If the resources include a lot of gold, then we have a lot of funds. If they don't, then we don't have a lot of funds.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 資金が底をつき始めたときに、パリでホテル代を払ってくれるというあの素晴らしいお方にお会いしたのです。
When we started running out of funds, we met a wonderful person in Paris who offered to pay for our hotel bills.

mnemonics.meaning: The sect that stands the highest are those who are high class, splendid, and fine. 立派だ!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The りつ shortens to りっ though, so keep an eye on that you splendid frood you. Oh and は changes to ぱ too. Because rendaku and all that.

sentences: 私の猫は立派な髯を生やしているので、「ヒゲ」と名付けました。
My cat grew very handsome whiskers, so I named him Hige.

mnemonics.meaning: People Rights are human rights.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 服装規定が人権侵害にあたることがあるという人もいますが、それについてどう思いますか？
Some people say that dress codes can violate human rights. What do you think about that?

mnemonics.meaning: An action matter is really just something that happens. It's an incident or case.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この「盗まれたコウイチの下着」事件について、できるだけ早く報告してください。
Get back to me as soon as possible about the incident regarding Koichi’s stolen underwear.

mnemonics.meaning: An increase will add to what you had before. This is an increase, addition, or growth.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: お正月に餅を食べ過ぎて、体重が五十キロも増加した。
I ate way too much mochi on New Years and my weight increased by 50 kilos.

mnemonics.meaning: You have an  occasion to check out another country. Wow, so international!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチは国際会議でトーフグの開発成果について発表する予定です。
Koichi is going to announce the development of Tofugu at an international conference.

mnemonics.meaning: Go ahead and throw your resources at the project. It could use the investment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!

sentences: リスクの高い投資商品にまで手を出したくはないんです。
I don’t want to get involved in high risk investments.

mnemonics.meaning: The main cause behind someone's righteousness is usually what isms, principles or doctrines they believe in. Buddhism, Shintoism, socialism, communism, you name it. If you believe in one of those it's the main driving factor behind what you believe righteousness to be.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: フグは肉を食べないよ。菜食主義者だからさ。
Fugu doesn’t eat meat. He’s a vegetarian.

mnemonics.meaning: I judge to cut off your head. That is my judgment!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 食用キノコか毒キノコかを、素人が判断するのは難しい。
It is difficult for an amateur to judge whether a mushroom is edible or poisonous.
よく人を見た目で判断してはいけないと言いますが、それは本当に正しいことだと思いますか？
We often say that we shouldn't judge people by their appearance, but do you think it's really true?
これまでに聞いたことから判断すると、どうやら真打ちは最後にあるようだね。
Judging from what I've heard so far, the best seems to have been saved for last.
私の母はいつも人を見た目で判断してはいけないと言っていたのに、父が禿げたことだけを理由に父と離婚しました。
My mother always told me not to judge people by their appearance, but she divorced my father just because he went bald.

mnemonics.meaning: This word has judge and judge in it, so it has something to do with judgment. It's usually used in sports, so it's the referee or umpire, depending on your sport of choice.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for rendaku turning はん into ぱん (as is so often the case after ん).

sentences: 私は審判でもあり、スポーツ解説者でもあります。
I’m not only a referee, but also a sports analyst.

mnemonics.meaning: The correct righteousness is always your righteousness. It is your form of justice.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: トーフグチームは正義の味方です！
Team Tofugu takes the side of justice!
戦争に正義はないと思います。
I believe there is no righteousness in war.
正義と悪についてずっと考えてきましたが、まだ正解が見えないんだ。
I have been thinking about justice and evil for a long time, but I haven't found the right answer.

mnemonics.meaning: What does your heart want to acquire above all other things? Knowledge! That's why you're here isn't it? Dig deep and see that all your heart wants is more information and understanding of Japanese to be happy.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 先輩が就職活動の心得を教えてくれました。
My senpai passed on his knowledge about job hunting.

mnemonics.meaning: The element of enemy isn't something you should think of as bad. You have to have the "enemy element" if you are to have lovely, dreamy, and beautiful things too. This is a good word when you're talking about some dude you think is hawt. Doesn't work as well with girls.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 素 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Oh wow, you look really lovely in that suit (す). Yes, I can see you through the Internet, and I have to say, that suit is just dreamy! Don't ever take it off.

sentences: 彼の他の人を助けたいっていう熱意が、素敵だなって思うのよね。
I find him attractive because of his enthusiasm for helping others.

mnemonics.meaning: If you use resources to make material, you'll have material. This is in the sense of material for a book, or data and documents for research.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 色んな資料が、箱の中で混ぜこぜになっていました。
The various materials were mixed up in the box.
その警察官は、資料の情報だけで事件を解決してしまった。
The police officer had solved the case using only the information in the documents.
もしよろしければ、いくつか資料をお送りさせて頂けませんでしょうか？
If you don’t mind, would I be able to send you some data?

mnemonics.meaning: A committee member is a member of a committee (or a committee member).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 風紀委員は、保健体育の授業で教師が夢精について生徒たちに教える必要は無いと判断した。
The school’s disciplinary committee decided that teachers don’t need to teach students about wet dreams in the physical education class anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: Let us conserve our tasks. We will give it to the Ministry Of Tasks!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ビエト財務省国際局次長は現在ダイエット中であり、砂糖の代わりにサッカリンを用いているため、彼の食事には砂糖を使用しないでください。
Mr. Viet, Senior Deputy Director General, International Bureau, Ministry of Finance, is on a diet right now and substitutes sugar with saccharin, so don’t use sugar in his meal.

mnemonics.meaning: A 形容詞 is an adjective. So what about an adjective with a 動詞 (verb) in there? How does that make sense? I'm not entirely sure either, but an adjective with movement in it is a na adjective. These are the adjectives that can end with な (便利な, for example). In fact, they're more like nouns than they are verbs, so what gives? Whatever it is, just decide you don't want to deal with this craziness. Just say nah, I don't care about this anymore.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 形容詞 and 動詞 as well, since they're both parts of this word.

sentences: 今日の授業は形容動詞でした。
Today’s class was on na-adjectives.
頭の中で、形容動詞と形容詞が混ぜこぜになってしまっていて、かなり混乱しています。
I mixed up na-adjectives with i-adjectives and now I'm really confused.
それが形容動詞なのかただの形容詞なのか、判断にまよいました。
I found it difficult to judge whether it was a na-adjective or just an i-adjective.

mnemonics.meaning: My righteousness task is my obligation to these people. I will go out and purge the world of evil, be righteous, and make things happen. It's my duty!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 家事をするのは、夫と子どもに対する妻の義務だと言う人が多くいますが、果たしてそれは本当でしょうか？
Many people say that doing housework is a wife’s obligation to her husband and children, but is that really true?

mnemonics.meaning: The place where actions and tasks happen is the office. None of that happens at home. The office is more of an action / task place.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この事務所では、喫煙は認められていません。
Smoking is not allowed in this office.
この事務所には、余計な金はビタ一文も無いんだよ。
There's not a dime of extra money in this office.
当社トーフグの事務所を簡単にご案内させてください。
Let me quickly show you around the Tofugu office.

mnemonics.meaning: Okayama (岡山) Prefecture is a prefecture in Japan. Learning the reading will help you to remember the meaning of this word since half of it is in Japanese.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the first two kanji. Luckily you learned them when you learned the kanji. Then, stick 県 on there and you should be good to go!

sentences: 岡山県には、土地特有の建築物はありますか？
Is there any vernacular architecture in Okayama prefecture?

mnemonics.meaning: The child of a judge is the thing he puts on his judgements. What does he put on his judgments? His seal, you know, to make it all official and stuff.
mnemonics.reading: 判 is the reading you learned. 子 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which I bet you know pretty well by now as well. You just have to remember to use it here.

sentences: 判子屋さんで、判子を注文しました。
I ordered my personal seal at a seal store.
ここにはサイン、そこには判子をおしてください。
Please sign here and put your seal there.
この書類には、コウイチによって公的な判子が押されています。
This document was officially sealed by Koichi.

mnemonics.meaning: My idea of duty is that you don't really have to do it. It's optional, you know?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 名前と住所は法律で答えなくてはいけないと決まっているものですか？それとも任意ですか？
Do I legally have to tell you my name and address, or is it optional?

mnemonics.meaning: When you take the whole and join it together, you get a good overall picture of things.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ワニカニは、総合すると良くできたサイトです。
Overall, WaniKani is a well-built website.
うちのクラスは、体育大会の総合の部でゆう勝しました。
Our class got the highest overall score on sports day.
オリンピックの総合メダル獲得数では、アメリカが一位だった。
America got first place in overall total medals in the Olympics.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 参加 is participation, so someone who does participation is a participant.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 映画好きのパーティーの最年長参加者は、なんと百歳だった。
Surprisingly, the oldest participant of the moviegoer party was 100 years old.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your plan and make a drawing out of it. This is your plan.
mnemonics.reading: The かく reading was not the one you learned with the kanji. It is an exception that was introduced with the word 計画 not long back. Just keep that in mind and you'll be fine.

sentences: 初めまして。私は経営企画部部長のコウイチと申します。
Nice to meet you. I am Koichi, the head of project management.

mnemonics.meaning: The police (警察) government is full of police officers. This is the formal way to say "police officer." It is similar to 警官, but has a slightly more official feel to it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 警察官が容疑者を発見した際、男は丘の上で美しい風景画を描いていました。
When the police officer found the suspect, he was painting a beautiful landscape on a hilltop.

mnemonics.meaning: He's the whole reason this country is still running. If it wasn't for the prime minister here we'd all be doomed I say. DOOMED! Note that this is actually an abbreviation of the word 総理大臣. You'll be learning the second part of that compound soon!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 元総理も同じ考えをもっていました。
The former prime minister had the same idea.
森総理がおっしゃっていた通りになりましたね。
It turned out just as Prime Minister Mori said it would.
昨日の総理の答弁はもう聞きましたか？
Did you hear the prime minister's answer yesterday?

mnemonics.meaning: Someone takes your hand and shows you how to continue. "This is the procedure," they say. Move your hand like this. Verrrryyy goood. Good procedure. Good!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of 手 and 続く put together into one. Darn these body parts making everything kun'yomi.

sentences: 誰だって面倒な手続きは避けたい。
Everybody wants to avoid troublesome formalities.
手続きがふくざつで、頭が混乱してどうしていいか分からなくなりました。
The procedure was very complicated and I got so confused that I didn't know what to do.
先週、子どもを学校に入学させる手続きを終えました。
Last week I finished the process of enrolling my child in school.

mnemonics.meaning: A noun (名詞) that has hardness is a noun that can't be budged. It's a big noun, so big that you have to capitalize these kinds of nouns in English. It is a proper noun.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 名詞 as well.

sentences: しりとりに固有名詞は使えません。
You can’t use proper nouns in the game Shiritori.

mnemonics.meaning: It's public establishment. It is public.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 来年度から、公設の委員会を設けることになりました。
Starting next year we will establish a public committee.
確かあの公園に公設便所があったはずだよ。
If I remember correctly, I think there is a public restroom in that park.
もし沖縄を旅行するなら、牧志公設市場に行った方がいいよ。
If you travel to Okinawa, you should go to Makishi Public Market.

mnemonics.meaning: The credible resources that determine your professional status are your qualifications. You need some good ones if you want to get into a good school or land a sweet job.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一流の資格を持っていたって、食いっぱぐれることはあるさ。
You can have the best qualifications and still lose the ability to make a living.

mnemonics.meaning: When you want to use the most basic elements of a material, you end up with raw materials. Maybe it's the raw materials you're going to use to build a house. Maybe it's the raw materials you need to make a good soup. Either way, they haven't been touched much (yet).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 素 is the そ reading, so be careful. You can remember by thinking how you have to sew the building together using these raw materials.

sentences: その素材を選んだアヤの判断は正しかった。
Aya was right in her decision to go with that raw material.
このレストランでは、素材そのものの味を楽しんでもらうために味付けは控えめにしています。
In this restaurant, seasoning is kept to a minimum for you to enjoy the natural taste of the ingredients.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're anti conserve, I'm going to ask you to do some heavy reconsideration and reflection, and see if that's really the right way to be. Think long and hard, okay? Why don't you want to conserve things? They're precious, after all.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 反 is all good. The reading for 省 is an on'yomi reading you haven't seen yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm standing in front of you, forcing a reconsideration of your anti conserve stance, with my saber (せい) to your throat. I better see some reflection on your face or you won't have one in a second.

sentences: 反省しているので、そんなにきつく当たらないでください。
I’ve been reflecting on it, so please don’t be so hard on me.

mnemonics.meaning: When people evaluate and judge you at every turn, it means you have quite a reputation, and indeed fame. Wouldn't this be terrible if people evaluated and judged you 24/7? Having that kind of reputation or fame would be difficult.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this on'yomi for 判 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To preserve your reputation, you always wear a pair of big Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses when you're out and about. That way nobody recognizes you, and you can behave however you want, without damaging your reputation.

sentences: あの野球評論家は、あまり評判が良くないんだよ。
That baseball commentator doesn't have a very good reputation.
この地域は昔はスラム街でしたが、政府の戦略としての居住地域の高級化が功を奏し、住環境ががらっと変わったんですよ。今は評判もすこぶるいいです。
This area used to be a slum, but the governmental strategy of gentrification has changed the neighborhood and now it has a really good reputation.

mnemonics.meaning: You can blame duty all you want, but you still have a responsibility as well, no matter what your duty dictates.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本のサラリーマンは責任を取る事を嫌がる傾向にある。
Japanese salarymen tend to hate taking responsibility.

mnemonics.meaning: Self control is self control and self restraint. Have some!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私としては、断然フランボワイヤン様式の方が良かったんですが、そこはまぁ自制しています。
I definitely prefer flamboyant styles, but I practice self restraint.

mnemonics.meaning: You have righteousness and then a reason behind it, at least in your own mind. This is your sense of duty. And it really is a "sense" in a way, too. You just feel it. It's not an actual thing that is tangible. It is your own personal reason for this righteousness. This word can also mean in-law like your mother-in-law, because they're your mother in the social obligation sense only, not by blood.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 義理の父に義理チョコを買いました。
I bought an obligatory box of chocolates for my father in law.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a weird one. Just think about the sect of hands. They are always doing jazz hands and things like that, trying to be all showy and flashy. Ugh, what a dumb sect, you think.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, though て goes to で.

sentences: ドレスが派手すぎるので、ブライズ・メイドには絶対なりたくありません。
I never want to be a bridesmaid because the dresses are too flashy.

mnemonics.meaning: Even though the kanji mainly means  occasion, for some reason this word means side or edge. I suppose on occasion kanji takes you to the edge of what ought to make sense when it comes to kanji.
mnemonics.reading: You're on the very edge of the world. You heard that at the edge of the world are the key words (きわ) written there in big fiery letters, telling you the meaning of life. Supposedly these are the words of God himself. They say: "We apologize for the inconvenience." WHAT? THESE ARE THE KEY WORDS???

sentences: 小さい頃、友人達と毎日水際で遊んでいました。
When I was little, I would play by the water’s edge every day with my friends.

mnemonics.meaning: To solve the problem we decided to come up with a solution, a way of solving the problem.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチはお金で何でも解決できると思っている。
Koichi thinks he can solve any problem with money.
いい解決策が思いつかないんだよね。
I can't come up with any good solutions.
トーフグの株式を上場させる前に、解決しなければならない難題がまだ山積みになっている。
Before taking Tofugu public, many difficult problems that have been piling up have to be solved.

mnemonics.meaning: You know how 宇宙 is outer space and how 船 is ship, right? Well, put those together and you have an outer space ship (better known as a space ship).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 宇宙 beforehand as well.

sentences: 十六台の宇宙船のほとんど全てが、保持され改装されました。
Nearly all of the sixteen space ships were retained and refurbished.

mnemonics.meaning: An  increase that hurries is an increase that's quick. How about a sudden increase?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 近年の、自制心が欠けている若者の急増について、フグ先生はどうお考えですか。
What do you think about the sudden increase in the number of young people who lack self-control in recent years, Dr. Fugu?
ちょっとした批判にも耳をかたむけられない人が急増している気がします。
I feel that there's been a sudden increase in the number of people who can't accept even the slightest criticism.
振り付け師になるのが夢だという子どもが、急増しています。
The number of children who dream of being a choreographer has increased suddenly.

mnemonics.meaning: I have a suspicion (容疑) about someone. That someone is my main suspect.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to be able to read 容疑 first, though.

sentences: その容疑者は、どういう訳か十代の若者たちに大志と楽観主義のメッセージを伝えた。
The suspect somehow conveyed a message of ambition and optimism to teenagers.

mnemonics.meaning: You control every degree of this system. Think about a system. It's designed to create more control for you, degree by degree by degree. That's why they call it "The system," after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: これは、新制度についての初心者向け案内書です。
This guidebook for the new system is intended for beginners.

mnemonics.meaning: The tax gold is what you have to pay when you have to pay a tax.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の両親があなたを養子縁組したのは、ただ税金の控除を受けたかったのが理由です。
My parents only adopted you because they needed the tax deduction.

mnemonics.meaning: When the tax is nothing things are tax free.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: お酒が無税だったらいいのにな。
I wish alcohol was tax-free.

mnemonics.meaning: When you increase tax you're doing a tax increase.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 増税するなんて、絶対に認めません。
I will never accept a tax increase.
増税のせいで、五十円余計にはらうことになりました。
Because of the tax increase, I had to pay an extra 50 yen.
さっき届いた請求書の固定資産税が、50%も増税されてたんだけど、間違いだよね。そうであってほしい。
I just received a 50% increase on my property tax, but it’s a mistake. At least, I hope it is.

mnemonics.meaning: If 混乱 is confusion then making it into a verb would cause it to be confused.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 混乱 so no reason for you to be confused, right?

sentences: 君はおそらく混乱すると思うけど、弟は今、死への恐怖を克服しようと必死で努力しているところなの。だから、そっとしておいてあげてくれないかな？
You’re probably confused, but my brother is striving to overcome his fear of death right now, so please leave him alone.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means solve so the verb vocab version is to be solved. It can also mean to be untied. You know that this is the version where something just unties on its own (you're not doing the untying) because you don't have a care (ける) in the world. You just watch things getting untied and don't do it yourself.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In fact, while you're sitting there with no cares, waiting for things to become untied, you stare down at your toe (と). Really imagine doing that while things around you are getting untied.

sentences: くつひもが解けているよ。危ないから、早く結んだ方がいいよ。
Your shoelaces are untied. That's dangerous, you should hurry up and tie them.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blame so this is to blame.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You say (せ) I did it. I say you did it. Everyone is going to blame everyone, apparently!

sentences: 「自分でちゃんと確かめるべきだったよ。」「そんなに自分を責めないで。あなたのせいじゃないわよ。」
"I should have checked it out myself." "Don’t blame yourself. It wasn’t your fault."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means come to an end so the verb vocab version is to come to an end.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your romp finally has to come to an end when someone decides to sue (す) you for all your romping.

sentences: 謝ったんだけど、「これは謝って済む問題じゃない」なんて言われちゃって、それで頭にきて彼の顔をひっぱたいちゃったのよね。
I apologized, but he told me that apologizing wouldn’t end the problem, and because of that, I slapped him in the face.

mnemonics.meaning: This is like 続く except for now you're the one doing the continuing. Unfortunately, there's no good way to differentiate the two "continues" using just the meaning, but you can think of it this way: With ける, you really care about continuing this thing so you are continuing it (doing the action of continuing). With く you're just like "that's coo' if it continues, but I don't really care...
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 続く, so be sure to know that so you can know this.

sentences: 一日中寝続けられるので、週末は最高だ。
Weekends are awesome because I can continue to sleep all day long.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decrease so the verb vocab version is to decrease. You can differentiate this from 減る because with this one, you are the one that is going to be doing the decreasing. The rush (らす) of decreasing something fills your veins.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 減る, so if you know that reading you should know this one.

sentences: その疫病は、河豚の数をそれまでの水準の半分に減らした。
The plague reduced the number of blowfish to half its previous level.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means envy so the verb version is to envy someone.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're really starting to envy those uranium Yankees (うらや). That's the new Yankees team hopped up on uranium that were created in a lab. Even though they're gross and hulk-ish, they're really good at baseball, so you're jealous of them.

sentences: コウイチは、世界が羨む男だ。
Koichi is a man the world envies.
人は他人の幸せを羨む傾向がある。
People have the tendency to envy others' happiness.
いつか誰もが羨む名声と富を手に入れたいです。
One day, I want to acquire wealth and fame that anyone would envy.

mnemonics.meaning: When you establish and determine something, you are making an establishment. When you make that into a verb, you have the word to establish. It also works for tech things, like to set up your computer settings.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful because the 設 gets shortened to せっ.

sentences: あなたの新しいビジネス用のメールアカウントを、グーグルに設定しました。
I set up a new business mail account in Google for you.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means establish so the verb vocab version is to establish.
mnemonics.reading: What are you going to establish? How about a new bar in Springfield called Moue's (もう). You had to add that extra "u" in there because "Moe's" was already taken. Do'h!

sentences: コウイチは、新しい従業員規則を設けることを検討しているようです。
Koichi often considers establishing new rules for his employees.

mnemonics.meaning: Double frustration would cause anyone to get irritated, to get annoyed, or to grow impatient.
mnemonics.reading: This isn’t the reading you learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You don’t just get irritated, you get ira-ira-tated (いらいら). That's the next level up from irritated. This word is often written in katakana or hiragana, but you'll sometimes see it in kanji too, so it's worth knowing!

sentences: あの人、いつも苛々しているね。
That person is always irritated, huh?
運転しながら苛々しないでよ。
Don't get impatient while you're driving.
私だって苛々したくてしてる訳じゃないよ。
It's not like I’m trying to get annoyed.

mnemonics.meaning: This word ends with a う sound so you can guess it's a verb. The kanji means nothing, and you'll end up with nothing if you want to to get rid of something, to do away with something or to lose something. This verb is transitive, so the action is happening to something. So maybe you're getting rid of debt, or discrimination, or stress... Whatever it is, there's a direct object with this verb!
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you already learned when you learned the word 無し.

sentences: 日本語のアメリカなまりを無くしたいな。
I wish I could get rid of my American accent in Japanese.
何よりもストレスを無くすことが大切です。
The most important thing is to do away with stress.
ご自身が自信を無くした原因は何だと思いますか。
What do you think caused you to lose your self-confidence?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give birth so the verb vocab version is to give birth. You know another 産む as well (生む). This 産む is more sciency, but both are good to know.
mnemonics.reading: You know another "to give birth" word (生む). Guess what!? They share readings!

sentences: あの人、去年の冬に赤ちゃんを産んだばかりなのに今年の秋にもまた赤ちゃんを産むんですって。
I heard that person just gave birth to a baby last winter and that she'll have another one this fall.
カマキリが産んだたまごの中からたくさんの赤ちゃんカマキリが出てきました。
A lot of baby mantises came out of the egg that the mantis laid.
コウイチ先生：よし、もう一度いきむ準備はいいかい？君は双子の赤ちゃんを産むんだよ！ サーモン：もう一人生んだじゃない。放っておいてよ。 フグ：大丈夫、大丈夫。頑張れ、サーモン！君ならできるよ！
Dr. Koichi: Okay. You ready to push again? You are going to have twins! Salmon: I already gave birth to one baby. Leave me alone. Fugu: Okay, okay, come on, you can do it. You can do it!

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means increase, so the vocabulary verb version means to increase. This is when something is just increasing on its own, and you're not doing the increasing. You know this because you like to err (える) on the side of caution and not touch anything when it's increasing, therefore you're not doing any of the increasing yourself (it's just happening).
mnemonics.reading: It would be foolish (ふ) of you to touch anything while things are increasing anyways. You don't want to mess up a good thing, do you? Don't be a fool.

sentences: ここ5年間、ビエトの一日当たりの飲酒量が増えてきています。
Over the past five years, Viet’s daily amount of alcohol has been increasing.

mnemonics.meaning: You examine the problem. In order to do this, you need to inspect it or to examine it. And if you're inspecting people like this, you're probably the police.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 警察が私の車を検問している時、どきどきしました。
While the police were inspecting my car, my heart was racing.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conserve... but why stop there when you could try to omit everything and to eliminate everything? Just take exactly what you need, conserve it, and omit everything else.
mnemonics.reading: You have (はぶ) what you have, and omit what you don't need. Perfect life.

sentences: このロボットが多くの人手を省くはずだったが、状況は変化しないままである。
This robot was supposed to eliminate many human worker’s hands, but the situation remains unchanged.

mnemonics.meaning: You know how 参加 is participation? Well, make that a verb with する and you have yourself to participate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the reading of 参加.

sentences: 今週の日曜日、摩天楼の見学ツアーに参加します。
I’m participating in the skyscraper observation tour this Sunday.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 説得 is persuasion, so what is the verb version of that? To persuade.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also immensely help to know the reading of the word 説得.

sentences: ロックミュージシャンになるには、親父を説得する必要がある。
In order to become a rock musician, I need to persuade my dad.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plan so the verb vocab version is to plan.
mnemonics.reading: What are you trying to plan? No. Wait. How could you? You're trying to plan a coup? Whadda (くわだ) you thinking???

sentences: 「何それ？」「わっ！何でもないよ。」「何か企てているでしょう？」
"What is it?" "Ah, nothing!" "You’re planning something, aren’t you?!"

mnemonics.meaning: You know how 乱れる is "to be in disorder"? Well, now you're the one causing this. So, by doing this you are going to put in disorder, to throw out of order, or to disturb whatever it is. Just imagine all the people who will try to sue (す) you for your actions.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 乱れる, so hopefully you know it already.

sentences: そういう発言がみんなの和を乱しているってこと、気づいてないの？
Don't you realize that such comments disturb everyone's harmony?
かみを乱して走ったが、結局予定の飛行機には間に合わなかった。
I ran with my hair in disarray, but in the end I didn't make my scheduled flight.
注意欠陥過活動性障害の子どもは、生活のリズムを乱されることに耐えられないことが多いです。
Kids with ADHD typically can’t stand having the rhythm of their lives thrown out of order.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recognize so the verb vocab version is to recognize.
mnemonics.reading: The reason I was able to recognize you is because your face was covered in meat (みと). Your face was always covered in meat all those years ago too!

sentences: 認めるのは悔しいけど、今回はフグはいい仕事をしていると思うよ。
I hate to admit it, but I think Fugu is doing a great job this time.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut off. What happens when you do the action of cutting someone off? You're going to refuse them whatever it is they want.
mnemonics.reading: Deciding to refuse something unfortunately starts a coat war (like a pillow fight, but everyone hits each other with coats instead of pillows). Coats to the ready, and let the coat war commence!

sentences: その仕事を断るべきかどうか、判断にまよっています。
I'm still trying to decide whether I should refuse the job or not.
野球の試合の主審をたのまれたけど、断りました。サッカーの試合の主審だったら引き受けたんだけどね。
I was asked to be the chief umpire for a baseball game, but I rejected the offer. I would have done it if it was for the chief referee of a soccer game though.
コウイチ大統領はビエトを次期国務長官に任命したが、ビエトはそれを断った。
President Koichi appointed Viet as the next Secretary of State, but he refused.

mnemonics.meaning: When you raise something you are causing it to rise. This verb can also mean things like to be listed and to be nominated. For these additional meanings, you might want to imagine something rising up onto a list or someone rising up to a nomination, because lists and nominations are always high up.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The reading for this is the same as the other "to rise" word, 上がる. Nice how that works, right? So, just associate the two and you have yourself a reading.

sentences: 先生がそう言うと、たくさん手が挙がった。
When the teacher said that, many hands were raised.
自分がヒゲ大賞の候補に挙がっているなんて、信じられないよ。
I can’t believe that I’m nominated for the Mustache Award.
その時にトムの名前が挙がってましたね。
Tom's name was mentioned at the time, wasn't it?

mnemonics.meaning: If your eyes are awake then you're going to wake up. Your eyes are usually the first thing to awaken when you're waking up, you know?  This word can also mean to awaken but it's like when you to come to your senses, not literally waking up.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 覚 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you start to wake up in the middle of the night, it's because of the wake up wizard (ざ). He sneaks into your house when you're sleeping and pokes you with his wand. Wizards like when you wake up. They're weird.

sentences: この裏ワザを使うと、朝、すっきり目覚めることができます。
I use this lifehack in the morning so I can wake up properly.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means task so what's the verb vocab version? Well, when you do a task, you are going to work as or to serve as something to do that task.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  To work as my secretary, you will have to complete a task. A task where you bring me two toes (つと)! Don't ask me why! You want to serve as my assistant, right? Just get me those two toes then!

sentences: 父は去年まで四十年間警察官を務めました。
My father worked as a police officer for forty years until last year.
コウイチは色々な星からやってきた宇宙人をお世話するという大役を務めた。
Koichi served an important role of taking care of aliens from various planets.
田村さんは田中さんの個人秘書を一年間務めたんだけど、あまりうまくいかなかったんだよね。
Mr. Tamura was employed as Ms. Tanaka’s private secretary for one year, but it didn’t really work out.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 自動詞 was "intransitive verb"? Intransitive verbs are when something just happens. You aren't doing the action to them. This word, however, is the other kind. A transitive verb is when you are directly doing something to something else. That's why it has other in there, because it's a verb (動詞) you do to another thing, directly.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その動詞が他動詞か自動詞かを学ぶには、まる暗記するしかないのかな。
Is memorization the only way to learn if the verb is transitive or intransitive?

mnemonics.meaning: There are many clauses about the promises you make in this contract considering it's supposed to be a treaty.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチの今年の抱負は、ベルサイユ条約の全文を暗記することです。
Koichi’s New Year’s resolution is memorizing the entire text of the Treaty of Versailles.
