mnemonics.meaning: If you control people, you make them wear the same clothes. That's a uniform.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: アヤに、制服を着た女の子の絵を、立体派の画風を取り込みながら描いてもらいたいんだよね。
I want Aya to draw girls in school uniforms and integrate cubism style into it.

mnemonics.meaning: You have nothing when it comes to enemies. Why? It's not because you're super kind and everyone likes you. No, it's that you've defeated anyone who's tried. You are unrivaled and invincible.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: しりとりで、コウイチは無敵だ。
Koichi is invincible at Shiritori.

mnemonics.meaning: A mouth flute... Normal flutes you blow air through to make a sound. How do you blow air through your mouth to make a sound? By whistling.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi readings put together. Thank 口 for being a body part, which tends to cause this to happen. So, you have 口 (くち) and 笛 (ふえ) put together, though ふえ changes to ぶえ, maybe because you can't whistle properly? Buuuweeee. Buwwweee.

sentences: 口笛が下手くそなので、私が口笛を吹いても犬が来てくれません。
My dog doesn’t come to my whistle because I’m bad at whistling.

mnemonics.meaning: A woman's rights consist of women's rights.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 西洋と違い、日本では歴史上、大きな女権拡張運動は起きていない。
Unlike the West, Japan does not have a history of strong women’s rights movements.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means ability.

You have some legs and you need to put them in the trash. But you'll get caught if you put them in one trash can. Quick, cut them up and allocate them to different trash cans around the city. Then you'll never get caught.
See the dude sitting inside the box? His head is sticking out the top. That's a bathtub he's sitting in.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means cheap.

This is a squiggle with two lines through it. Hmmm doesn't that seem familiar? It should, because it's the dollar symbol: $. Well, close enough. Just look at this and think, ah yes, a totally normal American dollar.
Your friend is on the ground and you step on him with your cleat. There is no friendship here. This is a true sport you're playing. This is football.
This ice is in the shape of a stick. It's an icicle!

You use your fingers in the game of football to aid and assist the other players. And when you smash your fingers in football, you need to get some aid yourself. If you're from the UK, just imagine someone kicking or stomping on your fingers instead. Picture yourself playing football. You catch the ball with your fingers and then assist your team by running and smashing your body into the enemy team. But in the process you smash your fingers... so you need to go to the aid tent.
mnemonics.reading: When you need aid for your football wrecked fingers you can't help but feel like it's the end (えん) for you. Your fingers hurt so much, you don't even want the nice nurses to aid you. You can't assist your team anymore because you got hurt. This isn't fair! It's the end. The end of your life and your career. Boo hoo hoo!

mnemonics.meaning: You have a great ability because your heart gives you the appearance of a superhuman. Your heart is really strong and powerful, fuelling your body to the best of its ability. All this together gives you the appearance of someone in top condition. See yourself in this ideal appearance. Everyone loves to look at you because you look so awesome. Your heart has given you many great abilities. Feel strong and powerful in this body of yours.
mnemonics.reading: While you may have the appearance of someone who is super strong, powerful, and awesome, you do have one shortcoming. You don’t know how to tie (たい) a tie. Actually, you don’t even know how to tie your shoes, let alone your tie. How embarrassing. Since you don’t know how to tie a tie or tie your shoes, you wear slip ons and clip ons. Hear the noise of Velcro being undone as you kick off your shoes and unclip your tie after a hard day’s work at the office.

mnemonics.meaning: They say yoga is the correct way to go through birth. Birth isn't easy, but people keep telling you that yoga is the right way to prepare and actually do it. Picture multiple people you know saying you should do yoga if you plan to give birth. It isn't a question of whether you want to, it's the correct way to do it. So you should.
mnemonics.reading: To prepare for giving birth you end up doing so much yoga outside that you get a really deep tan (たん). Hopefully having a tan doesn't make birth harder, since you've worked so hard to do this the correct way with so much yoga.

mnemonics.meaning: There's an icicle on a dog. That is the dog's condition. Imagine a couple police officers looking at the dog, talking specifically about the condition they found the dog in.
mnemonics.reading: The frozen condition of this dog was caused by Jourm (じょう), the local farmhand. He forgot to let the dog back inside, and then it froze. But, did Jourm forget? We all know he's a bit clumsy and slow, but he's been letting the dog inside for years now. Would he really do this by accident? That's what the police seem to think, despite the condition they found the dog in.

mnemonics.meaning: You use the power of your mouth to spit shellfish at people as a form of congratulations! In fact, you yell "CONGRATULATIONS!" as the shellfish come pouring out of your powerful mouth. Shellfish were once used as currency, so this totally makes sense. Just think of the shellfish as money coming out of your mouth as you say your congratulations.
mnemonics.reading: When you say congratulations like this, you look just like a gargoyle (が). You're crouching down, your mouth wide open, just like a stone gargoyle. The next time you're congratulating someone, assume the gargoyle stance and dump all of their congratulatory shellfish on them from your mouth.

mnemonics.meaning: You kiss each of your best pals to show them how much you love and care for them. You kiss each friend right on the mouth. Imagine kissing each of your best friends on the mouth. Does this make you uncomfortable? Excited? Both? Feel that feeling.
mnemonics.reading: Actually, each of your best pals are of the cock (かく) variety. By that, I mean they are both roosters. Imagine kissing both of these cocks on their beaks. Kissing the cock beak is kind of a strange experience. Feel the feathers in your hands as you steady the cock to kiss it. Cock-a-doodle-doo!

mnemonics.meaning: Dollars and shellfish are used to pay expenses and costs. Shellfish used to be used as currency, so they're like the coins that go with dollars. Imagine opening your bank account and looking at all of your monthly expenses. Now drag the little dollar and shellfish icons over to cover all of those costs.
mnemonics.reading: What is the biggest expense and cost? It's the heat (ひ) bill. When you see how expensive your heat is, you feel a heat going through your body too.

mnemonics.meaning: “Bring in the next woman so that I may examine her figure!” We’re holding auditions for a commercial and we need to find a woman with a nice figure. The last woman was no good, so bring in the next one. Imagine yourself as a figure judge on this panel. You need to find a woman with the perfect figure to cast in your commercial. You'd cast yourself, but you just aren't confident (Ridiculous! You're special, and beautiful, and no matter who you are [yes you reading this right now] you should be proud of who you are!).
mnemonics.reading: The next woman comes in and you examine her figure. The figure you've been searching for! It just happens to belong to a sheep (し) woman. But she's soft, fluffy, and round. The perfect figure! We should all try harder to have a figure like this stunning sheep woman!

mnemonics.meaning: The womb is a circle of power where a force of nature is formed. The womb has the power to create life. Life is a force of nature, and the circle of life starts in the womb. Imagine yourself in the womb, the circle of power. You’re being born into the world. Feel the force of your mother all around you.
mnemonics.reading: Now pretend you're the mother. You'll need all the force you can muster to bring that baby into the world, so you grab hold of your special saber (せい) and slice it about in the air to give you the extra force you need. All that force works wonders, and when the baby's born you slice through the umbilical cord with your saber.

mnemonics.meaning: You have something to say, you stand on a towel, and shout, "I GIVE UP!"  Standing on a towel is the universal signal for giving up, but you still need to say you're abandoning whatever it is with your mouth too (just in case).
mnemonics.reading: After you announce that you are ready to give up, you throw all of your tater (てい) tots onto the ground. You have abandoned your goal of eating all of them. Look at the tater tots at your feet. You feel ashamed for giving up but you were so full, you had to give up! Now they're all down there mocking you.

mnemonics.meaning: You can use a jackhammer to indicate and show someone where the prize is buried. You buried the prize to keep it safe, but the jackhammer is great at unearthing it. Jackhammers do a great job and show where the treasure lies. They indicate quite clearly where one needs to go. Imagine using this jackhammer to show someone where the prize is buried. Feel the vibrations through your hands and the rest of your body.
mnemonics.reading: Actually, you're unearthing Jesus (じ). He’s the treasure. For your soul. He’s here to show you that Jesus is still a hip and cool guy and he wants to indicate to you that having faith in Jesus and God and stuff is super rad. Jesus is all like, “Who has two thumbs and wants to show you the way of the Lord? This guy.” Picture Jesus getting all over the top and super preachy about his religious beliefs. He’s doing everything he can to indicate to the crowd that he’s the best, and show them how cool he is. Listen to Jesus preach to the crowd, desperate for their attention.

mnemonics.meaning: From the roof, an icicle falls and hits wolverine in the forehead, and he has to go over to the stool to lie down. And eventually he goes to sleep. Picture this entire scene. The icicle falls in slow motion from the roof. It hits wolverine right in the middle of his forehead. He goes down. He has to lie down. He has to sleep.
mnemonics.reading: While wolverine sleeps, he makes a horrible neighing (ね) sound. It's like there's a giant horse in his mouth screaming to get out! NEIGH NEIGH! Wolverine might have a concussion that's making him neigh in his sleep. I guess it's good that he's laying down, but I'm pretty sure you're not supposed to sleep... Maybe you should wake him up so the neighing will stop—I mean, so he'll be okay!

mnemonics.meaning: A Viking who knows how to use a bathtub will have to manage all the baths for the other Vikings. Vikings aren't so great with bathing... if you can get one Viking to figure it out he has to manage the rest of them. Picture a Viking trying to manage his Viking friends so they'll use the bathtub properly. He has to manage which people go in when, how hot or cold the water is, and provide all the soap. It's a very important job.
mnemonics.reading: The poor Viking trying to manage all the others keeps having to confiscate acorns (えい). "You can't take baths in acorns and wood, it has to be water!" he shouts. Some of the Vikings managed to fill their bathtubs with acorns and are trying to rub themselves clean with them instead of water...

mnemonics.meaning: Can you look at the dirt and know which direction you need to go? Then you might be a monk. Monks have amazing skills like that. And I'm sure you've seen monks wandering around in lots of media. They don't need maps or smartphones. They just look at the dirt and let the earth guide them to where they need to be. Picture a monk walking through a large field in the middle of nowhere. He knows where to go, he's not afraid. The dirt will lead him in the right direction.
mnemonics.reading: You want to know the monk's trick so you hide behind him for a while as he walks. Finally the monk stops, looks around, takes out a bowling (ぼう) ball and starts bowling in the dirt. The bowling ball rolls off, the monk follows it, and then heads off in that direction. Imagine a monk bowling in the middle of the road. Imagine your shock at how well he handles the ball. Also, imagine how heavy it must be for a monk to carry a bowling ball everywhere!

mnemonics.meaning: If you try to say things with a knife, the police will put you in a net as your penalty for breaking the knife laws. You can't just go up to other people and say things with a knife out. Imagine getting so mad that you use a knife instead of words to say what you're trying to say. A net falls over you and pulls you down. The knife goes flying. This is your penalty for acting like a crazy person.
mnemonics.reading: Your penalty for breaking the law isn't over. Now that you're stuck in a net, you can't fight back when they hit you with bats (ばつ).  If you don't want to be punished with bats, maybe next time don't use a knife instead of your words.

mnemonics.meaning: With a bamboo tree resting atop your head, you devise a plan. The plan is actually for getting the bamboo tree off of your head. You’re trapped under it. Imagine being trapped under this bamboo tree that is resting on your head. You’re stuck. Feel the weight of the bamboo tree pressing on your head as you try and devise a plan to get out from under it.
mnemonics.reading: But why is this bamboo tree so heavy? You look to each end of the bamboo and realize that there is a sack (さく) tied on each end. Each sack seems to be filled with heavy rocks. Looks like someone made a plan to trap you here. Now you have to devise a plan to escape! Bamboo is usually kind of light, but this bamboo has a sack of rocks tied to each end making it heavy. Imagine yourself trying to remove this bamboo tree by pushing it up and away from you. It’s like doing a bench-press, bamboo style.

mnemonics.meaning: A cheap tree has a plan. A plan to stay cheap. Picture a tree coming up with some elaborate plans to make sure they can spend as little money as possible.
mnemonics.reading: The cheap tree's plan involves only buying anchovies (あん) and surviving on them. Good exposure to the sun and fresh water is too expensive. The tree plans to save money by eating anchovies. You're not sure about this anchovy plan. Are you cheap enough to choose a life of eating only anchovies?

mnemonics.meaning: Pointing your fingers to the sun is the correct way to present yourself or offer to submit your ideas. You're really just raising your hand. And when you want to present yourself, your ideas, or offer anything, the correct way is to raise your fingers to the sun. You definitely learned this in school. Picture yourself in class. You want to present next! You want to submit your ideas for class approval. So raise those fingers to the sun the correct way and wait for your teacher to call on you.
mnemonics.reading: You want to present your show and tell of tater tots (てい) to the class. You raise your hand, the teacher calls on you, and you submit the tater tots for her and the class's approval. "Oh my!" the teacher exclaims, "I hope you brought enough tater tots to present to the whole class!" You raise your hand once more to the sky, and in it you submit a whole tray of tater tots! The next time you have to submit work in class just raise your hand and give everyone tater tots. Instant "A" material.

mnemonics.meaning: This net needs to be fixed if you want to put food on the table. You can't put something in your net if it's broken. Fix it!
mnemonics.reading: Once it's fixed, you put a bunch of cheese (ち) in the net. You want to catch something that eats cheese, so that you can then put that animal on your dinner table. Imagine putting a bunch of cheese in your now-fixed net. It kinda stinks!

mnemonics.meaning: Under the dirt in the ground is a drunkard with something in his mouth from a region in North America. He died from whatever it is that’s in his mouth. That’s how this drunkard ended up under the ground in the first place. His whole face region is disfigured from whatever he ate. I wonder what region of North America the strange object came from? Try and imagine yourself unearthing this dead drunkard and trying to figure out what’s in his mouth. Smell the decay of flesh as you poke around in his mouth, trying to figure out what this thing is. Think of an object and what region of North America it comes from.
mnemonics.reading: In an attempt to identify what region of North America the thing in the drunkard’s mouth came from, you touch it and try to remove it with your bare hands. Upon touching whatever it is, you find it to be all icky (いき) and gooey. Like, super icky. So icky that you barf in the region immediately adjacent to you. Imagine touching this super icky substance from the drunkard’s mouth. It’s really icky. Feel yourself throwing up as you feel the icky goo in the region between your fingers.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone gets under the canopy over your heart you should respond to them. You usually ignore everyone, but this one person... they really got under there and touched your heart. You finally feel like they're the right person to respond to.
mnemonics.reading: You respond and it turns out it was to the 王 (おう). The 王 touched your heart, you responded, and now you're together. It's like a fairy tale!

mnemonics.meaning: It may just be a roof over a bathtub, but this here is actually a Shinto shrine. It is indeed just a roof over a bathtub, but I guess spirits inhabit everything according to Shintoism, so there's no reason this bathtub can't be a Shinto shrine too.
mnemonics.reading: What god does this Shinto shrine hold? You see that "It's a-me-ya! (Mario!)" It makes sense, the person who says "It's-a-me! (Mario)" is someone who works on bathtubs (and plumbing).

mnemonics.meaning: A mix of spirit and reason helped you invent the sleeve. Your spirit told you your arms were uncomfortable, stuck to your sides under that shirt. Reason told you that maybe, just maybe, if you made holes for your arms something good would come out of it. And that's how sleeves were born! Your spirit and your arms are free! Imagine how unreasonable no sleeves were. How on earth did you survive without them?!
mnemonics.reading: To make the sleeve holes you took your shoe (しゅう) and kicked a hole through your shirt. Then you did it again on the other side, because you have two of those weird arm things. You also take the extra fabric that helped make your sleeves and turned them into another pair of really light shoes, since they're shoe shaped from the whole process anyway. Waste not!

mnemonics.meaning: Your mouth is like an escalator you use to suck and inhale things into your body. If you're ever having trouble remembering how to suck or inhale, just picture an actual escalator that leads into your mouth. That'll definitely help.
mnemonics.reading: Use this mouth ability to suck cucumbers (きゅう) into your mouth. Cucumbers are shaped like cylinders so you can suck them into your mouth like this. Just as nature intended. You can inhale a cucumber too, I suppose, but don't tell anyone I told you to.

mnemonics.meaning: While riding on your scooter, you grow a mustache on top of the mustache you already have in order to surpass the people around you. You're in a scooter race and your mustache is the only thing keeping you in the lead, but someone else has a mustache too! So you grow another mustache to surpass them once again! Picture yourself running on a scooter with a bunch of other people and closing your eyes tight, willing another mustache to sprout out of your face to surpass them all.
mnemonics.reading: Suddenly, something else manages to surpass you all. It's a car (か)! A car with two mustaches is also riding on a scooter and going way faster than you. Watch helplessly as the car surpasses every single one of your scooters. Both of your mustaches droop in shame.

mnemonics.meaning: Taking orders from a geoduck will place you into enemy territory. Geoducks make terrible commanders, so if you take orders from one, expect to end up in unknown territory, potentially even enemy territory. Be prepared. Imagine this geoduck shouting orders at you to march into enemy territory. See its gross body as a mouth forms and starts shouting out orders.
mnemonics.reading: Not wanting to end up dead in enemy territory, you decide to escape this geoduck leader by getting on a row (りょう) boat and rowing your way outta there. The geoduck commander orders you to halt your escape, but you still get in your row boat and row away. Feel yourself in the row boat as you imagine rowing away to safe territory. Hear the geoduck in the background shouting at you from shore, ordering you to return to land.

mnemonics.meaning: The light of the moon is shining on a guard who's been on duty all night. The moon light makes him so warm and comfortable that he forgets where he is and starts to undress. He thinks he's home! Everyone is going to see him take off his clothes! Picture a sleepy guard, bathed in moonlight, starting to undress. No! Keep your uniform on guard! Don't undress outside in the middle of the night!
mnemonics.reading: You can't seem to get the guard to stop undressing so you throw some darts (だつ) at him. You figure that even if the guard doesn't snap out of this weird sleepy trance, at least you can use the darts to stick his clothes to his body. Then maybe he won't be able to undress anymore.  Imagine throwing darts at a guard who's undressing himself. Imagine trying to aim for his pants so they'll be nailed to his body.

mnemonics.meaning: You take all of your thread and allocate them into one place to unite them. You wrap all the thread together into a giant thread ball. Now it's a big, united mess! Allocate all of your thread like you would your cash: by uniting it! Not at a bank, but in a big, intertwined lump.
mnemonics.reading: You're busy trying to unite all of your thread, twisting and tying and wrapping, and suddenly you look at the ball in your hands and see とうきょう. You've united this thread into the shape of とうきょう. There are even little pins for all the famous neighborhoods and tourist spots. This is strange, because you don't remember putting them there. Try to do this yourself at home. Unite all of your thread and poof! There's とうきょう!

mnemonics.meaning: The helicopter the leader is in has the most value! He would only choose to fly the very best one, after all. That's why it's worth way more than the others. Actually, any helicopter he flies goes up in value. That's the amazing effect of a good leader. Can you understand the value of this helicopter? The leader flew it to war and back! So of course it's worth a lot!
mnemonics.reading: To further increase the helicopter's value, the leader bought himself a car (か) and then tied them together. Now it has the value of a helicopter AND a car! Wow! Imagine driving a valuable car with the leader's helicopter on top. Yeah!

mnemonics.meaning: A leader can fix the value of certain goods and services. Leaders basically get to decide how much everything is worth in value, like rice or lamps or how much you get paid for the work you do. Imagine having a wonderful leader who values your work and time and so the value you get from working is high. Now imagine a terrible leader, who thinks you should be working at all times and doesn't find any value in what you do. Life will be a lot harder...
mnemonics.reading: This leader has fixed the value of cheese (ち), making it ￥1 permanently. One yen! That's, like, less than a penny! Unfortunately, the leader won't fix any of the other really expensive things... so now everyone only eats cheese. Imagine if you could fix the value of cheese to something. How much would you make it cost? If you were a dairy farmer you'd probably be pretty pissed about the leader making it this low.

mnemonics.meaning: That scarecrow with the knife is the vice president. Yeah, I know how he looks, and I'm pretty sure he does some murdering on the side, but you didn't hear that from me. I don't know how we managed to get a knife-wielding scarecrow as a vice president, there's a side of politics I don't get, I guess. I mean, just look at him up there. If something happens to our president we're stuck with that thing.
mnemonics.reading: It's the vice president's turn to speak at the podium and he just clears his throat and yells, "F**k (ふく) you!" to the crowd, holding up his knife. They cheer. What's going on? Normally if a vice president yells f**k you there would be... I dunno... consequences? What's happening?!

mnemonics.meaning: There's an arrow in a turkey that you can see in your view. The turkey seems to be viewing you too, from afar. View the turkey as the turkey views you. View the arrow stuck in it too.
mnemonics.reading: As you view the turkey, Genghis Khan (かん) suddenly comes into your view too. He towers over the injured turkey, leans down, and... pulls the arrow out!? As you view this strange scene, Genghis Khan turns and views you viewing him. He points two fingers to his eyes and then to you, and marches off into the woods. You also view the turkey running off in the other direction.

mnemonics.meaning: The only flowers that the moon gladiators will water are wisteria. The moon gladiators have a thing for wisterias.
mnemonics.reading: Since they're on the moon, where did they get the wisteria from? Actually, from one of the points on earth that is nearest to the moon, Mt. Fuji (ふじ). Imagine them reaching down from the moon and plucking some wisteria up from Mt. Fuji then taking them back up to the moon. Now they water them.

mnemonics.meaning: This is like your side part of speech, as in, you add it to the side of a verb because it's an adverb.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は昨日、日本語の時を表す副詞を学びました。
I learned Japanese adverbs that show time yesterday.

mnemonics.meaning: Penalty gold is the money you pay when you get a penalty. It's for a fine.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ばつ gets changed to ばっ though, so don't get it wrong (or you'll get a 罰金!).

sentences: 罰金については、追ってご連絡を差し上げます。
We’ll contact you shortly about the fine.

mnemonics.meaning: You want a machine to wait so you put it on alert. If the machine is your computer you put it on standby. You just want it to stay there and do nothing until you're ready, that's all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 少子化なのにどうして待機児童が増えるんですか？
If birth rates are declining, why are waitlists for schools increasing?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Lucky for you, even though this word is a single kanji, it uses the same reading you learned, meaning you know how to read it already. Time to plan and scheme for your next vocab/kanji.

sentences: 本日のプレゼンでは、主に3つの策を取り上げます。
In my presentation today, I will cover three main plans.

mnemonics.meaning: Whoops, this one comes out weird. You have anti respond though the meaning of this word is a response. Maybe you're "anti respond" but you have no choice, you have to give a response despite that fact?
mnemonics.reading: The 反 reading is all good and merry, but the 応 reading gets a bit wonky, turning into のう. This is probably because it's just way easier to say than はんおう and sounds basically the same too. So, はんおう goes to はんのう and everyone's happy. Do you have a response?  The reading はんおう is also going to be included since it's technically correct though a less common spelling.

sentences: 反応しないアプリケーションを強制終了する方法を教えてくれませんか？
Could you tell me how to force quit an unresponsive application, please?

mnemonics.meaning: If you aid and help someone you are giving them assistance. How kind!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このオナラ計画が成功するには君の援助がぜひ必要です。
Your assistance is vital to the success of this fart plan.

mnemonics.meaning: Your appearance has many degrees. You turn it up a dial, and you show off one attitude. Then you turn it down a degree and you have another behavior. So many manners to show off.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: すっごく態度の悪いスタッフで、イライラしたよ。
That staff member had a reeeally bad attitude, and it irritated me.
仕事でおそくなるのは仕方の無いことなのに、つい夫にひどい態度を取ってしまいました。
I behaved badly to my husband, though it can't be helped that he comes home late because of work.
あいつ、誰と話をしているかによって、態度を180度変えるからね。信じられないよ。
I can’t trust him because his attitude takes a 180 degree turn depending on who he’s talking to.

mnemonics.meaning: The guests who are viewing are the audience and spectators. That's all that viewers who are guests at a location do, right? Makes total sense.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: サーモンとコンサートに行ったんだけど、なんと他の観客は全員お相撲さんだったんだ。
I went to a concert with Salmon and surprisingly, everyone else in the audience was a Sumo wrestler.

mnemonics.meaning: Here's a weird one for you. You have a red monk. What is this? It's a baby. Think about it. Babies, when they come out, are all red. Also, they have a shaved head, just like a monk would. So, a "red monk" is really just a baby. I wonder who's getting the shorter end of the stick here, the monk or the baby? Probably the monk.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of 赤 (you learned this with the kanji) and the reading you learned for 坊 as well.

sentences: あーどうしたら赤ん坊を泣き止ませることができるんだろう。ミルクもあげてみたし、オムツもかえてみたでしょ。それに、げっぷもさせてみた。あ、これはどうかな？赤ちゃんを体に引き寄せて抱っこして、左右に素早く揺らしてみるって書いてあるわ。

Well, how can we get this baby to stop crying? We already tried feeding him, changing him, and burping him. Oh, here is something! It says to try holding the baby close to your body and then rocking it quickly from side to side.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 機嫌 means mood? Well when you add not it becomes a bad mood. It's so bad it's like you have no mood at all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: コウイチがつまらない冗談を飛ばすと、ビエトは不機嫌になる。
When Koichi cracks a lame joke, Viet gets in a bad mood.
そんな不機嫌そうな顔しないでさ。楽しもうよ！
Hey, don't make such a sullen face. Let's have fun!
昨日遅く寝たのに朝五時に起きなくてはいけなかったので、今日は一日中不機嫌だった。
I went to bed late last night and had to get up at five in the morning, so I was grumpy all day today.

mnemonics.meaning: A penalty game (ゲーム) is a fun kind of game you see on Japanese television a lot. When you mess up, you are punished. Usually it hurts. You can call this a batsu game or a penalty game. Don't call it anything else, though, or you know what happens...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この罰ゲームについて、がっかりもしてるんだけど、ワクワクしてもいるんだよね。
I’m kind of disappointed about this penalty game, but I’m also a little excited.

mnemonics.meaning: Give birth to life! That is a birth.
mnemonics.reading: The 誕 reading is what you'd expect. The 生 reading is an exception though. Just imagine the birth of your friend Joe (じょう). Pick a Joe you know well, or if you don't know a Joe use a famous Joe, like good ol' Joe Biden.

sentences: 私の誕生日は四月八日で、お釈迦様の誕生日と同じ日です。
My birthday is April 8th, which is the same birthday as Buddha’s.

mnemonics.meaning: The appearance of fault is a huge blunder on our family. At least do not have the appearance of fault.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しつ gets shortened to しっ, though, so make that blunder.

sentences: 社長は大失態を犯し、それを隠蔽しようとしたが、さらにその隠蔽工作が裏目に出てしまった。
The president made a huge blunder and he tried to cover it up, but it backfired.

mnemonics.meaning: What shows the district and region and where they exist? That would be the boundary. It is what surrounds every district and region, showing where it exists.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本政府は、その区域の正確な大気中の放射能濃度を公表しているのですか？
Will the Japanese government announce the exact zone in the atmosphere where the radioactivity is concentrated?

mnemonics.meaning: A monk who is at master status is probably a priest by now... though not just any priest, this refers to a Buddhist priest. In modern Japanese this has also come to mean a shaved head or close-cropped hair. You can probably guess why!
mnemonics.reading: The 坊 reads like you'd expect. Unfortunately 主 is an exception and read ず. Just think of a zoo that holds Buddhist priests in captivity. How sad for those Buddhist priests.

sentences: 坊主になる前に頭を坊主にした。
Before becoming a Buddhist priest, I shaved my head.
明日、バリカンで坊主にする。
Tomorrow, I'll shave my head with clippers.
息子よ。現実的になれ。いい加減俺の後を継いで坊主になったらどうなんだ？
Hey, son. You have to be realistic. Isn’t it about time you followed in my footsteps and became a Buddhist priest?

mnemonics.meaning: Managing a business? That's business!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: トーフグの営業チームに配ぞくされました。
I was assigned to Tofugu's sales team.
トーフグオフィスの営業時間は西海岸時間で大体朝九時から夕方六時までです。
The business hours for the Tofugu office are from nine to six PST.

mnemonics.meaning: A company expense is a company expense. These are nice, by the way, if you can get them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は社費で日本語を勉強させてもらっています。
I’m studying Japanese at my company’s expense.

mnemonics.meaning: The condition that something is in and the appearance of it is the condition / state of that object.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 妹は、精神状態が不安定であるということを私に打ち明けた。
My little sister told me about her unstable state of mind.

mnemonics.meaning: You extinguish an item and therefore have to expense it. This is how consumption works. Expense, extinguish, consumption.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 豆乳や納豆の消費が増加しています。
Soymilk and natto consumption have been increasing.

mnemonics.meaning: To prevent crime is a good thing. To do this you use crime prevention techniques.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 本日参りました理由は、当社の最新防犯グッズをご紹介するためです。
The reason I’m here today is to introduce our latest crime prevention products.

mnemonics.meaning: A large force is a group of people. Just think about when this word was probably made up... a long time ago, and the biggest force you could have was a huge group of people. This group of people force is also known as a crowd, or a large number of people.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 大 is the おお reading (like 大きい). Nothing you can do about that but remember it. Then, 勢 is rendaku'd to become ぜい. Also something you'll just have to remember. Say this word a few times in your head, then you'll be able to come up with an idea of what sounds right and what sounds wrong so that you can figure it out next time this word comes up.

sentences: 大勢の人の前で話す事に慣れていないので、今からもう手が震えています。
I’m not used to speaking in front of crowds, so my hands are already shaking.
大勢の生徒の出席を取る時、たまに一人か二人、名前を飛ばしてしまうことがあります。
When I take the attendance of a large number of students, I sometimes skip over one or two names.

mnemonics.meaning: When you undress from the line it's like you're peeling something off the line, going off in another direction, and then causing a digression in whatever the line was about. It's like when you're talking and you digress. Think of your speech as a line. Then, undress a part of it and let it fall away. That is your digression.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 電車が脱線しましたが、怪我人はありませんでした。
The train was derailed, but nobody was injured.

mnemonics.meaning: This is my territory. This is my region. This is my domain!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 誰でも、前進するためには未知の領域に足を踏み入れなくてはいけない。
Everyone has to take a step into unknown territory to progress.

mnemonics.meaning: You have each each which is each (or every, or "respectively"). Kind of goes along the lines of "each and every" in English.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is weird. So sorry. Just imagine you look at each item. Every single one is messed up in some way. Possibly they are robots all accidentally programmed to need to kill humans. You say "oh no oh no" in quick succession because this is a bad situation.

sentences: どうやら各々独自のポテトチップスの食べ方をもっているようだ。
It seems that each person has their own way of eating potato chips.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji, though it's kind of like an add-on for other words in a sense, which makes it behave like jukugo, I think. Don't confuse this with 各々 though. That one does use the kun'yomi reading, which is strange when you consider this one doesn't. Every kanji has its own "perks" I suppose.

sentences: まず始めに、各チームの代表者を決めて下さい。
First, choose a representative for each team.

mnemonics.meaning: Each ground is its own ground. It is each area or various areas.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ワニカニのユーザーは世界各地にいます。
Wanikani users are in various areas of the world.
テレビでを点けると、ちょうど各地の今日の天気が伝えられているところだった。
When I turned on TV, they were just reporting that day's weather in each area.
父の仕事の都合で、私の家族は各地を転々としなくてはいけませんでした。
My family had to move from place to place because of my dad’s job.

mnemonics.meaning: Each self refers to each person or individual.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 遠足には、各自お弁当とお菓子、水筒を持参してください。
You need to bring your own bento box, snacks, and water bottle for the school trip.

mnemonics.meaning: Let's evaluate the value. What is this also known as? An evaluation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私のホームドクターは、いつも急いでいて、自分の症状について調べてきた患者の話を聞かずにけんもほろろに追い出すので、評価が低い。
My family doctor has a low rating because he is always in a rush, is unwilling to listen to patients who have researched a medical problem they have, and often dismisses their worries.

mnemonics.meaning: The expense of use is the expense and cost we have to pay, I'm afraid. If you use something, there'll be expense.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 昼食の費用は各自が負担することを提案します。
We propose that each participant pay for their own lunch.
日本では引っ越し費用の平均って大体どれくらいなの？
Roughly how much is the average cost of moving in Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who has experience (経験) is an experienced person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 経験者から、価値あるアドバイスをいただくことができました。
We were able to get valuable advice from an experienced person.
やっぱり経験者はちがうね。
As you'd expect, the experienced person's exceptional, isn't she?
コウイチはトーフグに犯罪経験者を雇うと思いますか？
Do you think Koichi would hire an experienced criminal at Tofugu?

mnemonics.meaning: The outside view of you is your external appearance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このアパートメントの外観が好きです。
I like the outward appearance of this apartment.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What's that figure / shape in the distance? Is that who I think it is? Is that Sugar Tom (すがた)??? You'll have to make up some lore about this "Sugar Tom" but whatever you do be excited about him. He's a dude who gives you tons of sugar, I'm guessing, and you always see him coming from a long ways away because of his Sugar Tom hat, or something like that.

sentences: 彼が私に微笑みかけている姿が頭に焼きついて離れない。
I can’t get the image of him smiling at me out of my mind.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, which means you think it ought to be an adjective, but it's not, it's a noun :( What's the noun form of force? It's also force.
mnemonics.reading: This is a rough one. There is much force behind you, so when you come at me I scream: "EEK! OI! (いきおい), Get away from me!"

sentences: 私達の犬は、誰と競争している訳でもないのに、いつもすごい勢いでミルクボーンに向かって行きます。
Our dog always bolts towards the milk-bone even though he isn’t racing anyone.

mnemonics.meaning: Managed by the government? Then it is run by government management or it is a  government operation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本郵政をどうして官営から民営に変える必要があったのか、未だに分かりません。
I still don’t understand why Japan Post needed to change from government management to private management.

mnemonics.meaning: The plan inside this piece of paper is the guide you'll be using. It's a plan. It's inside. Use it as your guide! Depending on the context, this can also be information and even invitation. These are all things that guide you in some way, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 友人が、県営プールまで案内してくれました。
My friend guided me to the prefectural pool.
先生の案内で学校を見て回った後、入学案内をわたされました。
After the teacher guided us around the school, we were given an admission guide.
「二人なんですが、席は空いていますか？」「お席にご案内するまで少しお待ちください。」
"Do you have a table for two?" "Please wait just a moment, and I'll guide you to your seats."

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 嫌い is to dislike? When that dislike is big, you really dislike it. That means you hate (or really hate) it. As with 嫌い, a more literal translation is detestable.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading for 大, and the reading for 嫌い is like the one you learned with 嫌い in level 20.

sentences: 大嫌いな食べ物は何ですか。
What food do you really hate?
世の中には、トーフグのことが大嫌いな人もいるらしい。
I heard that there are some people in the world who hate Tofugu.
コウイチはあなたのことが大嫌いなので、彼に代わってビエトがお会いします。
Mr. Viet will meet with you instead of Mr. Koichi because Mr. Koichi really hates you.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember blood pressure (血圧)? Well, now the blood pressure is tall... so you have "tall blood pressure." Well that's dumb. Let's call it high blood pressure instead.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 原因は高血圧です。
The cause is high blood pressure.
コウイチが高血圧だというデマをあちこちで飛ばしているのは一体だれなんだ？
Who the heck is spreading the false rumor that Koichi has high blood pressure?
フグは高血圧で、塩分の少ない食事を取る必要があるとお医者さんから言われた。
Fugu has high blood pressure and was told that he must stick to a low-salt diet by a doctor.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a flavor of dislike. If someone gives you "flavor" and you dislike it, what might that "flavor" be? How about hurtful words.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 味 is the on'yomi you learned with the kanji, but the reading for 嫌 is the kun'yomi, いや. Just imagine someone saying words so hurtful that you have to scream, "Iyaaaaa!" いや.

sentences: 彼はちょっと頭が悪いよね。どうしてあれが嫌味だってことに気づかないのかしら。
He’s kind of an idiot, really. Why didn’t he realize that it was sarcastic?

mnemonics.meaning: You have a thought on a particular view. This is your idea or notion on it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼女は芸術においては素晴らしい美の観念を持っているのに、どうしてあんなに不細工な男性と付き合っているのかが理解できない。
She has a keen sense of beauty for art, so I don’t understand how she’s dating such an ugly guy.

mnemonics.meaning: You already know how 可能 means possible. So when you add not it becomes impossible.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read 可能 first as well.

sentences: あのポーカーのトーナメントで、悪い予感はしてたんだけど、捨てるのは不可能な手札を持っていたんだよ。
In the poker tournament, I had a bad feeling, but it wasn’t possible for me to fold my hand.

mnemonics.meaning: What will give birth to business? Well, some kind of industry, probably. Though heavy industry is pretty good too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本で最も重要な産業は何ですか？
What is the most important industry in Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: Your force and power combine together to create an influence (or a force).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その武装勢力は、急速に勢力を増大している。
The armed insurgents are rapidly increasing their influence.

mnemonics.meaning: Use your finger to indicate some things. These are your instructions. Okay, do this (point), do that (point), and then finally do this (point).
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the on'yomi readings. You've learned them both already, good for you!

sentences: お金を使い切るよう、コウイチに指示されたんだ。
I was directed by Koichi to spend all the money.
医者の指示をあおいだ方がいいんじゃないかな？
Wouldn't it be better to ask a doctor for advice?
指示を無視するのはよくありませんが、指示待ち族にはなってもらいたくはありません。私の言っている意味が分かりますか？
Ignoring orders is not good, but I don’t want you to be someone who can’t work without instructions. Do you know what I mean?

mnemonics.meaning: You respond versus someone else to have an interaction with them. If one of you stops responding, so does the correspondence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの医者の対応は素晴らしかった。
Interacting with that doctor was wonderful.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 不足 is a physical shortage? Well, now you have a physical shortage of sleep. That's a lack of sleep.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. However, the first kanji 寝 actually uses its kun'yomi ね. 不足 is on'yomi as you'd expect, but the ふ in 不 changes to ぶ, so hopefully you've been getting enough sleep.

sentences: 「今日も残業するつもりなの？」「えっと…ですね、今日は寝不足なのでどちらかというと早くあがりたいと思っています。」
"So are you going to work overtime again today?" "Well actually, I was kind of hoping to get off work early today because I’ve been missing out on a lot of sleep."

mnemonics.meaning: The ground's value is the land value.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 地価税と固定資産税は、別にはらわなくてはいけないんですか？
Do we have to pay land value tax and property tax separately?
中国市場の暴落による地価の下落が止まりません。
Land value has not stopped falling due to the crash of the Chinese market.
幸運なことに、私の両親は地価が高騰する前にその土地を買い、最高値で売り抜けました。
Luckily, my parents had bought the land before the price of land went sky-high and sold it at the highest price.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who has territory under their sleeve is the leader. They're the boss of all this territory because they say so, and because they shoved it all into their big sleeves.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: 領袖の言うことは絶対だ。
What a boss says is absolute.
その政治家こそが、党の領袖だ。
That politician is the leader of the party.
「領袖」と言う言葉は、現代では、政治的な使われることが多い。
These days, the word "leader" tends to be used in the political sense.

mnemonics.meaning: さん is what you put on people's names. It's like "Mr." sort of. So a "Mr. monk" is a monk.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. ぼうさん！

sentences: くそ、彼女が付き合ってた坊さんたちには太刀打ちできないよ。あいつら俺とはかなりレベルが違うんだ。
Man, I can’t compete with the monks she goes out with. They’re on a whole other level.

mnemonics.meaning: A noon sleep is sleep you do during the day, also known as a nap.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: コウイチはただ今昼寝中です。おかけになって少々お待ちください。
Koichi is napping at the moment. Please be seated and wait for a moment.

mnemonics.meaning: A year congratulations condition is when you tell the world about your condition for the new year. What's a better way to tell them than by using a New Year's Card?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 年賀状以外の挨拶状は出さない。
I don’t send any greeting cards save for New Year’s cards.

mnemonics.meaning: An undressed letter is one that's missing. It's an omitted character or omitted word.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 誤字脱字を見つけたら、遠慮せずに教えてくださいね。
Don’t be afraid to let me know if you find misspelled or missing words, please.

mnemonics.meaning: So this doesn't quite make sense in terms of the meaning of the kanji... but you'll be okay. This means on purpose. Perhaps when you do something that has the  appearance of doing what you wanted to do you're doing it on purpose.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You did that to me on purpose? Whazapp with that?"

sentences: 彼女は、彼に態と気のないふりをした。
She pretended to be indifferent toward him on purpose.

mnemonics.meaning: When the machines meet, you finally have the opportunity to take them all out at once. DIE MACHINES!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「土曜日に夕食にいらっしゃいませんか？河豚のパイ生地包み焼きを作る予定なんですよ。」「喜んで行きたいのですが、会議がありますので。またの機会にお願いします。」
"Would you like to come to dinner on Saturday? I’m going to make Fugu-wellington." “I’d like to, but I have a meeting. I’ll take a rain check."

mnemonics.meaning: You sleep like a monk, as in you never stop sleeping (because you sleep while you meditate). When you sleep like a monk like this you're constantly oversleeping, probably because you're up late doing sutras or something. You're a late riser.
mnemonics.reading: These are the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あいにくですが、トーフグのオフィスには今、ご対応できる者がおりません。社員がみんな寝坊してしまったのです。
I’m afraid no one in the Tofugu office is available at the moment. Every worker overslept today.

mnemonics.meaning: This shinto shrine you're staying at? Turns out you go inside and it is magically turned into this amazing palace. Wow! I'm totally becoming a Shinto monk.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

sentences: 主人は宮仕えでとても忙しくしており、私は四週間も顔も見ていません。
My husband is so busy with the imperial court service that I haven’t seen him for four weeks.

mnemonics.meaning: If you surpass the past then you're going backwards in time (at least if you're coming from the "present.") If this is the case, then you are definitely in the past.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 玉ねぎが目にしみたことは過去に一度もありません。
My eyes have never watered from onions before.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji... and you thought I was about to punish you because it was a single kanji vocab word. Now get over here. Time for a dirty spanking for thinking such a thing.

sentences: クラスの生徒全員がカンニングで罰を受けたなんて、信じられない。
I can’t believe that all the students in the class received punishment for cheating.

mnemonics.meaning: Your appearance is strange. You're abnormal. Oh, and you're a pervert because you look so abnormal. Though you could just be a caterpillar going through your metamorphosis to become a butterfly. You just look really weird while the changing is going on.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 実は、ちょっと恥ずかしい話なんだけど、俺の親父めちゃくちゃ変態で、児童ポルノの一斉捜査で捕まっちゃったんだよね。
Actually, it’s sort of an embarrassing story, but my father is so perverted that he was caught in a massive child porn ring.

mnemonics.meaning: A plan made by the government is usually known as a policy. "The government passed a policy prohibiting the use of guns on zombies, dooming us all."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: お集まりの皆さん、本日は我々の諸政策についてのプレゼンテーションの機会をいただき、有難うございます。
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the opportunity to make this presentation about our policies today.

mnemonics.meaning: Go ahead and put a rank on something. This one is rank #1, so its position is up higher. Then you put a rank #67 on something. That one's position is lower.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 位置について、用意、ドン！
On your mark, get set, go!

mnemonics.meaning: Put a force on your figure to make it into a certain shape. This is your posture.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 恐らく姿勢が悪いことが首の痛みの原因でしょう。
Your poor posture is probably causing your neck pain.

mnemonics.meaning: Go ahead and present then exit. This will be your presentation of the materials. Perhaps it's the submission of your resignation, or the filing of a complaint, which explains why you exit so quickly afterwards. You could also just be handing in your homework, though.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 答えが合っているのか判断がつかなかったが、とりあえず時間が来たので提出した。
I couldn't decide if the answers were correct, but the time was up, so I handed them in anyway.
トフグライターへの応募者の提出物について教えて頂けますか？また、必要なスキルは何ですか？
Could you tell me what a Tofugu writer applicant needs to submit and what skills are required?

mnemonics.meaning: When you big unite in a territory you need a great leader. Someone like a president, perhaps?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well

sentences: ほら、彼はここの大統領としての仕事がとても好きだったんです。 それに、現実を見つめてください。彼がしてた仕事と同じくらい良い仕事をする人を見つけられないでしょう。 そうじゃないですか？
Look, he loved his job as president here. And let’s face it, you’re not gonna find anyone who did it as well as he did it. Isn’t that true?

mnemonics.meaning: When you value status you really care about how much the price of things are. The more things cost, the more you value them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この価格はちょっと高すぎやしないかい。
The cost is a little too high.

mnemonics.meaning: Things with value have prices. This is just the general prices of things. In other words, the prices of commodities or cost of living.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ぶつ changes to ぶっ, though, so hopefully that doesn't change the price you're willing to pay for this vocab? Right? Please give me your money.

sentences: 日本では、物価が上がり始めたようだ。
In Japan, it seems that prices have begun to go up.

mnemonics.meaning: Anything that's privately managed is private and privately run.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の両親は、私営の葱園を所有しています。
My parents own a private green onion garden.

mnemonics.meaning: Please present your plan in the form of a proposition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「提案はどうだった？」「うーん。まあまあって感じかな。」
"So what did you think of the proposal?" "Well, I think it was just okay."

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is publicly managed is something that is public aka government run. Compare this to 私営 which is private / privately run.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: もし収入がものすごく低いのであれば、安い公営のアパートに住めるかもしれませんよ。
If your income is really low, you may be able to live in a cheap public apartment.
日本では、競馬は公営ギャンブルです。
In Japan, horse racing is government run gambling.
日本政府は、トーフグを公営にさせてもらえないかとコウイチにお願いしたそうです。
I heard that the Japanese government asked Koichi to place Tofugu under public management.

mnemonics.meaning: Please indicate this in a public way. How about a public announcement?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 毎年いつ頃日本の地価公示価格が公表されるのか教えて頂けませんか？
Could you tell me when Japanese land prices are announced each year?

mnemonics.meaning: Please accept this territory. Oh, you want some writing to make the deal official? Okay, here's a receipt.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 先週購入したトーフグ製品の受領書を送って頂けませんか？
Could you send me the receipt for the Tofugu products I bought from you last week?

mnemonics.meaning: The region that is this ground is the region / area. Just think of each area of ground. Each area is each region.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: スーパーマンはその地域へ食料と新鮮な水を急送した。
Superman rushed food and fresh water to that region.

mnemonics.meaning: When you give up and just try to enjoy the view, that's resignation. You know things aren't going well, and you know you can't do anything about it now, so you resign yourself to what's to come.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 父は、様々な経験の後に諦観に至った。
My father's various experiences led to his resignation.
やる気はやがて、諦観となった。
Motivation became resignation before long.
君は諦観するにはまだ若い。
You are too young to be resigned.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is managed by the city is run by the city, or city-run.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 大阪市は、舞洲にすごくユニークな市営のゴミ焼却炉を建設しました。
Osaka City built a very unique, city-run incineration plant in Maishima.

mnemonics.meaning: Prefecture managed things are run by the prefecture.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日曜日に、県営球場で野球の試合があります。
On Sunday, there's a baseball game at a stadium run by the prefecture.
フグは県営図書館でサーモンといちゃついていて、図書館司書さんに怒られた。
Fugu was scolded for making out with Salmon in the prefectural library by a librarian.

mnemonics.meaning: A side business is a side business.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 副業で、私の彼氏はネットワークビジネスをしている。
As a side business, my boyfriend works for a company using multi-level marketing techniques.

mnemonics.meaning: Let's go view some sunlight! Oh wait, we can't do that here. We will have to go sightseeing to go see this amazing sunlight thing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 観光案内のパンフレットありますか？
Can I have a sightseeing brochure?
観光シーズンに京都のホテルを取るのは難しい。
It is difficult to get a hotel in Kyoto during the tourist season.
歩いて観光する方が好きなんですが、今年は小さい子供がいるので、レンタカーを借りて観光しました。
I prefer to go sightseeing on foot, but we rented a car this year because we have a small child.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You only wear sleeves because your soap is dead (そで). If it wasn't, you would go sleeveless forever! But, your soap is dead, so you have stinky armpits, which you hide in these sleeves.

sentences: ねえ、袖が汚れているよ。
Hey, your sleeve seems dirty.
このポロシャツ、袖が短すぎてノースリーブに間違われたんだよね。
This polo shirt's sleeves are so short that people mistakenly thought it had none.
先輩の袖から見えた腕の血管に見とれて車にひかれそうになったなんて誰にも言えない。
I can't tell anyone that I almost got hit by a car because I couldn't stop staring at the blood vessels that were showing on my senpai's arms from under his sleeves.

mnemonics.meaning: Are you visiting a neat place? Grab some dirt and bring it back with you. Then pretend to give birth to it in front of your friends. That dirt is now a special souvenir! It's the best present you could ever give someone!
mnemonics.reading: These readings are exceptions, sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you: When someone asks you who gave you a souvenir, just say "Miya gave (みやげ) it to me." Who's Miya? No idea. But neither do they. You never have to remember who gave you anything ever again! Miya gave you everything you own. She's probably a great person.

sentences: まだお土産を選んでいません。
I haven’t picked out a souvenir yet.

mnemonics.meaning: People mainly view things through a lens of subjectivity. People mainly look at things from their own point of view and biases. It's hard to take a step back from yourself and lose that subjectivity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼女の文章はとても主観的だが、だからこそとてもユニークでもある。
Her writing is very subjective but that’s what makes it so very unique.

mnemonics.meaning: The side topic is the subtitle or subheading.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 昨晩、私の本にぴったりのすごくいい副題を思いついたの。
I came up with a killer subheading for my book last night.

mnemonics.meaning: To support and aid is to support.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 心あるオナラ臭い支援を有難うございます。
Thank you for your hearty and farty support.

mnemonics.meaning: You must respond with aid in order to show your support for someone who needs it. You can usually show your support if you root for them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あの熱心に声を出す応援者はいったい誰なんだ？
Who the heck is that enthusiastic and vocal supporter?

mnemonics.meaning: Your butt tail is just your tail, though I wonder why they had to specify that it was your butt tail. Where else do you have a tail, I wonder?
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is a bit of an exception. You kind of already know the reading for 尻 from the kun'yomi しり you learned already. Here it gets shortened to しっ. The reading for 尾 is totally different from what you learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The animal with the best tail in the world is the polar (ぽ) bear. They're stubby and white and cute. Only polar bears have tails like that!

sentences: あの可愛い柴犬が、尻尾を振りながらコウイチに近づき、飛びついた。
That cute Shiba came towards Koichi wagging its tail and jumped on him.

mnemonics.meaning: To undress your taxes is to throw them away. Just throw it out, who needs 'em? I'm not going to pay these taxes, therefore I am committing tax evasion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は小さい頃、両親から親切な人になるよう教わりましたが、二人は脱税容疑で逮捕されました。
My parents taught me how to be a kind person when I was little, but they were arrested on charges of tax evasion.

mnemonics.meaning: Okay, only one response for that, and that is that tentatively we have an agreement... for now. Just think of the one response you have, and that one response is to just get everyone off your back, so you agree with them... for now.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 一応念のため、全データのバックアップをこのハードディスクに取っておきました。
For now I made a backup of all the data on this hard drive, just in case.

mnemonics.meaning: The soil that makes up your territory is your territory. Ain't nobody goin' set foot on my soil nuh'uh.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「ここからはオレの領土だから、入ってくるんじゃない」と言って、コウイチはビエトと自分のデスクの間に線を引いた。
"It's my territory from this line, so don't enter," said Koichi as drawing a line between his and Viet's desks.
ブログでは、国家間の領土問題にはあまり触れたくありません。
We don’t want to touch on the territorial disputes between nations on our blog.

mnemonics.meaning: Some people have a difficult time saying thank you. But not you now that you know how! This is often written in kana, so you don't need to use the kanji when writing. But you'll sometimes see the kanji used so it's important to be able to recognize them! Did you know this is an abbreviation of 有難うございます? You can also spell it like this: 有難う.
mnemonics.reading: You've heard people say ありがとう before right?!

sentences: どうして素直に有り難うと言うことができないんだろうね。
Why won’t you just obediently say thank you?

mnemonics.meaning: This one is a little strange. You have 混じる (to get mixed up in), 混ぜる (to mix), 混ざる (to get mixed), and now this: 混む, to be crowded. It makes sense that when everyone's all mixed up it's going to be crowded, but how to differentiate between this and the other 混 words? Just think of how cows muuuuu (む) get all bunched up and crowded, which is why this word is to be crowded.
mnemonics.reading: Hey, come (こむ) out of that crowd of cows. It's going to be crowded in there.

sentences: 電車は毎日混みますが、あなたのせいではありません。自分を責める必要はありませんよ。
The train is crowded every morning, but it’s not your fault. There’s no need to blame yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: Know how 非難 is a criticism? Make it a verb and you have the word to criticize.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, it will be really helpful to know the word 非難 to start.

sentences: 子どもたちは両親が不祥事を隠したことを非難した。
The kids criticized their parents for hiding the scandal.

mnemonics.meaning: You undress and run out of that room. You had to take off your clothes in order to escape, but now you can run and start to flee. Just imagine some sort of contraption that holds you in place via your clothes, and you need to escape from it by taking said clothes off. Now imagine running away from that place naked. Escape!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The だつ changes to だっ, though, so be careful of that.

sentences: 重い刑罰を言い渡された犯罪者が、刑務所から脱走した。
The criminal, who had received a heavy sentence, broke out of prison.

mnemonics.meaning: Know how 存在 is existence? Well, make it a verb and then you have to exist.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は死後の世界は存在すると思います。
I think that life after death exists.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen how 倒す is "to knock over." But this is when something gets knocked over by itself. You know that you're not doing anything here, because when you're not touching all these fine glass items, it's very rare (れる) that anything gets knocked over (because you're not touching anything, you clumsy dumsy). It's also when you or someone else collapses. You didn't push yourself over, you just kind of fell by yourself.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same like 倒す. If you knew 倒す you will know the reading of this one too.

sentences: そのマラソン選手は、ゴールの直前で疲れきって倒れてしまいました。
The marathon runner collapsed from exhaustion right before the finish line.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give up or abandon so the verb version is to give up or to abandon.
mnemonics.reading: Just before you're ready to give up on something, you yell, "AKIRA (あきら)!" You don't know anyone named Akira, you just saw it in a movie once and it made sense, you know? So now when you've tried really hard on something, but you have to abandon it anyway, you shout AKIRA into the sky. I just did it while trying to write this mnemonic!

sentences: 死んでも漢字の勉強を諦めないで！
Even if you die, don't give up on learning kanji!
コウイチはついにポケモンマスターになる夢を諦めた。
Koichi finally abandoned his dream of becoming a Pokemon master.
山のようなレビューを諦めずにやるかリセットするかは、とても難しい選択です。
Doing a mountain of reviews without giving up or resetting—it's a difficult choice.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 手洗い is "handwashing" (and also a not as polite way to mention a bathroom). When you add お you're suddenly making it polite. Why? Because you're talking about something a little more crass than handwashing. You're talking about the toilet or restroom or bathroom. Ewww. Poop goes there.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 手洗い, so if you know that you'll know this too!

sentences: お手洗いは、真っすぐ行って左です。
The restroom is straight and to the left.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means indicate so the verb vocab version is to indicate or to show. This isn't used for "showing" a physical thing, this is more like when "a study shows that ...."
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Studies seem to indicate or to show that She-men (しめ) are way more powerful than He-men. Just look at how much bigger their swords and biceps are.

sentences: 約束なんてしないで。言葉ではなく行いで示してよ。
Don’t promise me anything. Actions speak louder than words.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 飛ぶ is to fly? Well this word is for when you make some thing fly. So, this word is to let something fly or to send something flying. It also means to skip over something, such as someone's turn or a question on a test.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just like 飛ぶ, so if you know that reading you're close. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember the second part: You can use your strength to let something fly, and that something is a bus (ばす). You're that buff!

sentences: フグは、センターオーバーの三塁打をかっ飛ばした。
Fugu sent a triple flying over center field.
僕の順を飛ばさないでよ！
Don't skip over my turn!

mnemonics.meaning: Like with 確か, which means certain, this is the verb version of that. So when you "do certain" you are going to make sure of something or you're going to verify something.
mnemonics.reading: This one is kun'yomi followed by okurigana. If you remember the reading you learned with 確かに, you should know this one!

sentences: ちゃんとドアに鍵をかけたかどうか確かめた方がいいですよ。
You should make sure the door is properly locked.
アルコール分がちゃんと飛んだかどうか、確かめてくださいね。
Verify that the alcohol content has been completely removed.
いつも、カナエさんが単語の使い方に間違いが無いか、辞書で確かめてくれています。
Kanae always checks the dictionary to make sure there are no mistakes in word use.

mnemonics.meaning: The pressure used easily collapses whatever it's pushing against. That's why this verb means to overwhelm.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the あつ goes to あっ, as you'd probably expect.

sentences: ダリンは自然の美しさに圧倒された。
Darin was overwhelmed by the beauty of the nature.
この新しいサイトは他社の日本語学習サイトを圧倒するだろう。
This new site will overwhelm other Japanese language sites.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surpass, but this verb is intransitive, meaning we’re not focussing on who did the action, but on the action itself. So this means to pass, as in “the storm passed”, to be over as in “winter’s over”, or to be too much.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In order for the storm to pass you’re going to have to sue (す) it. Sadly storms won’t pass unless you take legal action these days.

sentences: 夏が過ぎ、木の葉が色づき初めていた。
Summer was over and the leaves on the trees were beginning to change color.
トーフグの社員達はみんな、台風が過ぎるのをオフィスで待った。
All the Tofugu employees waited at the office for the typhoon to pass.
昨晩は、晩ご飯を食べ過ぎて、どうしても寝られませんでした。
I couldn't get to sleep last night because I ate too much supper.

mnemonics.meaning: When you do a  penalty to someone you are trying to punish or to penalize them.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Just remember that the つ becomes a small っ so I don't have to punish you.

sentences: コウイチはトーフグの秘密を漏らした従業員を罰した。
Koichi punished the employees who leaked Tofugu’s secrets.

mnemonics.meaning: When you put something you don't just put it, you have to put down this item or even (to) set down the item. Basically, you have to put something down with this verb. It's a little different from the kanji meaning you learned but not that different.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just imagine you're putting down Oreos (お). One after another. Each oreo that you try to put down say in your head "Hello Mr. Oreo, I'm going to put you down.. ooh yes, you like that don't you?" REPEAT.

sentences: フグと私は今距離を置いてるの。
Fugu and I are putting some distance between us right now.

mnemonics.meaning: If 在留 is residence, then the verb version of that would be to reside.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 在留 so you should be able to read this one already!

sentences: 外国人が日本に在留する時に必要になるものは何ですか？
What do foreigners need when they stay in Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means respond so the verb vocab version is to respond.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji! Not too shabby.

sentences: 先方は、我々の二割りの値下げ要求に応じるでしょうか？
Do you think they will respond to our request for a 20 percent discount?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means manage, but when you manage something, what are you usually managing? How about a business? So this word means to run a business even though the kanji is manage.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.
