mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to provide your friends with their own sauna (そな) because they don't want to use your shower. This requires you to go out and buy a sauna for your house (very expensive) just so you can provide your needy friends with what they want (a sauna). Feel angry you have to provide this.

sentences: トーフグのオフィスに電話が備え付けられましたが、ほとんどだれも使っていません。
Tofugu's office has been equipped with a telephone, but almost no one uses it.
老後に備えて、家をバリアフリーにしました。
To prepare for our old age, we had our house renovated to be wheelchair-accessible.
気持ちを引き締めて敵の攻撃に備えろ！
Brace yourself and prepare for your opponent’s attack!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means raise, and this verb is when you do that to something. It's transitive. So this means to raise something. It actually has a pretty wide meaning, and can also mean "raise" in the sense of to cite something, like an example. It can even mean to hold something, like an event.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 挙がる, so if you know that reading you should know this one as well.

sentences: 名前を呼んだら、手を挙げてください。
When I call your name, please raise your hand.
例を挙げたらキリがないですよ。
If I cite examples, it will be endless.
私は結婚式を市役所で挙げましたが、そのことを恥ずかしいとは思っていません。
I held my wedding ceremony in city hall, and I’m not ashamed of that.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means solve so the verb vocab version is to solve. It also means to untie and you know this verb is when you are doing the actual untying because you think it's super coo' (く) to untie things, which is why you do it nonstop.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 解ける, so if you know that you can read this one too.

sentences: プレゼントのリボンを解くのが好きなんです。
I like untying the bows on presents.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stretch so the verb version is to stretch.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine yourself trying to stretch (or better yet stand up and do it). Every time you stretch you start to laugh uncontrollably. HA (は) HA HA HA HA HA. Go ahead and laugh like that out loud while you stretch, it will help you to remember this reading.

sentences: バレーボールのネットを張ったのは誰ですか？
Who put up the volleyball net?

mnemonics.meaning: 理解 is understanding, so the verb version would be...? How about to understand or to comprehend? Well, do you?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, if you know 理解 already this one is easy to comprehend.

sentences: お前が彼のことを愛しているのは理解するけど、あいつがお前にキスをするのは許せないよ。
I understand you love him, but I can’t forgive him for kissing you.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:  When you cut the tree down to produce a tree trunk, out jumps Mickey Mouse. "WHY YOU CUT DOWN MY TREE BRO?" he yells. I'm Mickey Mouse and I don't stand for this.

sentences: 木の幹に絡まっているツタを取り除いた方がいいよ。
You should remove the ivy winding around the tree trunk.

mnemonics.meaning: You're going to get judged times two. Judge and judge again. Once by the judge and another time by the jury. This is a whole trial here.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You hopefully learned this on'yomi for 判 with the word 評判, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: At your trial, you wear a pair of Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses in the hope you look cool, and that'll convince the judge and jury not to convict you.

sentences: できるだけ、裁判するのはさけたいんですよ。
I'd like to avoid a trial, if possible.
裁判の費用がいくらぐらいかかるか知っていますか？
Do you know how much the cost of a trial would be?
この貯金箱には小遣いからためた80ドルが入っているんだけど、裁判を起こすには到底足りないと思うんだよね。
This piggy bank contains the eighty dollars I’ve saved from my allowance, but I guess it is not close to enough to file a lawsuit.

mnemonics.meaning: When the status of your employment is "nothing" then you're probably unemployed. You're experiencing unemployment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 無職でお金がはらえずにいたら、ガスと電気を停止された。
When my unemployment meant I was unable to get money, my gas and electricity was shut off.
無職のホームレスの男性と友達になりました。
I became friends with an unemployed homeless man.
彼は完璧な夫ですが、一つだけ問題があるんです。十年間ずっと無職なんです。
He would be the perfect husband, save for one thing - he has been unemployed for ten years.

mnemonics.meaning: This not writing law is a law that hasn't been written down. It's an unwritten law, like taking your shoes off and showering every day.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 学校では日本語でしか話してはいけないという不文律のようなものがあります。
There is some sort of unwritten rule that says people are only allowed to speak Japanese in this school.

mnemonics.meaning: A demon that sucks blood? What mythological creature can you think of that sucks blood? How about a vampire? Them Sparklzzzz!
mnemonics.reading: 吸血 should be easy for you to read. The 鬼 part uses the reading you already learned with the kanji, き. Easy, no?

sentences: あの吸血鬼の野郎、俺の事、血を吸いたくない程インチキ臭すぎるって言うんだ。
That vampire told me that he wouldn’t even suck my blood because I am too much of a phony.

mnemonics.meaning: The superior person wins. They will win the championship and be able to claim victory over all others.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ジャイアンツは去年はボロ負けだったが、今年はリーグ優勝を果たした。
Although the Giants got their butts kicked big time last year, they won the championship this year.

mnemonics.meaning: An element of clear up (like the sky clearing up!) is so wonderful and splendid. Sort of a weird word, but very useful. Just think of that wonderful feeling you get when the sun breaks and things clear up and it's awesome.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a bit weird, too. Luckily, you've learned both of them already. 晴れる is はれる. That's the reading you use here, though は goes to ば.

sentences: 「そんな風に自分を安売りしないで。君は素晴らしい女性だよ。」
"Don’t sell yourself short like that. You’re a magnificent woman."

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means accept.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means control.

The sun is coming up out of the ground, making this radical dawn. Of course, don't confuse this with dusk! You can do that by thinking that the sun is an optimistic and bright thing, so it tends to come up, not go down. (Also, Japan is the Land of the Rising Sun. I mean come on!)

There is a hat covering the moon and it's holding a knife. Wait, that's no moon. It's a space station! It's the Death Star! It's pretending to be a moon under that hat. And it's armed! Don't let the Death Star stab your planet to death.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means guest.

There are five mouths eating cow at Korean BBQ. Korea is famous for their delicious BBQ, and you need a lot of people to eat all that beef. At least five people. (Get it? Five people!) That's why this radical is Korea.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means nature.

There are people under a canopy on the street forming their own agency. They're banding together right here in the street, making a new government office! Imagine them putting together papers, talking to politicians, and standing in the street outside the capitol. They demand for this agency to be formed. They are doing all the correct, legal things to do it too.
mnemonics.reading: This new agency is just starting to make progress when you hear a low rumble... then a screech. "THIS IS MY STREET. NO NEW AGENCIES ON MY STREET!" Mrs. Chou (ちょう) cries as she barrels into everyone. "Whenever you're in a 丁, you're in my territory," she yells, taking out a few agency members with her fists. "You won't be starting any kind of agency here, not on my watch." And she lights it all on fire.

mnemonics.meaning: This word has three really important meanings. It's probably best if you remember them all. Let's do this! When you're a guest somewhere it's important to bring geoducks. But more than that, the amount of geoducks you bring is really what matters. If you don't have any live geoducks go ahead and bring any amount of framed pictures of geoducks instead. If you can't even do that, well, then you're going to have to tattoo geoducks on your forehead. If you're a guest you either have to have the right amount of geoducks, geoducks in framed pictures, or geoducks on your forehead. Otherwise you're a jerk.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, if you mess up any of these things, (the amount, the framed pictures, or the forehead tattoo) every other guest will gawk (がく) at you. Feel the feel of hundreds of gawks. Feel ashamed as they gawk at you. How could you!?

mnemonics.meaning: The moon shines on your roof in the evening and a snake suddenly appears! Wait, that's not a snake, it's your arm, sticking out from under the roof. Arms really look like snakes in the moonlight. Picture it. Your arm is long and shiny, just like a snake.
mnemonics.reading: Your arm is exposed to the moon and the outside and you feel a chill. Where are your clothes? Ah, you're nude, eh (うで)?! I guess it is pretty common to sleep in the nude, eh? Your arms are nude, eh? That's why they look like snakes, you know. You should be more careful.

mnemonics.meaning: You stand in the dirt and see the boundary. The boundary between your home and your neighbors. The boundary between your town and the next. All you have to do to see it is stand in the dirt. It also helps that there is a boundary sign standing in the dirt that you can also see. Get off your computer and go stand outside in the dirt and see what boundaries you can see.
mnemonics.reading: The boundary you're looking at is the Kyoto (きょう) boundary. Kyoto is a really famous, important place, so if you think about it, everything could be the boundary between where you are and Kyoto if you just make them really big. Picture yourself outside of Kyoto. Picture the boundary between you and Kyoto. Now hop over it!

mnemonics.meaning: Fire in nature will burn down everything in its path. In nature, there are no firefighters or anyone to contain the fire, so the fire will burn and burn until it has no fuel left to consume. Feel the fire all around you as it burns. You’re out in nature – the middle of a forest fire. Hear the woods burn and crackle as you feel the heat around you.
mnemonics.reading: What is the worst thing that could burn in this fire? Your nendoroid (ねん) collection. You've spent a lot of time and money collecting all these cool and rare and unique nendoroids and now they've all burned in the fire. Cry your eyes out as you smell the smell of burning plastic from the nendoroids. Worst. Day. Ever.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your fingers at dawn to carry many things. You have to carry yourself out of bed. You have to carry your backpack or purse or laptop bag to school or work. Your fingers have to carry a lot of weight around at dawn. Think about your morning routine. You carry yourself into the bathroom and carry a toothbrush into your mouth. You carry your coat and bag out the door.
mnemonics.reading: Once you're carrying everything, and the dawn sun is shining bright, you start getting tan (たん). Especially those fingers you're using to carry things. Picture yourself carrying a coat and a bag, walking through the rice fields to work, with the hot, dawn sun shining down, making your fingers get tanner and tanner.

mnemonics.meaning: If a spirit blesses your older brother it's time to celebrate! This isn't something that happens every day to everyone's older brother. Yours is very good and very lucky. So celebrate with him! Imagine what celebrating would be like. Imagine an older brother too, if you don't actually have one.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, the two of you celebrated too much, and you went a little crazy. The spirit grabbed your brother and shook (しゅく) him. Shook him so hard his head popped off. Never celebrate too hard. Otherwise you'll always have to think about the time a celebration spirit shook your brother till his head fell off.

mnemonics.meaning: The American flag is the reason you need to deliver this package. The flag is inside the package, and you need to deliver it to the president. He lost his old flag, so now it’s up to you to deliver this new one to him. What more of a reason do you need? You need to deliver this flag to the president. Imagine yourself running as fast as you can while carrying the parcel in order to get it to him. Your lungs are tired and your legs burn, but you must deliver the flag as soon as possible!
mnemonics.reading: To deliver this flag is something you just have to do (とど). Need to do. Want to do. There is no one else to do it. This is something only you are equipped to do. The world depends on you to do this delivery. If you fail, the United States will be ruined. You have to do it! Deliver that flag now! Run! Run!

mnemonics.meaning: You take your scooter to Korea and everything is different! Imagine scooting down a street in Korea and seeing how different literally every single thing is compared to what you're used to in Japan.
mnemonics.reading: What's also different is that there's a weird tiger bouncing on its tail alongside you yelling that its name is Tigger (ちが). You didn't know Tigger was living in Korea these days. That's definitely different. Tigger is different in Korea too. For one, he's a white tiger now, and he's, like, really aggressive. Wait, was he always like that?

mnemonics.meaning: When a sheep tries its hoof at construction, it gains distinction. Now that is something that really sets a sheep apart! After all, have you ever seen a sheep working in construction? Note that the sheep has to sweep its tail to one side so that it doesn't get in the way of all the construction tools. That's why it looks a little different here. Imagine a sheep in a hard hat, with its tail on one side, getting down to some construction. How very distinctive.
mnemonics.reading: The extra distinction of this sheep is that its really skilled with a saw (さ). That's why it's so good at construction. Imagine the sheep holding the saw in its hooves. It isn't easy to grip a saw with hooves, but this is no ordinary sheep.

mnemonics.meaning: The elephant radical and the elephant kanji are the same. But! This kanji has another meaning: phenomenon. If you were the first person to see an elephant, you'd call it that too. Picture the first Japanese person to see an elephant. He stops dead in his tracks, points and screams out, "What a phenomenon!"
mnemonics.reading: Elephants are great and all, except that when they die they turn into elephant zombies (ぞう). But you never see these zombies because the shougun (しょう) has a special project in place that destroys all elephant bodies when they die. Hint: The readings and meanings for this kanji match up really nicely. ぞう is always for elephant and しょう is always for phenomenon. Remember it like this, the elephant is the zombie and the shougun keeps everyone from finding out about this phenomenon. Picture the shougun standing over a pit of zombie elephants. None of these are getting out on his watch, letting people believe in such crazy phenomenons.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a flag under the blackjack table that you can kick in order to expand the table. Sometimes you only have a few people playing blackjack so you don’t need to kick the flag at all, and sometimes  there are many people playing blackjack so you need to kick the flag many times in order to expand it to a proper size. Imagine yourself kicking this flag to see the blackjack table expand. Feel your foot kicking the flag. You’ve kicked it so many times that your leg is sore, but you need to expand the table some more so you keep kicking it. Imagine the blackjack table making that sound Mario makes whenever he gets a mushroom and expands in size.
mnemonics.reading: The blackjack table does have a limit though of how many times it will expand, and that limit is ten (てん). You can only kick the flag to get the table to expand ten times. Imagine yourself kicking the flag ten times. Count it off in your head and imagine each instance up to ten. Any more kicks after ten don’t cause the table to do anything, but it does cause your leg to get sore.

mnemonics.meaning: Behind the flag lies a mask—yet another layer of secrecy. You’re standing in front of a crowd, giving a rousing speech. Hiding your face is the flag of your country, and behind that flag you’re also wearing a mask, just in case the flag falls down. The extra layer of secrecy is just to be safe. These layers are meant to protect you. We all have layers we hide behind sometimes, you know? You can't be totally transparent with everyone.
mnemonics.reading: Someone jumps up on stage and starts peeling off your layers! You stand there, first goes the flag, then the mask, then ... your soul (そう) is laid bare. No, literally. You don't have a body, your soul was under that mask. And now it's floating there for all to see. Everyone in the crowd is completely silent, staring at your soul, with all of its layers peeled off.

mnemonics.meaning: When you see a spirit you have to look at it. Look at it directly, because if you look away then it could disappear. Look at the spirit. Look at its shape and into its eyes. Just don't look away.
mnemonics.reading: You look at the spirit for as long as you can, until you hear a sheep (し) sound. You look away for a second, see the sheep look at you, and when you look back the spirit is gone. Damn! Now you have to look at this sheep. Maybe the sheep was projecting the spirit... or maybe it's just a sheep. You'll have to look at it a bit longer to know for sure.

mnemonics.meaning: The king is showing his people how to put a net around a weird zombie by walking around it in a loop. Watch as the king loops the net around and around and around the zombie, keeping it completely pinned down.
mnemonics.reading: The king also explains that this loop technique was used by Genghis Khan (かん) when he was conquering cities. He'd loop around the entire place with a net and trap them. Picture Genghis Khan looping around and around just like the king is looping around and around this zombie.

mnemonics.meaning: In an attempt to control your clothes, you manufacture a mind control device. This mind control device will allow you to control the mind of your clothes and all that they do. You just need to manufacture it. Imagine being able to control your clothes with your mind. What would you have them do? Imagine what you would do with your clothes if you could manufacture something to control them and move them around at will with your mind.
mnemonics.reading: You manufacture these clothes to control your saber (せい). It's hard to manufacture, you have to do a lot of work, but you manage to make your clothes control your saber. Now you don't need to rely on your hands! Now you're trying to manufacture a machine that will make sabers and clothes you can use to control them. Soon you'll have a manufactured army of saber-controlling clothes!

mnemonics.meaning: On this scooter, there's an angel with a drop of sweat coming off of it, because it forgot to mention something to you! It seems like it's something important too, since they're sweating so much. The angel just visited you, but it forgot to mention something important (probably life-threatening, it's an angel after all), and now you see it scooting at top speeds toward you.
mnemonics.reading: "I forgot to mention, you have to study ninjutsu (じゅつ)!" the angel yells. But it's too late, there are ninjas jumping out of the bushes around you and taking you hostage. The angel really should have mentioned ninjutsu earlier. Then maybe you would have gone straight to a dojo to learn instead of falling into a ninjutsu trap yourself. The angel definitely failed its mission.

mnemonics.meaning: On the ground there's a ceremony where everyone keeps stopping. This stopping ceremony is being performed by the military. They'll march one direction, then stop and turn, then march another direction, then stop again. The military really seems to have a thing for stopping a lot during their ceremonies.
mnemonics.reading: You look closer at the people in the military and realize that every time they stop they take a drink of booze (ぶ)! This is a ceremony for celebrating the military so I guess they can drink as much booze as they want, but this seems very strange to you.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a lantern on top of a knife in the dirt. You walk up to take the knife and lantern when you realize it's just a model. It all looked real from far away, but now that you're up close you can see none of it is real. Why would anyone make a model that looks like a lantern and a knife sticking into the ground?
mnemonics.reading: You touch the model and see that it's made of cake (けい)! Someone really into lanterns and knives must have been given this model cake as a birthday present! Though they left it out here so they probably didn't like it. Haven't you seen any of those crazy cakes modeled after things like movies, towns, giants hams, and purses? They're all the rage. Next time you make a cake try to make it look like a model lantern and knife with fake cake dirt and everything.

mnemonics.meaning: You have an animal for a husband with horns that are narrow. This animal husband of yours is a goat. A goat with narrow horns. Why is this animal your husband? You’re weird, that’s why. Imagine yourself married to this animal husband with horns that are narrow. It’s a strange marriage. Listen to the goat making its goat noises as it clomps around your home. Now hug your goat husband and feel its soft fluffy coat against your skin.
mnemonics.reading: I’m not even going to get into the semantics (せま) of how this weird relationship of yours works. Nope, this reading explanation is on the straight and narrow. Need to know basis. Classified. All that junk. There will be no discussion of the semantics between you and your goat lover. But that doesn’t mean you can’t imagine the semantics. The finer points of the relationship. Go ahead, imagine all the weird stuff that comes with the territory for having a goat as a husband. Use all that weird stuff to remember this kanji and its reading. Want an example? Just imagine the goat doing dishes! Goats don’t have hands! Hahahahaha!!

mnemonics.meaning: On your bamboo roof is a bear. It is pulling the bamboo off, because it wants to use it to make a long pipe. Bamboo is great for pipes, and the only place for the bear to get it is your roof. So, that's why it's there.
mnemonics.reading: The pipe will be for Genghis Khan (かん), who would like some pipes for his house. Watch the bear take away your bamboo. Follow it to Genghis Khan's house. There, the bear installs the pipe in Genghis Khan's bathroom.

mnemonics.meaning: If you leave a cross on a drunkard's car it's a sign that you'll publish everything if they try to drive. It's basically the universal symbol of, "We're watching you, and we'll publish what you do, so don't drive drunk." Open your newspaper in the morning and you can see what's been published about all the drunkards who didn't pay attention to the crosses on their cars. They were all arrested and their stories were published for all to see.
mnemonics.reading: You need someone to publish all these stories, so you get your cyborg (さい) to do it. It can keep an eye on all the drunkards cars through the special crosses you put on their cars. And the cyborg is a great editor, which is a plus. Picture your cyborg, with one of those newsie hats on, publishing stories about all of the bad drunk drivers so they never do it again. It's using its metal and meat arms to publish multiple stories at once.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to use two axes to open these shellfish. That seems like overkill, but it is necessary. These particular shellfish are of very high quality meaning they won't open so easily. Imagine the highest quality shellfish you've ever seen. They're hard, smooth, and basically impenetrable.
mnemonics.reading: You finally get all of the shellfish open and you're admiring their quality, when your shih tzu (しつ) jumps up on the table and gobbles them down. NO! You try to chase after the little dog, but it's too late. They're gone. I guess your shih tzu knows good quality shellfish too. :(

mnemonics.meaning: When dawn reaches this village it increases in quantity. That's right. Every morning the amount of people or animals living here goes up by at least one. Picture dawn, the sun rising, the birds chirping, and the screams of a new born baby rise in the village. Or Maybe it's a new sheep! Or a new hat that someone just finished making.
mnemonics.reading: Today's dawn has brought with it an increase in the quantity of row boats! Aww, aren't they cute? Look at all of the new row boats lined up together. They all have their own sets of oars too. When every dawn brings a new amount of people, those new people are going to need that same amount of row boats.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're anti-shellfish, then you won't mind if I sell them all. You don't want them in your house anyway! if you're serious about being anti-shellfish then you should sell all the ones you have, or let me do it at least.
mnemonics.reading: I'm going to sell all of our shellfish to Han (はん) Solo. He isn't anti-shellfish like you, he knows how to turn a profit too! Picture me (hi) selling all of your shellfish to Han Solo as you stand there with your arms crossed. Han just shakes his head at you and continues to toss them onto his space ship.

mnemonics.meaning: A leader is always together with their servant. The servant is their constant companion, always following close behind the leader, offering them hot towels and bottled water. Try to picture the servant without the leader... you can't! The servant and the leader are always together.
mnemonics.reading: Once a year, when the servant wants to go home to きょうと, the leader follows. The servant isn't just there for the leader, they're companions, they support each other at all times. Even if that means heading home to きょうと to see the fam. Picture the servant enjoying tea and cherry blossoms in きょうと with their family as the leader sits patiently off to the side. What a good relationship these two have!

mnemonics.meaning: The door leading to the moon can be broken down with one’s shoulder. It’s not a very sturdy door to the moon, so it’s quite easy to drop your shoulder and ram it open. Picture yourself smashing through this door using your shoulder and seeing the moon on the other side. Hear the splintering of wood as your shoulder crashes through the door and feel the impact with your body.
mnemonics.reading: "Wow, your shoulder is just like my catapult (かた)!" you hear someone shout. As you turn you're just in time to see a man catapulting through his own moon door! Now the weird man is inspecting your shoulder really closely and he keeps muttering "catapult powers" under his breath. It's very unsettling, but he's kind of right. A shoulder works just like the mechanism that winds up a catapult.

mnemonics.meaning: What might cause a tree to slide down a jet would be if its stocks and shares took a dive in the market. This tree was on a jet for an important investor meeting when it got the news that its stocks and shares had just plummeted. Being very upset, the tree got up and got on the emergency slide out of the jet and plummeted into the ground just like his stocks and shares. Visualize this tree sliding out of the jet and falling to his doom. As he falls, visualize red lines falling alongside him to represent the stocks and shares. Hear the shrill whistle of them speeding through the air to the ground.
mnemonics.reading: Once the tree hits the ground with his stocks and his shares, the impact creates a large KABOOM (かぶ)! Stocks hit the ground - KABOOM! Shares! KABOOM! Tree! KABOOOOOOM~! Listen to each of these things impact the ground and see each individual mushroom cloud appear around them. KABOOM! KABOOM! KABOOM!

mnemonics.meaning: If, at a certain angle, you approach an insect, you’ll be able to touch it without it noticing. Most of the time, insects will run away from you when you try and touch them, but if you do so from the right angle, the insect will have no idea. Imagine yourself approaching this insect from a sneaky and stealthy angle. Now touch it. What does it feel like? Smooth? Hard? Fuzzy? Feel the insect in your mind as you touch it.
mnemonics.reading: Uh oh, looks like this particular insect is a lightning bug so when you touch it you get a shock (しょく). Did you know that lightning bugs contain bazillions of volts inside them? Well they do, and if you touch one, you get a shock. A very big shock. Feel this electrical shock to your system as you touch the lightning bug. This discourages you from ever touching another insect again. You don’t enjoy the shock.

mnemonics.meaning: What does a car and the Death Star have in common? They're both used to transport people and things. Imagine stuffing a bunch of Stormtroopers in your car so you can transport them across the country. Well the Death Star can transport even more Stormtroopers, faster, and through space!
mnemonics.reading: Right now you and the Death Star are transporting yurts (ゆ). They're the universe's #1 best transportable homes! It's easy to transport a yurt even without a car or the Death Star.

mnemonics.meaning: You're flying a helicopter and you see a woman in the moon light touching her waist. She has both hands on her waist, like she's Wonder Woman or something. But it's the middle of the night. What is she doing? Imagine flying your helicopter closer to the woman, it's not so hard because you have lots of moon light to see in, and try to see why she's touching her waist.
mnemonics.reading: As you get closer you realize her waist looks weird and... puffy? You bring the helicopter down and see that the woman's waist looks incredibly cozy (こし)! She has a blanket balled up and tied around her waist, she's holding it there with her hand, probably because it's cold out at night. But even with just her waist covered, she looks so warm and cozy!  Imagine how cozy your waist would be if you tied a nice warm blanket around it.

mnemonics.meaning: Above mentions are above mentioned. Look above to see where I mentioned it, okay?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 上述のように、雇用者、従業員のどちらも、いついかなる理由においても契約を終了することができる。
As stated above, both employees and employers can terminate an employment contract at any time for any reason.

mnemonics.meaning: The year amount is the yearly amount.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 前回のサービスも良かったとは思いますが、今回の新サービスはもっとよくなったと思うんです。それでいて、会員費は変わらず年額80ドルのままなんですよ。
I think the previous service was good, but we feel we outdid ourselves on this new service. Furthermore, the membership fees are still only eighty dollars a year.

mnemonics.meaning: The angle of the touch is important with an antenna. Think about antennas. An ant's antenna wiggle around and move in different angles, touching things, to understand the world around them. Imagine their tiny bug antennas touching your arm to figure out who you are.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. しょく goes to しょっ.

sentences: 触角の先端に目があるなんて知らなかったので、その蝸牛の触角を切り落としてしまった。
I cut off the snail’s antennae because I didn’t know its eyes are on the tips of them.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 「フグのこと、どう思う？」「正直に言うと、私の好みじゃないわ。私はキンニクマみたいに筋肉モリモリの腕の男が好きなの。」
"What do you think of Fugu?" "To be honest, I don’t like him. I prefer a guy with muscular arms like Kinnikuma."

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 誕生 is birth? If you add day on there, you have a birthday. Happy birthday!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but with this word 日 uses the kun'yomi ひ, which is turned into び due to rendaku.

sentences: 「君の誕生日会に友達を連れて行ってもいい？」「もちろん！ 人数が多ければ多いほど楽しいしね。」
"Can I bring a friend to your birthday party?" "Of course! The more people we have, the more fun it will be."

mnemonics.meaning: Transport of blood. Only time you do this is during a blood transfusion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼女はちょうど東京に向かおうとしていた矢先に交通事故に巻き込まれ、現在病院で輸血を受けている。
She was in a car accident when she was just about to head off to Tokyo, and now she is getting a blood transfusion in the hospital.

mnemonics.meaning: The pipe that holds your blood is your blood vessels.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The けつ goes to けっ.

sentences: 彼は血管が切れそうなぐらい怒っていた。
He was so angry that his veins were popping out.

mnemonics.meaning: Both arms are both arms!
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the on'yomi reading of 両 and the kun'yomi reading of 腕. You've learned them both, so you know this too!

sentences: 両腕にホクロがたくさんあります。
There are a lot of moles on both my arms.
次は両腕を交差させてください。
Next, please cross one arm over the other.
両腕がもうげん界です。
My arms can't take it anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: The boundary separates worlds. It is a boundary.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 母と私は、いつもお互いの個人的な境界線のようなものを気にしています。
My mom and I are always cautious of each other’s personal boundaries.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You walk up to the boundary. You're there to pick something up to take it across. This thing you're smuggling across the boundary is a sockeye (さかい) salmon. You take it across the boundary and sell it for a big profit.

sentences: この川がちょうど両州の境となっているんですよ。
This river forms the boundary between the two states.

mnemonics.meaning: You lose. Because of that, you have to carry this burden and responsibility.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 10キロのお米を持ち上げることは、彼の腰の負担となった。
Lifting 10kg of rice was a burden on his lower back.

mnemonics.meaning: Possible to burn ゴミ (garbage). This is burnable garbage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あなたが私から貰うクリスマスプレゼントは、可燃ごみだけだよ。
The only thing you’re getting for Christmas from me is burnable garbage.

mnemonics.meaning: Your special quality is your characteristics or your traits.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 笑いは人間だけの特質なのかな？それとも動物も笑うのかな？
Is laughter a characteristic that only humans have, or can animals laugh as well?

mnemonics.meaning: A child servant is a child. Children are basically like little servants anyways, what else are they good for?
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this one are the kun'yomi readings of each kanji. 子 is just こ, like the individual vocab word. 供 is ども, however. Remember this by thinking how much children love domo-kun. Also, 子ども is kind of more "politically correct" with the kana hanging off there. 子供 is still used in a lot of situations, usually stiff ones. The second kanji means servant, and some people don't like that. The second version pops up a decent amount, so it's good to be familiar with that as well.

sentences: お前の子供、イケメンすぎて、お前の子供だとは思えねーよ。
Your child is way too good looking, I can hardly believe he’s your kid.

mnemonics.meaning: Your parents don't want this to expand out into the community. Let's keep this confidential.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: もし「親展」と書かれている封書を勝手に開けたら、信書開封罪とみなされて一年以下の懲役又は二十万円以下の罰金に課せられるかもしれませんよ。

If you opened a sealed envelope marked "Confidential" without permission, it could be considered as an unlawful opening of a letter and you could be punished with imprisonment with work detail for under one year, or a fine of up to 200,000 yen.

mnemonics.meaning: Your versus plan is to attack back. They've already attacked you once, so now it's time for your counter plan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コーヒーを入れようとしてボタンを押したら、コーヒーメーカーが火を噴いたの。不具合の原因を見つけて、再発防止対策を講じなきゃいけないわ。
I was making a cup of coffee, I pressed a button, and the machine caught on fire. We have to find the cause of the defect and take measures to prevent its recurrence.

mnemonics.meaning: Write down and mention what happened. When you do this you're writing a description and account of what happened.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: もしその男に関する記述が誤植だったら、間違った人を逮捕してしまうかもしれないよ。
If your description of the man is inaccurate, we might arrest the wrong person.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you'd think it's probably an adjective. However in this case, it's a noun. What's the noun form of different? It's difference.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Not different at all.

sentences: 清掃員と副社長の違いなんて全く分からないね。
I really don’t see the difference between a garbage man and an executive vice president.

mnemonics.meaning: You make a distinction between people and based off that you separate the people. This is terrible! Why so much discrimination?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は偏見や差別は好きではありませんが、そういう冗談は好きです。
I don’t like prejudice or discrimination, but I do like those types of jokes.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the ぞう reading of the kanji. You're at the ぞう show. How exciting.

sentences: あの象、別の動物園から来た雌の象と昨夜交尾をしたよ。
That male elephant hooked up with the female from the other zoo last night.

mnemonics.meaning: The loop that makes up the boundary of this area holds in the environment, at least this particular one.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 環境保護の観点では、固形石けんの方が液体石けんよりも優れている。
From an environmental perspective, bar soap is usually better than the liquid kind.

mnemonics.meaning: The real quality of something is its essence, or its true nature. Whether it's good or bad is a different story.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 問題の本質の追求って難しいよね。
Pursuing the essence of a problem is difficult, isn't it?
トーフグは、うらで、人間の本質をあばくための様々な実験を行っています。
Tofugu secretly conducts various experiments to expose the true nature of human beings.
この男は、物事の本質を見抜くことができる。
This man is able to see things for what they really are.

mnemonics.meaning: When you transport things and they exit from your country, you are exporting them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 出張の際にヘロウィンを密輸出しようとしたため、彼は試験期間のうちに契約を打ち切られた。
He was terminated during his probation period because he tried to smuggle heroin on a business trip.

mnemonics.meaning: When you can look at far things, but not near things, you have farsightedness, longsightedness, or hyperopia.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, which you'd know if it wasn't for your farsightedness (go get some glasses so you can read our lessons!).

sentences: 遠視の治りょうは、メガネをかけることです。
The treatment of longsightedness is to wear glasses.
毎年遠視が悪化していっています。
My farsightedness is getting worse every year.
遠視が進んできたので、そろそろ老眼鏡を買わなきゃいけないかもしれない。
My farsightedness is progressing, so I may have to get a pair of reading glasses soon.

mnemonics.meaning: A determined amount is an amount that is fixed, aka a fixed amount, a fixed sum, or flat rate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 定額のプランに変こうしました。
I changed it to the flat rate plan.
ワニカニは月々定額で利用できますよ。
WaniKani is available for a fixed monthly amount.
あの〜、定額貯金の口座を開設したいんですが。
Um, I’d like to open up a fixed deposit saving account.

mnemonics.meaning: A determined quantity is a fixed quantity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 定量オーバーですよ。
It's over the set quantity.
定量供きゅう機を発明して特許を取った人を知っています。
I know the person who invented and patented the fixed quantity supplying machine.
どうにかしてこのリスクを定量化する方法はないのかな。
Isn’t there any way to change the set amount of risk?

mnemonics.meaning: You previously learned this kanji with three different meanings. In vocabulary form, it just has one of these meanings, framed picture! Similarly, it can just mean picture or frame too.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 大統領、本当にコウイチの絵を額に入れてホワイトハウスにかざる気なのかな？
I wonder if the president is really willing to frame Koichi's painting and hang it in the White House?
卒業証書を大学の名前付きの額に入れてかべにかけました。
I put the graduation certificate in a picture frame that comes with the university name on it and hung it on the wall.
この絵に合う額を探しています。
I’m searching for a frame to match this picture.

mnemonics.meaning: A material you can burn is called fuel!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 単なる燃料切れだったよ。
I was simply running out of fuel.

mnemonics.meaning: Good quality is always good quality. Don't skimp!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 良質のワインを飲む事が私の唯一の楽しみだ。
Drinking good quality wine is my only pleasure.

mnemonics.meaning: A government government office is a government office. Did I mention government?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 主に官庁内で使われる特別な用語ってありますか？
Are there specific words that are used mainly within government offices?

mnemonics.meaning: A half amount sale is when things are half price. Cheap!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチ、そろそろ起きる時間よ！ウォールマートの半額セールに行かなきゃいけないんだから。
Koichi, time to get up! We have to go to Walmart’s half price sale today.

mnemonics.meaning: A tall value. If you paid for something that had a tall value, it would have a high price.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

sentences: コウイチの秘密の日記が、オークションで歴代最高値で落札された。
Koichi’s secret diary fetched a record high price at the auction.

mnemonics.meaning: By my self at home I manufactured this. It is homemade.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私がホテルで自家製ビールを楽しんでいる時に、警察が自宅へ襲撃を決行したようです。
While I was enjoying my home brewed beer in a hotel room last night, the police seem to have conducted a raid on my house.

mnemonics.meaning: You carry everyone else and you are always right. With these traits, you are in charge.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: もしこの染みが抜けなかったら、私はこのプロジェクトの担当から外されてしまうかもしれない。
If that stain won’t come off, I may no longer be in charge of this project.

mnemonics.meaning: You mix, but there's a distinction as to where you mix at this point. Where is this point? It can be found when two streets cross, at an intersection, also known as a crossing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 次の交差点を左に曲がって下さい。
Please turn left at the next intersection.

mnemonics.meaning: A many amount is a large amount or large sum.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 最終的に会議はうまくいって、なんとか我々の科学調査への多額の寄付金を約束してもらうことができたよ。
The meeting ended smoothly and we managed to make them promise us a large donation for our scientific research.

mnemonics.meaning: A large quantity is a large quantity. Kind of like the large number of words you're learning here now. A huge amount. Well done you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 単に気が変わったという理由で、前日に大量のドーナツの注文をキャンセルした。
I cancelled the order for a large quanty of donuts the day before, simply because I changed my mind.
台所に蟻が大量発生しているのを見て、完全に取り乱してしまいました。
I totally freaked out when I saw the large number of ants in the kitchen.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember 寝坊 and how it means oversleep? Someone who oversleeps in the morning is someone who's a late riser.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the vocab words 朝 and 寝坊 put together into one. So long as you know them separately you should know them together too!

sentences: 私は朝寝坊だが、妹は私と違って早起きだから、君の犬の散歩に行けるかもしれないよ。
I’m a late riser but my sister is an early riser, she might be able to walk your dogs for you.

mnemonics.meaning: Laws are standard in society. You must have laws and regulations in society.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 海戦に関する国際法規について書かれた本は、この図書館にありますか。
Is there a book about the international laws concerning naval hostility in this library?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a word that's attached to other things indicating the layer of something (or just layer). It has essentially the same meaning as the kanji it comes from, layer.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. It's treated like a jukugo reading because it's normally attached to things.

sentences: ホッケーの競技場さえも、オゾン層の破壊に関係しているって、知ってたかい？
Did you know hockey arenas are related to the destruction of the ozone layer?

mnemonics.meaning: Your left arm is your left arm.
mnemonics.reading: The reading can either be a combination of the kun'yomi readings (more common) or the on'yomi readings (pretty uncommon, and only used to talk about sports players, especially baseball). That being said, you've seen all of these readings except わん. If you want to remember さわん just think: I have just one (わん) left arm!

sentences: 左腕を骨折しました。
My left arm is broken.

mnemonics.meaning: Long sleeves are long sleeves.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

sentences: 今日は、長袖着ていった方がいいかな？
Should I wear a long sleeve top today?
長袖のパーカーを買いに行くのに、付き合ってくれない？
Can you help me shop for some long sleeve hoodies?
私の彼氏は、タトゥー隠すため夏でも長袖を着ることがある。
Sometimes my boyfriend wears long sleeves in summer in order to hide his tattoos.

mnemonics.meaning: A cheap valued item comes at a low price. What a good deal!
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

sentences: 私はこの長靴を驚くほどの安値で買いましたが、防水加工がされてませんでした。
I bought these rain boots at an unbelievably low price, but they aren’t waterproof.

mnemonics.meaning: China (中国) manufactured items are made in China.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know the word 中国 already.

sentences: インターネット上で、中国製の日本語学習サイトがどれだけあるのかについては、正確な数字は今は分かりません。調べてのちほどお答えします。
I’m afraid I’m not sure of the exact number of Japanese learning sites on the internet right now that were made in China. I’ll check on it and get back to you later.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that are manufactured in Japan (日本) are made in Japan. Good quality stuff, that is.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know how to read 日本 already.

sentences: その日本製の刀の柄には、美しい宝石が散りばめられている。
The sword hilt was made in Japan and is studded with beautiful jewels.

mnemonics.meaning: America manufactured is something that is made in USA or made in America.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: アメリカ製の寿司は食べられないだって？好き嫌いするんじゃないよ！
You really won’t eat sushi that was made in USA? You’re too picky.

mnemonics.meaning: Things you sell that pass through the world to get to you are probably mail order. You order them and they get zoomed off to you, passing through all kinds of space to arrive at your door.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今まで通販で買い物したことないけど、ちょっとやってみるよ。
I’ve never bought anything through mail order before, but I’ll give it a shot.

mnemonics.meaning: The pipe of reason. Imagine someone holding this pipe. It always leads to the correct decision because it is the pipe of reason. Those who have this pipe are in a higher rank than you. They are the management, and by using this pipe of reason they're able to make good management decisions.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 時間管理法の授業の講師が遅刻しているなんて、信じられない。
I can’t believe the lecturer of the time management strategy class is actually late.

mnemonics.meaning: A place where you manufacture and make is a place where manufacturing and production are done. So many things getting made.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 村田製作所は、電子部品を製造している日本の会社です。
Murata Manufacturing Co., Ltd. is a Japanese company that manufactures electronic components.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take the road of the military you're going to have to fight a lot. Back in the day, this involved learning martial arts to fight with. Remember, just wax off.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 武道の経験が無い日本人はたくさんいます。
There are many Japanese people who don’t have any experience in martial arts.

mnemonics.meaning: A product's quality is in its material quality. If the materials aren't any good then the product isn't either.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼女は品質管理マネージャーとして入社した。
She’s been brought on board as the quality control manager.

mnemonics.meaning: The metropolis agency is the government that controls the metropolitan area. This is the metropolitan government.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 東京都庁の展望台に行った事はありますか。
Have you been to the observation deck of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building?

mnemonics.meaning: They warn, they look at crime, and they're an agency of the government. They are the metropolitan police department.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の兄は、東京都警視庁公安部に勤めています。
My brother works for the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department Public Security Bureau.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: What model cutter (かた) is this? I can only use a certain type for my work.

sentences: どうして日本人は血液型をそんなに気にするんですか？
Why do Japanese people care about blood types so much?

mnemonics.meaning: A month's amount is the monthly amount.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 月額たったの5ドルでできる新しい日本語学習体験を促進するための広告キャンペーンを打ち始めます。
We are starting an advertising campaign to encourage a new Japanese learning experience that costs only five dollars a month.

mnemonics.meaning: One layer... that's it? We need much more!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち goes to いっ.

sentences: かわいそうなことに、彼の視力はレーシック手術の後に一層悪化してしまった。
I feel sorry that his eyesight got even worse after the Lasik surgery.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of narrow? It's narrow.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you're good to go here. It may be a narrow way of thinking about this kanji, but it will help you out the most.

sentences: コウイチ、おもちゃを片付けなさい！さもないと、暗くて狭いクローゼットに閉じ込めるわよ。
Koichi, put your toys away! If you don’t I’ll put you in the dark, narrow closet.

mnemonics.meaning: A country boundary is that country's national border. Be careful about crossing it if you're carrying bananas. The border police seem to hate when you tell them you're carrying a banana in your pants when they ask you if you're bringing any fruits back. No idea why.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The こく gets shortened to a nice little こっ.

sentences: 国境警備隊の隊員がアメリカに不法入国した外国人を国境のそばの茂みで見つけることはよくあることです。
It is common for Border Patrol agents to find foreigners who have entered the U.S. illegally in the bushes near the border.

mnemonics.meaning: A celebrate day is a day you get off to celebrate something awesome. More specifically, this is known as a national holiday or a public holiday. Festivus for the restivus!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチは祝日はいつもかなり派手な格好をしている。
Koichi always wears the most showy clothes on holidays.

mnemonics.meaning: Unlike the 警視庁, who look at things, this is just the police officer (警察) agency. Just the general police agency of the whole country, making them part of the National Police Agency.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 警視庁と警察庁の違いは何ですか？
What’s the difference between the Metropolitan Police Department and the National Police Agency?

mnemonics.meaning: When you can look at things that are near well but you can't see things far away, you have nearsightedness, shortsightedness, or myopia. Good to get those eyes checked out occasionally.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: メガネをかけてるのはファッションじゃなくて、単に近視なだけですよ。
I wear glasses not for fashion but because of my shortsightedness.
このコンタクトレンズは、遠視と近視両方に対応しています。
This contact lenses are both for farsightedness and nearsightedness.
私は近視と乱視の両方があります。
I have both nearsightedness and an astigmatism.

mnemonics.meaning: These are not burnable garbages (ごみ). Pay attention to this on signs when you throw things away. You want to put the right things into nonburnable garbage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 不燃ゴミは火曜日に出してください。
Please take out the nonburnable garbage on Tuesday.

mnemonics.meaning: When you present something to your servant you're doing them a favor. You're kindly giving them an offer. Or, because they're a poor student, maybe you're offering program sponsoring to them. You know, because you're so nice.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本で臓器提供者になる同意書にサインをするには、どうすればいいですか？
How can I register to become an organ donor in Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: 営業 means running a business. You're in the middle of running a business, which means you're open for business (otherwise you wouldn't be in the middle of running it, you'd be at the beginning or something).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 営業 first.

sentences: 営業中に電話しないでって言ったじゃない。
I asked you not to call me when the shop is open.

mnemonics.meaning: The past shape is how things were in the past. To describe those things (like you would with an adjective, aka 形容詞), you'd use past tense.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この場合は過去形は使わないんですか？
Don’t you use the past tense in this case?

mnemonics.meaning: A present time phenomenon is a phenomenon whether it's in the present or in the future or in the past.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本にUFO現象を調査しているUFO団体はありますか？
Are there any UFO groups investigating the UFO phenomena in Japan?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: "That's coo' だ," you like to say in response to pipes. You've never seen pipes before, which makes them pretty cool to you. You've been using an outhouse your whole life, so pipes are pretty neat.

sentences: 妹は二歳の時に甘い咳止めシロップを一気飲みしてしまい、鼻から管を通して胃を洗浄するはめになった。
My sister chugged a bottle of the sweet kind of cough syrup when she was two and she had to get a tube shoved through her nose and into her stomach to pump it out.

mnemonics.meaning: 置く is to put down something. So a location where you put something down is a place to put something.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the readings of 置く and 場 put together.

sentences: 洗面台の下にタオル置き場があるから、シャワーの後勝手に取って使ってね。
We have a place for the towels under the sink, so help yourself after your shower.

mnemonics.meaning: A price tag is... a price tag!
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You learned the kun'yomi reading for 値 in the vocabulary word 値(ね), earlier in this level. You learned the reading for 札 in the vocabulary 札(ふだ). Put them together and you have ねふだ.

sentences: この品物には、値札シールがありません。
This item doesn't have a price tag.
王様は、いつも値札を見ずに買い物をして、女王様に怒られます。
The king always buys stuff without looking at the price tags and the queen gets angry at him.
値札を確かめた後に、買うのを止めました。
After checking the price tag, I decided not to buy it.

mnemonics.meaning: The item is in a place in its existence where it is published. If something is in this place, it is printed and published.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 『古事記』所載の日本最古の和歌について何か知っていますか？
Do you know anything about the Japanese first waka published in the Kojiki?

mnemonics.meaning: Manufactured goods are manufactured goods. What does that end up being? A product.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 我が社の新製品に関する会議を火曜日の午後に延期することは可能かな？
Would it be possible to postpone the meeting for our new product until Tuesday afternoon?

mnemonics.meaning: The original model of something isn't usually very good. It's rough. It's a prototype.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私たちはまず初めに、粘土で彫刻の原型を作るんです。
We usually sculpt a model out of clay at first.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 外国語指導助手の質は人によって全然違うので、心配です。
The quality of assistant foreign language teachers varies from person to person and I’m worried about that.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 仕事の量を考えると、この給料じゃ割りに合わない。
Given the amount of work, we’re being badly paid.

mnemonics.meaning: A quality problem is worth a question. A low quality problem however... don't ask the question. There are stupid questions, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼はある観客からの予想外の質問にたじろいだ。
He flinched at the unexpected question from an audience member.

mnemonics.meaning: Please write down and publish this so we have a record of it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 小論文を提出したが、日付を記載するのを忘れてしまった。
I turned in my essay but I forgot to record the date on it.

mnemonics.meaning: The remainder amount is the remaining amount, aka the balance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 残額は五百円あるので、次の旅行に繰り越すこともできるし、半日市内バス観光をすることもできます。
The balance is 500 yen, so we could carry it over to the next trip or we could also go on a half-day bus tour of the city.

mnemonics.meaning: A group that roots for you is your rooting section or  cheerleaders. Go go go you!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 応援 is a word you've seen before, so if you know that this word will be easier.

sentences: ああ、君が応援団長だね？噂はかねがね伺っておるよ。
Hey, you are the leader of the cheerleaders, right? I’ve heard a lot about you.

mnemonics.meaning: Sell, sell, sell. This is the attitude you need if you want to work in sales or do sales. You have to work on your selling.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which means you need to know the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know them both, hurray!

sentences: 我が社の販売員の多くは、八月に休暇を取ります。
Many of the salespeople at our company are taking time off work in August.

mnemonics.meaning: A military samurai is a samurai. This is how most people say "samurai" in Japanese.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチは武士のようにストイックに走り続け、フルマラソンを完走した。
Koichi kept running as stoically as a samurai and finished the full marathon.

mnemonics.meaning: You look at things and memorize them via your sight, using your sense of sight.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 視覚障害のある社員を差別したとの理由から、上司が解雇された。
My superior was fired for discrimination against a visually disabled worker.

mnemonics.meaning: Half sleeves is just another name for short sleeves.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 半 and the kun'yomi reading for 袖. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word.

sentences: 半袖で寒くない？
Aren't you cold in a short sleeve top?
コンマリの本を読んでから、半袖のシャツは一枚しか持っていない。
After reading Kon Mari's book, I only own one short sleeve shirt.
今年のファッショントレンドは半袖の革ジャンです。
This year's trending fashion is short sleeve leather jackets.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 肩がこっているんだけど、ちょっと揉んでくれない？
My shoulders are stiff, so could you rub them a bit?

mnemonics.meaning: The standard of standards is the main standard we work off of.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼は世間の規準からはちょっと外れた、ユニークな人です。
He is a unique person who is slightly out of the ordinary.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji.

sentences: コウイチは株でガッポリ儲けたので、車のタイヤをどでかいホイール・タイヤに変えて、シートも革張りにしてカッチョ良くしちゃおうと決めた。
Koichi made tons of money on the stock market and decided to swag out his car with big wheels and leather seats.

mnemonics.meaning: A stocks ritual is the dance we do in the modern world around stocks and shares of different companies. Buy! Sell! Buy! Sell!
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 株式市場が底なしの下落に陥ったようだというニュースは、彼に大きな精神的ダメージを与えた。
The news that the stock market seemed to go into a bottomless decline was a great blow to him.

mnemonics.meaning: 主観 is subjectivity. So when something moves towards subjectivity it is becoming subjective.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know 主観.

sentences: これはとても主観的な見方かもしれないけど、僕にとっては君は働き過ぎだと思うんだよね。近々休みを取った方がいいよ。
This may be a very subjective view, but to me, you work too much and should take time off sometime soon.

mnemonics.meaning: The versus phenomenon is what you're going up against. It's your target because you're heading towards this phenomenon you're versusing against.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 勤続三十年の従業員は、勤続手当として二週間連続有給休暇の対象となる。
Employees who work for this company for thirty years are subject to two straight weeks off with full pay as a reward for their many years of service to the company.

mnemonics.meaning: The time distinction is how you tell apart time zones. It is the time difference.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: まだ時差ボケに苦しんでいるんです。
I’m still suffering from jet lag.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 援助 is assistance or aid. So the verb vocab version is to assist or to aid.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 援助. It is also just the readings you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 俺はポテトチップス一袋を買うのに、他人からの援助を必要とするほど貧しい。
I’m so poor that I need help from others just to buy a bag of potato chips.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deliver so the verb vocab version here is to be delivered or to arrive. You know this one is "to be delivered" (aka it's just getting delivered, you aren't doing the delivery) because when this item arrives at your house you say "coo'" (く), it arrived.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji: とど!

sentences: トーフグからの手紙がちょうど今届きました。
The letter from Tofugu was just delivered.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means different so the verb vocab version is to be different... and of course, to be different is also to be wrong in Japan. Don't be different!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. It's not different at all.

sentences: ベテラン社員とは違って、新入社員の基本給はあまり高くない。
Compared to veteran employees, the base pay of new employees isn’t very high.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means publish so the verb vocab version is to be published. Books can be published, magazines can be published, and I guess even your gross blog posts get published too.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  "Hey, were you able to be published yet?" someone asks, and the answer is always NO (の)! It's never your time to get published. The answer is always no... because no one likes (sniff) what you write (sob).

sentences: 新入社員の代表として受けた私のインタビュー記事が、社内報の春季号に載りました。
My interview as the representative of the entry-level employees was published in the spring edition of the company newsletter.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means burn and the verb vocab version is to burn something (or to burn).
mnemonics.reading: This is when you're burning something. To remember this meaning, you have to remember the も part. So, just think of your friend Moe (も), and how you're going to burn him... uh... just a little bit.

sentences: 何かを完全に灰になるまで燃やすことが大好きだ。
I really like burning things until they’re reduced to ashes.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carry so the verb vocab version is to carry. This has to do with carrying something literal, unlike 担う which is not necessarily literal (you'll learn it later). And in this case, you carry it on your shoulder(s). You can remember that it's literal from the reading mnemonic, which has you carrying literal cats on your shoulders.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You love to carry things, especially cats (かつ). You hoist them up onto your shoulders and carry them all around town.

sentences: 日本に行ったら、お祭りで神輿を担いでみたい。
If I go to Japan, I’d like to carry a portable shrine in a parade.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means celebrate, so the verb vocab version is to celebrate. When you burn this word, you should 祝う!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you celebrate something, you have to yell out your celebrations. Yell out いわう three times! It's kind of like a combination of the word いい (good) and "wow." いいwow! いいwow! Just make sure the いい gets shortened, because it's getting combined.

sentences: 日曜日におじいちゃんの還暦を祝うために、中華を食べに行きます。
We are going to a Chinese restaurant to celebrate grandpa’s 60th birthday on Sunday.

mnemonics.meaning: Let's depart from this place and expand it out. To do that we'll have to develop it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はつ gets shortened to はっ, though.

sentences: 年寄りの風邪は肺炎に発展しやすいんだよ。
When old people catch a cold, it can easily develop into pneumonia.

mnemonics.meaning: I will look at nothing. I am going to ignore you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 休暇届を申請したが、上司に無視された。
I requested a day off for personal reasons, but my boss ignored it.

mnemonics.meaning: You don't servant something... but what do servants do? You are their god, so they have to make an offering to you every day.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. It shares its reading with the word 備える, which you learned a level ago, but in case you need a reminder, here it is: What's the best way for your servants to make an offering? When they offer up their sauna (そな)! You really value a warm and relaxing sauna session at the end of the day.

sentences: 明日お墓に供える花を、帰りに買ってきてくれない？
Can you buy some flowers to place on the graves tomorrow on your way home?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means quantity, but you don't "to quantity." To figure out the quantity, however, you have to measure / to weigh whatever it is you want to get the quantity of.
mnemonics.reading: You need to measure the quantity of something, but don't have a scale or anything. Luckily, you are quite the hacker (はか) and hack together a scale using only rubber bands and beans.

sentences: 体重計で自分の体重を量るのが恐い。
I’m scared of weighing myself on the scale.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mention so the verb vocab version is to mention.
mnemonics.reading: I have to mention this thing... "NO," (の) you quickly respond. I don't want you mentioning that here and now.

sentences: 上司に全く正反対の意見を述べるのは気が引けます。
I don’t feel like explaining to my boss that I have a completely different opinion than he has.

mnemonics.meaning: 過ぎる is to pass. When you pass what is needed, what are you left with? Just this word: too much. This can also mean after, as in "after 5pm", and past, as in "past sixty".
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 過ぎる. Know that and you know too much. Dial it down to get 過ぎ.

sentences: うちの子は、気が多過ぎて一つのことに集中するのが苦手なんです。
My child has too much on his mind and has trouble focusing on one thing.
五時過ぎにむかえに行きます。
I will pick you up shortly after 5 o'clock.
短時間の仕事で良い給料をもらい過ぎだよ。
You get paid way too much for working such short hours.

mnemonics.meaning: 寝坊 is oversleep. Make that into a verb and you have to oversleep.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also just takes the reading from 寝坊.

sentences: 「しまった！寝坊した！」と思ったんですが、有り難いことに日曜日でした。
I thought, "Oh no! I overslept," but thankfully, it was Sunday.

mnemonics.meaning: When you want to use your finger to explain the distinction between more than one thing you need to point at it. Otherwise the person you're talking to won't be able to tell which one you're talking about.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 人を指差すのは失礼だよ。
It’s rude to point at people.

mnemonics.meaning: You remember 提案, which means proposition? Make that into a verb and you have to propose.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 本日は、新しい投資信託をご提案させて頂きたいと思います。
I’d like to propose a new mutual fund to you today.

mnemonics.meaning: 応援 is aid and root for, but for this verb the "root for" one is going to be more on the money. You can call this to root for, to cheer on or to cheer for.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 応援. It's also just the on'yomi readings you learned.

sentences: どちらの力士を応援しているんだい？
Which sumo wrestler are you rooting for?
トーフグ社員はみんな、両足を肩はばに開いて立ちながら、コウイチを応援していた。
