All Tofugu employees were cheering for Koichi, standing with their feet hip-width apart.

mnemonics.meaning: The word 営業 is business. The verb version of that (to do a business) becomes to run a business.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, it shares the reading with 営業.

sentences: 道ばたで営業する占い師が、どれくらいのお金を稼ぐのか知ってる？
Do you know how much money a fortune teller doing business on the street makes?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is distinction. To distinct something would be nice, but this is used more like to shine at or to shine on, like when a light shines on someone on a stage, distinguishing them from everyone else.
mnemonics.reading: The reading of the kanji is actually the same as the reading for this word, making things easy (both on'yomi and kun'yomi are さ).

sentences: 窓の外を見ると、もう雨が上がって薄日が差していた。
When I looked outside the window, the rain had already stopped and a soft light was shining through.

mnemonics.meaning: To support and aid is to support.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 何が起ころうが君を支援しようとしたけど、できなかったんだ。
I tried to stand by you no matter what happened, but I failed.

mnemonics.meaning: All of the amount is your total.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お菓子代は、全額自己負担でお願いします。
Please pay the total amount for the candy yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means touch so the verb vocab version is to touch.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're an idiot. You try to touch a saw (さわ).

sentences: うちの猫は他人に触られるのが大嫌い。
Our cat doesn't like it when strangers touch her.
これを手で触ってみると、温かい感じがします。
When I touch this with my hand, it feels warm.
私のパソコンに触るな！
Hands off my computer!

mnemonics.meaning: Your feeling of touch is your touch sense (or simply just touch).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このストールの感触、シルクみたい。
This scarf feels like silk.

mnemonics.meaning: Sightseeing (観光) guests are tourists and sightseers.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 観光 as well.

sentences: その観光客は、アメリカで医者の診断書をもらうために50ドルを支払わなければならなかった。
The tourist had to pay $50 to get a doctor’s note in the U.S.

mnemonics.meaning: I want to expand my business. I want to show my goods. I want to do this in a place where everyone meets up to do these things. You can do this in a trade show.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の兄は、カフェで初めての美術展示会を開催した。
My brother organized his first art exhibition in a cafe.

mnemonics.meaning: Transmits the feeling of wanting to unite behind something. What do people unite behind, if they're all part of a similar people? Tradition. Add 的 on there and you have traditional.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 褌は、伝統的な日本の男性用下着です。
Fundoshi is traditional Japanese underwear for guys.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to transport something by sending it? Well that's transportation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 輸送コストを教えて下さい。
Please tell me the transportation cost.

mnemonics.meaning: The rule model is the model that follows all the rules. It's the normal model. It is typical.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: どうして彼のことを典型的な日本人だっていうの？
Why do you call him a typical Japanese person?

mnemonics.meaning: To expand and open. Just imagine something happening like this. This is when something is unfolding or in development.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 中小企業が海外展開をする利点とは何でしょうか。
What are the advantages of small businesses expanding overseas?

mnemonics.meaning: These views that have merit (価値) are your values.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 結婚相手と価値観が近いことって結構大切だと思うんだよねー。
I think it’s quite important to share similar values with your spouse.

mnemonics.meaning: Automatic (自動) sell sell machine. The machine sells things by itself, basically. This is a vending machine. There is a shorter version of this, but good to learn the long one first :)
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Remember those, and you'll be fine here.

sentences: 10月23日の自動販売機に関する会議は、コウイチの誕生日会のため、10月24日に変更されました。
The October twenty-third meeting about the vending machines has been rescheduled for October twenty-fourth due to Koichi’s birthday party.

mnemonics.meaning: You know about 大統領 (president), right? Well, this is the vice version of the president, aka the vice president.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the word 大統領 first, though.

sentences: やってみるべきだと思うけど。大統領は無理でも、副大統領ぐらいなら狙えるんじゃない？
I think we should give it a try. You may not become the president, but maybe you’ll become the vice president.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 腰に激痛が走ってるんだ。もう一歩も歩けないよ。
My waist is in intense pain. I can’t take another step.

mnemonics.meaning: A container used by the military is probably going to be used as a weapon. After all, that's what the military does... weapons.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 全ての警察官に武器を使う資格があるわけではないというのは本当ですか？
Is it true that not all police officers are qualified to use their weapons?

mnemonics.meaning: The energy phenomenon. That's when energy is doing stuff in the sky and nobody understands it. That's the weather for you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 気象予報士と気象学者の違いが説明できますか。
Can you explain the difference between forecasters and meteorologists?

mnemonics.meaning: Tree manufactured items are wooden / made from wood.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 俺の木製バットは、あいつの内角速球によって折れてしまったんだ。
My wooden bat was broken by an inside fastball thrown by that guy.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 時計 is watch? An arm is now there too, making this a wristwatch.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the words 腕 (same reading as what you learned with the kanji) as well as the reading for 時計. Just don't forget that rendaku!

sentences: 俺の無くなった腕時計についてちょっと話がしたいんだけど、いいか？あまり時間は取らせないよ。
Can we talk about my missing wristwatch for a second? I won’t take up too much of your time.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means both.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means capital.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means friend.
Flowers need the sun to get big. To help them grow as big as possible, we put them in the greenhouse.

You have a task to save two kinds of lives. Who saves two kinds of lives? A lifeguard. They save the lives of people drowning, and then the lives of the people who go to try to help them. Picture a lifeguard saving the lives of two people at once. What a hero!
This radical has slide, head, and insect in it. Which insect will slide your head off in a matter of seconds and then eat it? The fearsome praying mantis.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means mix.
This radical looks like someone wearing a giant dress who has a tear in their eye. This is a person at their wedding. That explains the big dress and the tear (of happiness!) in their eye.

If you could just get your soul to open the window to shellfish, you'll grow accustomed to them sooner or later! I know shellfish are a bit of an acquired taste, but if you don't open that window, you'll never like them! Close your eyes and picture your soul. Now your soul is opening a little window inside of you that is the perfect size for shellfish of all kinds. Hopefully with exposure and acceptance you'll grow accustomed to them.
mnemonics.reading: You'll need to become accustomed to eating shellfish if you want to grow up big and strong like Genghis Khan (かん). He didn't have shellfish growing up either you know, he had to grow accustomed to their taste too, but look how successful he was! Force yourself to get accustomed to shellfish like Genghis Khan, then maybe you'll rule most of the planet someday.

mnemonics.meaning: The flag is old but that doesn't mean it's not still alive. This is a living flag, and it gets old just like other living things. Imagine the old flag with a face and mouth and eyes and nose... it talks and listens and everything else. It's a flag that's alive D:
mnemonics.reading: The flag that is old and alive is actually a Buddhist relic (that's why it's alive, in fact ... and old!). But, it's a really dumb relic, so it's put in Little Kyoto (きょ). Not as cool as a real relic, it's put in this dumb Little Kyoto shrine that's basically just a tourist attraction. Eh, whatever.

mnemonics.meaning: Your scooter's been stolen by a wolverine, who's now getting water all over it. You need to apprehend that wolverine! Not only did the wolverine steal your scooter, but it is getting your poor scooter all wet by riding it through puddles. Now you and all the cops are chasing the wolverine down on police scooters and you're going to apprehend it!
mnemonics.reading: You catch up with the wolverine and apprehend it by tying it down with the tie (たい) from around your neck! It's a really nice tie you use to apprehend the wolverine, so even though it's struggling and fighting, it can't get away.

mnemonics.meaning: You have to fly in a helicopter and use a jackhammer to punch your ballot. The helicopter gets you far away from prying eyes, and the jackhammer makes you really try for whoever you're voting for on that thing. It's foolproof! Imagine trying to fill out your ballot while flying in a helicopter and using only a jackhammer to do it. Do you think you could do it? Do you think you could do it AND vote for the right person?
mnemonics.reading: While using the jackhammer on the ballot, the helicopter pilot keeps yelling “Heyo (ひょう), don't mess up! Heyo! Watch out, don't let me see!” as he flies the helicopter all over the place. You're starting to think this method of filling out ballots is rigged.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a mantis sitting on a flag and you know for a fact that it does not belong there. Insects should be in trees and on the ground. Not on flags. Insects belong in the wild! Look at that mantis, pretending it belongs here. What are you gonna do about it?
mnemonics.reading: Luckily for you, and unluckily for this mantis who doesn't belong on your flag, you're a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang member, and you don't take crap from nobody. You climb the flagpole, punch the mantis and yell, "YOU DON'T BELONG HERE!" Your Bosozoku life has prepared you for this moment. Those who don't belong, shall be punished, you think to yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: Use your fingers to grab this guy's foot and catch him! Not physically though, you do grab his foot, but you close your eyes, and catch the idea of him in your mind just by touching your fingers to his foot. You don't really like the idea of touching your fingers to someone's foot, so you do it ever so slightly, and only catch the gist of what it's like.
mnemonics.reading: As you touch his foot, you catch a glimpse of the Torah (とら) in your mind. Suddenly, you are able to grasp and understand every single thing written in the Torah. You fall to the ground. You wipe your eyes and look up, seeing that the person running from you is wearing socks with little pictures of the Torah on them. You were able to catch that in your brain but not the person. You must have touched those Torah socks and not his foot. You've been tricked!

mnemonics.meaning: At your wedding you use your fingers to catch the wedding rings. And to catch the bouquet. And to catch the rice that everyone is throwing at you, ow, ow, hey stop! Weddings are really more about catching things than they are about whoever is standing across from you. Imagine being at a wedding and getting to catch a ton of things in your fingers.
mnemonics.reading: You're having a good time catching things until it's cleanup time and someone throws a hoe (ほ) at you. First of all, ow again, that was your face. Second, this is your wedding. You aren't supposed to have to hoe it all up. You're supposed to drop everything you caught and leave! Picture yourself grumpily hoeing all the things you couldn't catch, and the dirt under it, and putting it into a big dumpster.

mnemonics.meaning: A leader with a stick, a hook, and an arrow is able to change the climate and weather. Not just the type of climate that causes sunny and rainy days though, the political climate too, because they're a political candidate too. Imagine this leader twirling his stick around with his hook so quickly it changes the actual weather. Then he shoots it into the sky with an arrow, changing the actual climate itself.
mnemonics.reading: Who is this climate and weather-changing candidate leader with the hook, stick, and arrow? It's none other than こういち. Ask こういち why he's changing the climate. He says more people do their WaniKani reviews when it's raining, so he decided to create climate change to make it more dangerous to go outside. "This way, people will stay indoors and do their WaniKani reviews," he tells you.

mnemonics.meaning: The criminal that stole your car was your comrade! You thought the two of you were friends, but you were probably wrong. Just because someone is your comrade doesn't mean they actually like you. Don't let your guard down and let them near your car.
mnemonics.reading: You feel really weird about this whole situation so you write your comrade a haiku (はい). It's really all you can do, since your car is long gone. Comrade, what the heck I want to get my car back I thought we were friends.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a tsunami coming and your older brother is in no condition to escape. Your older brother has brittle bone syndrome so there’s no way he’ll be able to escape the tsunami in time in his condition. Imagine your poor brother and the condition he is in. His glass bones and paper skin make it impossible for him to move very fast. Imagine the sad face he makes when he realizes his fate.
mnemonics.reading: His condition gets worse and you have to travel all the way to his home in きょうと to get him out. This is also, incidentally, where the tsunami's condition is the worst, so you better get to きょうと quick!

mnemonics.meaning: If you poop on the roots of a building, the sound will echo all the way through the building, and each and every person in there will know what you did. Hear the poop echo. You know what a poop usually sounds like, now imagine that sound again, but louder and with an echo. How could anyone not notice?
mnemonics.reading: The echo doesn't stop there, this building's roots extend throughout the entire city of きょうと. The echo reverberates and soon everyone in きょうと is listening, horrified, to your poop. Welp. きょうと knows you pooped. That will echo through your memories for the rest of your life. I hope you're happy.

mnemonics.meaning: If you mix different types of power you'll produce something effective. It doesn't matter what power you mix, because all power is strong. No matter what you use this mixed power on, it will be effective. Imagine some situations where you mix power with power.
mnemonics.reading: The most effective mix of two powers is two こういちs. Take one, mix it with another, and you have something with immeasurable power. You use it to attack that animal-like creature. It's super effective! こういちs punch attack was super effective against that Pikurchort.

mnemonics.meaning: You have a greenhouse that is endless. Imagine your endless greenhouse, which goes on and on, as far as the eye can see. Lucky you.  What will you grow in your endless greenhouse? Imagine all your favourite flowers and foods growing endlessly in your endless greenhouse.
mnemonics.reading: Your flowers have grown so big that now the only way you can fit into your endless greenhouse is by lying on your back (ばく). Imagine yourself lying on your back in your greenhouse under a canopy of great big flowers, tending to them as they grow even bigger.

mnemonics.meaning: Touch your fingers to your friend to extract their friendship. Extract it with a high five. Extract it with a back rub. Extract it with an, "Oh no, there's some lint on your shirt, let me get that for you." REMINDER: You are not allowed to touch any of your friends without their permission. If they say no to extracting, then you don't get to touch. End of story.
mnemonics.reading: Your friend looks you in the eye and says, I want you to extract my clothes. I want to be nude (ぬ). Now you have to use your fingers on your friend to extract their clothes to help them be nude. REMINDER: If someone asks you to extract their clothes to help them be nude, you don't have to do it unless you also want to! Choices and respect, people!

mnemonics.meaning: The fish and sheep are very fresh here. This is a great place to get fresh fish and fresh sheep. I kid you not. Imagine eating this fresh fish and fresh sheep. It’s the freshest you’ve ever tasted. Taste it on your tongue and experience how fresh it is.
mnemonics.reading: This place also serves fresh centaur (せん), but that’s just weird. Centaur is endangered and you don’t believe in eating endangered things. Even if they are incredibly fresh. Can you imagine eating a fresh centaur? How weird would that be? Half of it is human-like, so you’d be like, a half cannibal. Weird, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: If a tsunami hits these flowers they'll both become full of water. Tsunamis carry a lot of water, definitely enough to make both of these flowers full. Picture both of these little flowers, happily swaying in the breeze. Then the tsunami comes, leaves, and you look back and their little cup-heads are full to the brim with water.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare at the full flowers, you decide to write a manga (まん) about them. Your head is full of manga ideas! Soon you have full color pages, full of stories about both of these tsunami-filled flowers and their adventures together. And when you're done, your heart is full as well. Awwww.

mnemonics.meaning: A beggar lies sprawled on the ground so you give him some money. You feel bad for the beggar on the ground, so that’s why you decided to give him something. See the beggar on the ground. He’s writhing in agony and moaning for help. Imagine how sad and pitiful he looks.
mnemonics.reading: When you set the money down next to the beggar he shouts, “No! I want a yo-yo (よ)!” so you go to the corner store and buy him a yo-yo with the money instead. You give the yo-yo to the beggar and he looks very happy. Now watch as the beggar plays with the yo-yo you just gave him. He’s actually pretty good with it. See the beggar doing insane tricks with his new yo-yo as passersby give him change for his impressive yo-yo performance.

mnemonics.meaning: Somebody got dirt on your fingers and dirt on your toes so you're going to hang them upside-down and slap them with your dirty extremities. If someone got dirt all up in your finger and toe business wouldn't you want to hang them too?
mnemonics.reading: You have this person hanging upside-down but they don't seem to be suffering enough, so you hit them with your car (か). No mercy. Don't get dirt on me, buddy. Or I'll hang you upside-down and hit you with my car. Then you'll be sorry.

mnemonics.meaning: Behind a building, a cleat-wearing wolverine is holding his heart and trying to hide. You know the phrase, "You can run, but you can't hide?" This wolverine can't run anymore so he's trying to hide (even though he knows it probably won't work).
mnemonics.reading: The wolverine looks up at the building he's trying to hide behind and sees it's an inn (いん). Lucky wolverine! Inns are good for hiding. The staff isn't supposed to give out his room number, and there are tons of different rooms for him to hide in.

mnemonics.meaning: A tree grows next to a greenhouse enclosing an imitation of the tree. The imitation greenhouse tree wants to be big and impressive like the tree outside, so it does its very best imitation of a real tree. Look at this greenhouse tree struggle to grow big and strong like the wild tree outside. Hear its leaves shake and timber creak. How cute.
mnemonics.reading: The greenhouse tree realizes that its imitation will never be as good as the real thing. When it realizes this, the tree moans (も) aloud. The tree is still kinda tiny, so the moan isn’t very loud, but it is still pretty strange to witness. Speaking of witnesses, Bobo (ぼ) the clown sees this greenhouse tree moaning and decides to take it for his next clown show. Surely this miniature moaning tree can be worked into Bobo's next clown act. Hear the little tree moaning at its pitiful imitation of a real tree. The greenhouse tree sounds very sad and you actually start to feel bad for it. Moan along with the tree in sympathy.

mnemonics.meaning: Now your mouth can include more words than ever before! With our new and improved “Mouth Now!” program, your mouth will include more words than you ever thought possible! Imagine how your repertoire of new words will impress all your friends and family. Don’t include them on your secret that you used the Mouth Now! program, just feel super smart with all the words you now know.
mnemonics.reading: If you buy now, we’ll also include a handful of books by Gandhi (がん) himself. Gandhi didn’t use our program, but we’re sure if he’d had the opportunity to, he would have used it. So buy now, and get the words of Gandhi in your hands as well as your mouth! Since you bought the program, you also got the Gandhi books included with your order. Imagine yourself reading them and learning all about non-violent resistance. Fascinating.

mnemonics.meaning: Be careful what you say in public, otherwise you might face a lawsuit. People will sue you for just about anything these days, so you really need to watch what you say in public, otherwise you might find yourself with a lawsuit on your hands. Think of all the things you could say in public that could get you stuck dealing with a lawsuit. Oh my gosh! How dare you think those things?! You're lucky you didn't say them out loud in public, or I'd file a lawsuit against you myself!
mnemonics.reading: Any and all lawsuits need to be brought before the Shougun (しょう). Oh, you thought you'd get a judge or a jury? Nope, the Shougun decides your fate. You better hope what you said wasn't about the Shougun, or he's really going to use this lawsuit to destroy you.

mnemonics.meaning: A building's roots will limit the things under and around it. Picture the roots of a building: metal beams going into the ground. Now imagine trying to build something like a subway under there. It's not good! The building limits what can go under it.
mnemonics.reading: The person who hates these limits more than anyone else is Genji (げん). He wants to be able to tunnel under buildings, sneak in, smooch ladies, and sneak back out. But all the building root limits make that impossible! Picture Genji tunneling under a building where a cute lady lives. He's trying to get in, but the building roots limit how far he can dig. No! Now how will he steal a secret kiss?!

mnemonics.meaning: A moon who stays in bed all day every day will soon become obese. A healthy moon needs movement and exercise to stay fit and not become obese. If a moon stays in bed all day, they’ll be sure to grow obese over time. Imagine this moon in bed, slowly getting bigger and bigger, becoming more obese every day. Hear the sound of the bed creaking and cracking as the moon grows larger and larger.
mnemonics.reading: Since the obese moon is in bed all day, and since the moon stays pretty cold, she needs some extra heat (ひ) to stay warm. A heated blanket should do the trick. Imagine the obese moon cozied up in bed with a heated blanket and hot cocoa.

mnemonics.meaning: Music beans make farts plentiful. And lucky for you, music beans themselves are also plentiful, so you can eat plenty of them to power your musical bean toots. Imagine dancing to your own plentiful bean music as you gorge on beans.
mnemonics.reading: Your music bean farts are too plentiful to leave your home (ほう). If you tried to leave your home you'd definitely fart all over people outside, so you keep your plentiful farts to yourself. Be polite! Keep your plentiful farts at home.

mnemonics.meaning: A husband marries a husband while the sun goes down and the men replace their solitary lives with one of everlasting companionship. Instead of one husband and one wife, we have two husbands here. They shed their lives of bachelorhood and replace it with one of monogamy. See these two husbands as the sun sets under them. Listen to them each saying their vows, expressing how they could never replace one another.
mnemonics.reading: After the ceremony, the husband and his husband get in a car (か) and drive off into the sunset. They’ll never be able to replace this memory with anything. Truly it is the happiest day of these husbands’ lives. See the husbands driving off into the sunset in their car. Hear the engine rumble as the car speeds off into the distance.

mnemonics.meaning: The sun rises over the capital building, creating a breathtaking scene. The sun is so bright and warm as it crests over the capital building. It’s quite the scene to behold. Picture this scene in your mind. Squint as the sun shines in your eyes and feel its warmth as it rises up and over the capital building.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to make this scene better would be to add cake (けい). Now that you think about it... as you look at the scene in front of you, the capital kind of looks like a big cake. Picture this scene again, but this time the sun is making the capital look like a big, fancy cake. Now take a bite!

mnemonics.meaning: A gladiator only sees himself (oneself) on those big scrolls they advertise the fights with. Gladiators don't get mirrors and there are no cameras or videos yet. The scroll drawings are all they get of themselves. Imagine being a gladiator. Your big fight is coming and you're the  main event! Look at the scroll for the fight and try to find yourself.
mnemonics.reading: When you look at the scroll you realize... you look just like Genghis Khan (かん)! You excitedly fist pump and start showing everyone how cool you are. After a while of showing off the scroll, someone finally pulls you aside and says, "That guy isn't you, it's the real Genghis Khan. He's coming to the event and he's against you. So. Nice knowing you." Oh.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to get your fingers on the humble stool, so you dedicate your life to search for it. Wait, the humble stool? You know, like the holy grail or the ark of the covenant, but it's called the humble stool. It's from some bible or something, I promise. Now you have to search through a bunch of religious texts for this humble stool with your fingers. Don't go too fast and get paper cuts!
mnemonics.reading: You search and you search and, unfortunately, you spend your entire life searching and you die without finding the humble stool. But don't worry, your soul (そう) comes back and now you get to continue your search but with afterlife powers! You dedicated your soul to searching, and now that your soul is free from its body, you can continue the search until you find it!

mnemonics.meaning: A lifeguard will choose a tree to set up the station where he'll care for the people on the beach and in the water. Trees provide the shade lifeguards need to take care of half-drowned kids and grannies with sand stuck in their bathing suits. That's why they set up their care stations here. Watch the lifeguard walk around the beach. He needs to pick a nice big tree for his set up, so he can provide the best care possible.
mnemonics.reading: You look closer at the set up and realize the lifeguard is こういち! You know he teaches Japanese but... is こういち really qualified to care for people like this? Imagine こういち setting up a care station. You hope you don't get in trouble in the water so you don't have to see how good he is at caring for people. Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.

mnemonics.meaning: The sun rises over the capital, shines down on your hair, and casts a long shadow on the ground in front of you. Feel the heat of the sun on your back as you look down over your capital, your long hair blowing over your shoulder. Your shadow stretches in front of you and it's honestly pretty impressive.
mnemonics.reading: In the shade from your shadow you see a small acorn (えい) laying on the ground. You're about to reach down and pick it up when you realize that your shadow is keeping this little acorn from growing up big and strong. What do you do? Keep standing here, admiring the view and casting this shadow on the acorn. Or do you move and let the acorn grow, becoming a tree that can cast its own shadow on your capital.

mnemonics.meaning: A thread is mixed all around and begins to strangle you. Just imagine thread everywhere, mixing in with everything. It's all around, and no matter where you go you get more and more caught in this thread. Eventually it tightens because you're trying to escape, and you feel yourself having trouble breathing. Imagine the moment when you realize you're getting strangled.
mnemonics.reading: As you are strangled you see who set this trap. (What else could it be, with all this thread everywhere?) It is こういち, who just watches you as you lose consciousness, tapping his fingers together. In your final moments before you are totally strangled, you think you see a little thread come out of his butt. "I should have done my WaniKani reviews" is your last thought.

mnemonics.meaning: You say you have an axe with a drop of blood on it. You hit someone with that axe and now they're going to sue you. That drop of blood on your axe is pretty incriminating, which is why they have enough of a case to sue you. Imagine being unable to stop yourself from saying "I have the axe with the drop on it!" and the recently axed person jumps out from behind a bush and shouts, "Aha! I'm gonna sue you!"
mnemonics.reading: You want to sue them back so you clean the axe with some soap (そ). "Your honor," you say in court, "I don't see any drops of blood, I countersue!" The person you axed cries and tries desperately to find their blood on the axe so they can keep suing you properly. You hold the soap behind your back and cackle.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a spirit at your wedding. It's there as a supplement to the guests because not enough people came. It's weird that you supplemented your wedding guests with a spirit or two, but even if you hadn't invited them, they may have showed up anyway.
mnemonics.reading: Along with the spirits to supplement your wedding guests, you made everyone carry a hoe (ほ). That way no one had to bring a date, they carry a garden hoe as a supplement and no one feels bad about being dateless. Everyone is! Maybe you should supplement your wedding with other things next time... instead of spirits and garden hoes.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami carries your yurt and you on a stool under it away. You are now in transit. Imagine being carried away on your stool by the tsunami, with your entire yurt floating around you too. You're both in transit... to somewhere. You don't know where though.
mnemonics.reading: The transit of yourself and your yurt home is due to the water (わた). This is water transit. You hope the tsunami's water will drop you off somewhere nice. Somewhere it's easy to jump on a different kind of mass transit, to get back home again.

mnemonics.meaning: I've announced I'm going to sue you. The accusation and charge I have against you for suing you? Uh... You suck.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 毎月きちんとお金を払って頂けるなら、告訴はしません。
I won’t take legal action as long as you pay me every month.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 男優 was "actor"? Well, I bet you can extrapolate what this one means because it now has woman in it. This is an actress.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「ホグワーツ魔法魔術学校にはもう行きたくない。女優になりたいの。」「もう、馬鹿なこと言わないで。ハーマイオニーったら。」
"I don’t want to go to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry anymore. I want to be an actress." "Oh, don’t be ridiculous, Hermione."

mnemonics.meaning: The fruit of something that's effective is an effect.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ジムで水泳をすることが、最も効果的なダイエット方法だと聞きました。
I heard swimming at the gym is the most effective way to lose weight.

mnemonics.meaning: When you apprehend and catch someone, that leads to an arrest / capture.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ラッシュ時の電車内で痴漢行為を働いたとして、危うく誤認逮捕されるところだった。
I was almost arrested by mistake for molestation on the rush hour train.

mnemonics.meaning: A place where something belongs is where it is attached. It's where it's attached to. It belong(s) to that place.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 所属部署に病欠のための診断書を提出しておいた方がいいよ。
You should turn in doctor’s notes for sick days to your own department.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It can also be a vote, because that's what ballots tend to do.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: コウイチは票の大半を得て相手候補者に圧勝し、アメリカ合衆国の大統領となった。
Koichi defeated the other candidate with a majority of the votes and became the President of the United States of America.

mnemonics.meaning: It's a prize where you are given gold. In business, this is called a bonus. You didn't expect it (not your salary) and it is given to you (and is gold, if you're lucky).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 給料日は毎月5日と20日で、会社の業績次第で賞与金が年末に支払われます。
Our paydays are the fifth and the twentieth of every month and a bonus may be paid at the end of the year depending on how well the company has done.

mnemonics.meaning: Take a look at this scene and the condition it’s in. This is the climate of the situation, but more specifically the business climate. This word is really only used to talk about the state of business and economic stuff.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本の景況感が大きく上向くのは、まだまだ先のことだろう。
It is only in the far away future that Japan’s situation will soar.

mnemonics.meaning: The candidate is someone who's a supplement to the entire political system. Despite being a supplement, they're still a candidate nonetheless, unless they can win!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 学歴的には、候補者として十分通用するはずが、彼は性格に難があるからね。
Academically speaking, the candidate would be very useful, but he has such a bad personality.

mnemonics.meaning: The energy of the climate is the climate. High energy? Climate. Low energy. Climate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 気候は荒れ模様だが、新しい仕事ではいいスタートが切れた。
I got off to a good start with my new job, considering the threatening climate.

mnemonics.meaning: When you can see all the scene you have a complete view.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は息を飲むような富士の全景を期待していたが、実際はかなりお粗末なものだった。
I was expecting a breathtaking panorama of Mt. Fuji, but the reality of it was pretty pathetic.

mnemonics.meaning: The condition condition is the condition. It's also the circumstances if you can remember that. It's like saying "What's the condition!??" which is similar to saying "What's the circumstances?"
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: しっかりしろよ。状況はお前が思っているほど悪くないみたいだぜ。
Get a grip! The situation isn’t as bad as you think.

mnemonics.meaning: When you search and inspect things, you are probably part of a criminal investigation. You may even be subject to a manhunt.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ビエト達は、警察の捜査の手をたくみにかわした。
Viet and his gang deftly evaded the police manhunt.
本日は捜査に関する重要書類を作成する予定です。
I’m going to draw up some important documents for a criminal investigation today.

mnemonics.meaning: I've learned to be accustomed to this. It has become my custom and habit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「たばこ、止めたんじゃなかったの？」「まあ、ほら、『古い習慣はなかなかなくならない』って言うだろ。」
"I thought you quit smoking." "Well, they say old habits die hard."

mnemonics.meaning: A strangle kill is when you are strangled to death. Try to avoid this.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「あんた、もう少しであの男を絞殺しかけたのよ！」「ごめん。やりすぎたよ。」
"You almost strangled that guy to death!" "I’m sorry. I went too far."

mnemonics.meaning: Divide that price and pull it apart. You only have to pay for one part! What a discount.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. き from ひき kind of just gets stuffed into the 引 and hidden away like that strange collection of fingernails you have hidden in your closet drawer inside of a 35mm film container. Also remember that the reading gets changed to びき here because of that pesky rendaku.

sentences: 二割引きの値札が付いてたはずですよ。
I'm sure it had a had a 20% discount price tag on it.
ちょうどホームページへ割引クーポンの追加をしようと思ってたところだよ。
I’ll set about adding a discount coupon to the website.

mnemonics.meaning: An anti echo is still an echo! It's just going back and forth with a normal echo. Together they get a weird reverberation going.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この記事への反響はとても大きかった。
The reaction towards this article was huge.

mnemonics.meaning: Your effective power is your effectiveness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あなたの今日のプレゼンテーションは、前回に比べて効力が少し弱いような気がしました。
Your presentation today seemed like it was a bit weaker in its effectiveness compared to the last one.

mnemonics.meaning: Your effective percent shows how effective you are. If you're at an effective percent of 80%, that's your efficiency.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 効率が第一だということを、しっかり心に刻んで置いてください。
Keep in mind that efficiency is our top priority.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who is a comrade with years has been around a lot of said years. They are an elderly person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はい goes to a ぱい, because elderly persons love pie, right?

sentences: 年輩の上司が、牛の乳搾り体験の費用を払ってくれた。
My elderly boss paid for me to experience milking a cow.

mnemonics.meaning: Bind and set up everything so it is fairly fine and alright. This word is used like this: "That's fine, no more" 結構です "It's fairly big" 結構大きい "It's alright" 結構です etc.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The けつ shortens to けっ.

sentences: 「今日は他には何か、ございませんか？」「いいえ。それだけで結構です。」
"Would you like anything else today?" "No, that’s alright."

mnemonics.meaning: The above scroll is the top scroll, the one you read first. It's the first volume. Many Japanese books come in parts, so look for this if you want to get the first one.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 上巻の終わりは、すごく続きが気になる感じで終わった。
The ending of the first volume was a real cliff-hanger.

mnemonics.meaning: The front scene is the foreground.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このカメラでは、どうすれば前景の被写体にピントを合わせることができるんですか？
How can I focus on something in the foreground with this camera?

mnemonics.meaning: New and fresh is fresh (has to be new if you want it to be fresh, after all).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 前の職場では、止めろと言われるまでいつも残業していたので、毎日五時に退社するのはとても新鮮です。
I always worked overtime at my last job until I was told to stop, so it’s very new to me to leave work at five o’clock every day.

mnemonics.meaning: Fresh fish is fresh fish (and the best fish, nom nom nom).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 俺の魚屋で働いている限り、従業員は福利厚生として鮮魚をもらう権利を、放棄することはできないぜ。
Employees cannot waive their right to receiving fresh fish as a benefit as long as they work for my fish shop.

mnemonics.meaning: Full of members, so sorry, no more room. This place is a full house. That means there is no vacancy here.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 毎朝、新宿駅に着くまで、満員電車の中に立っていなくてはいけないのが苦痛です。
I hate that I have to stand in a packed train until I arrive at Shinjuku station every morning.

mnemonics.meaning: The full moon is a full moon.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 明日の夜は満月なんだって。曇らないといいね。
Tomorrow night will be a full moon. I hope it’s not cloudy.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is endlessly big isn't just big, but huge and enormous. This word is often used in contexts that involve money, but it can also be used for things like time and energy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 道路建設には莫大な費用がかかる。
Road construction costs huge amounts of money.
このままでは、コストが莫大になる可能性があります。
If this situation continues, the cost could be enormous.
カニの像は美しいが、莫大な資金が使われたことについてはだれも喜ばないだろう。
The crab statue is beautiful, but no one will be happy with the huge amount of funds spent on it.

mnemonics.meaning: Include your ideas here, but think about the implications they will result in too, especially considering you're just including them now. They have implications!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 誰にとっても、含意を汲み取るのは難しいことだ。
It’s difficult for everyone to understand the implied meaning.

mnemonics.meaning: The limit is nothing. What? No limit? That means it will never stop! It is infinite!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 若者には、無限の可能性がある。
Young people have infinite possibilities.
この世に無限なものなんてある？
Is anything infinite in this world?
今は絶好調のように思えるが、需要は無限には増加しないだろう？
The situation looks bright at the moment, but the demand won’t increase indefinitely, right?

mnemonics.meaning: In the shadows you still echo. Your echo leaves the shadows and hits people, creating an influence on them. You're like the shadow person pulling the strings, making things do what you want... influencing them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 残業は健康に悪影響を及ぼす可能性があるということを考えた方がいいですよ。
You should consider that working extra hours may have a negative influence on your health.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 規則 means "rule" or "regulation." So a not "rule" or "regulation" is an irregularity.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 不規則な生活で体調を崩してしまった。
My health was ruined by my disorderly life.

mnemonics.meaning: The comrade who's behind you is your junior.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 後 is the long こう reading, though. Just think of your junior being こういち.

sentences: お前は俺のお気に入りの後輩だから、どんなことがあってもちゃんと面倒みてやるよ。
I’ll take care of you, no matter what happens because you’re my favorite underclassmen.

mnemonics.meaning: The scroll that's below is the last scroll you read, making it the last volume.
mnemonics.reading: The 下 uses the alternative reading of げ but 巻 is all good and normal.

sentences: 上巻を買ったつもりが下巻を買ってしまっていた。
I thought I bought the first volume, but it was actually the last volume.

mnemonics.meaning: If you sue and bring about a lawsuit, you are bringing about a lawsuit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その訴訟に関する書類は、弁護士によって全てきちんとファイルされている。
The documents related to the lawsuit have all been properly filed by the lawyer.

mnemonics.meaning: 革 is leather and ジャン is short for ジャンパー (Jumper, like a jacket). So, put those together and you have a leather jacket.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the vocab word 革, because this word is like two separate words put together (so it's treated as single words too, giving it that reading).

sentences: お洒落大好き人間にアドバイスされたってだけで、あんな高い革ジャンは買うわけないじゃん。
I’m not buying such an expensive leather jacket just because a fashionista told me to.

mnemonics.meaning: The limit degree is how far you can go. It's your limit. Turn things up one more degree and it's too much. Keep it right where it is and it's perfect. It's your limit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このクレジットカードの限度額がいくらだったか忘れちゃったんだよね。
I forget what my limit is on this credit card.

mnemonics.meaning: The limit of the world is the limit. It's the boundary too. You can't go beyond the world's limit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その野球選手は、自分の限界を感じて引退した。
The baseball player retired when he felt that he had reached his limit.

mnemonics.meaning: Your limit is determined. It is where it is. It is your limit after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: これはライフタイム会員限定のサービスなんです。
This service is limited to lifetime members.
お母さん、あの限定販売のトーフグ人形が欲しいんだけど、百万ドルくれない？
Mom, I really want the limited edition Tofugu dolls, so can’t you give me one million dollars?

mnemonics.meaning: Your fee for being obese is lots of manure coming out of your butt. If you eat a lot you'll poop a lot of manure.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 肥料工場での社員間のいざこざについて、どう対処していいか全くわかりませんでした。
I had no idea how to handle the conflict among the workers at the fertilizer factory.

mnemonics.meaning: Gold belongs to this family... "What is metal?"
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 厳しい景況にもかかわらず、あの金属メッキ工場は成長を続けている。
The metal-plating factory is thriving despite the challenging business climate.

mnemonics.meaning: If you try to calculate something, but instead you feel the urge to hang your teacher, you know you're doing multiplication. It's hard, guys. Like really hard. The hardest kind of math of them all. But you can do it! No one needs to get hanged. And don't hang your head in defeat either. Multiply those numbers like a boss! Hang the numbers instead!!
mnemonics.reading: This is the kun'yomi reading for 掛 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

sentences: 明日、塾で掛け算のテストがあるんです。
There’s a multiplication test in cram school tomorrow.

mnemonics.meaning: Long Cape Prefecture. This will make more sense when you look at the reading. Hint: It's Nagasaki Prefecture.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are 長 from 長い, normal 崎 and normal 県.

sentences: 私は長崎県の出身で、家族の墓も全部そこにあります。
I am from Nagasaki prefecture and my family graves are all located there, too.

mnemonics.meaning: Does being obese mean you're always full? Of course not. But clearly that's what the people who coined the Japanese word for obesity thought... You can see there are some implicit biases in these kanji!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 肥満の主な原因は、おそらく運動不足でしょうね。
The main cause of my obesity is probably lack of exercise.
とうにょう病は、肥満が原因で起こる病気の一つです。
Diabetes is one of the diseases that obesity can cause.
あの肥満上司が、私たちに対する全権限を持っていて、先週は二名を解雇しやがったんだよ。
That obese boss has authoritative power over us and he terminated two workers last week.

mnemonics.meaning: One scroll is one scroll back in the day, but now it refers to books and means one volume.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち goes to いっ.

sentences: 一巻では、全ての引用に脚注がつけられ出典が記されています。
In the first volume, all sources are cited in the footnotes.

mnemonics.meaning: If you set up something so that it becomes a certain way, that's the organization of this thing. That's its structure and composition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この映画は二部構成になっている。
This movie is composed of two parts.
構成のしっかりしたプロットでも、台詞がありきたりだと面白くなくなる。
Even if the plot is well structured, it won't be interesting if the dialogue is trite.
この文を構成する文法は今まで見たことがありませんでした。
I've never seen the grammar that makes up this sentence before.

mnemonics.meaning: An imitation manner is something that does something in the manner of something else. Imitation over and over and over. Make it into a pattern.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 様 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. You see a pattern in your yogurt (よう). The yogurt is an imitation of life. So deep, man. So deep.

sentences: 私の妻は、小さな花の模様が好きです。
My wife likes patterns with small flowers.

mnemonics.meaning: Full points are when you get a perfect score.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 満点をとったら、先生に花丸をもらえるの。
When I get a perfect score, my teacher draws a flower on the paper.

mnemonics.meaning: An imitation model is obviously not the real thing. It's (usually) a plastic model or just a model figure or something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 祖父は、最初は従業員一人の小売模型店からこのビジネスを始めました。
My grandfather started his business out as a small one person plastic model retail shop.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're plentiful and full, you could say you're plump or full-figured... in other words, you're not a snack, you're the Whole. Damn. Meal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 細い人より、豊満な人の方がタイプです。
I'm more into full-figured people than thin people.

mnemonics.meaning: A "not condition" is where nothing is going well. How are things going? Not well. The condition is bad. We're in a recession.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 不況時に金の価格は上昇しやすい。
The price of gold tends to rise during recessions.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, that you learned already. If you follow the correct rules everything will stay regular and well regulated.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word too.

sentences: 規則正しい生活を送って下さい。
Please live a regular life.

mnemonics.meaning: You hide away but you're alive. You've lived your life, so now it's time to hide and enjoy your retirement by making your retreat from working life. This word refers to life after someone retires, and usually implies being retired from active life and having a quiet, maybe even secluded, lifestyle. It can also imply handing over the reins to your successors. The word is a little old-fashioned, but you'll still see it in modern writing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の父は隠居生活をエンジョイしていますよ。
My father has been enjoying his retirement.
この里は、かつては隠居の地として人気がありました。
This village used to be a popular place for retreats.
お前は本当に隠居したいのか？
Do you really want to retire?

mnemonics.meaning: A person who lives in a revolution (革命) house is a revolutionary. They want government change! They want to take down the people in power!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know 革命 already as well.

sentences: あの革命家は、ネット弁けいだ。
That revolutionary is only hot-tempered on the Internet.
革命家になりたければ、まずは効果的な話し方を身につけないといけないよ。
If you want to be a revolutionary, first you need to be able to speak effectively.
彼女は情熱的なフランス人革命家と恋に落ちた。
She fell in love with a passionate French revolutionary.

mnemonics.meaning: Rhythm is 律動, but by adding a 的 in there we get the adjective version of that word, making it rhythmical or rhythmic.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 律動. The 的 part you should also be able to read by now.

sentences: この音楽はとても律動的ですね。
This music is very rhythmic.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the same as the kanji 豊, making it plentiful. It can also mean rich or wealthy.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Don't worry, these resources are plentiful. You take (ゆた) what you want.

sentences: 80年前と比べると、日本は本当に豊かになりました。
Compared to 80 years ago, Japan has become really wealthy.
九州は自然が豊かな所です。
Kyushu is a place that's rich in nature.
本を読むと心が豊かになりますよ。
Reading books will enrich your mind.

mnemonics.meaning: I am full and sufficient. I am satisfied.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that the reading for 足 in this one is ぞく because of that pesky rendaku.

sentences: ビジネスが順調なので、ようやく満足しています。
My business is doing well so I finally feel satisfied.

mnemonics.meaning: The standard of imitation is to imitate to the scale and scope of the original.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あなたにとってはただの規模の小さな会社かもしれませんが、私は両親の会社に誇りをもっています。
It may be just a small scale firm to you, but I’m proud of my parents’ company.

mnemonics.meaning: The scene's color is the scenery, scene, and landscape. Looking good, scenery!
mnemonics.reading: You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember them: You're admiring the scenery and you notice key marks all over everything. You realize it's that girl who keys everything and you say to yourself kay she keyed (けしき) that, kay she keyed (けしき) this.

sentences: ちょっといつもと違った景色を見るために、今日は回り道をしてみない？
Do you want to make a detour to see some different scenery than usual today?

mnemonics.meaning: Quite the scene, this view is. What you're looking at is called scenery. And, in fact, it's a spectacular view!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は京都の景観がとても好きです。
I really like Kyoto’s scenery.
この市の自治体は景観計画をきちんと立てています。
The local government of this city has a solid landscape plan.

mnemonics.meaning: The time's climate is the current season. Each season has a different climate and exists in a different time of year.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本では、通常手紙は時候の挨拶から書き始められる。
People usually begin letters with a seasonal greeting in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: The number two scroll is the second volume. With Japanese books, they often come in pieces with groups of three being common. This represents the second volume.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 二巻では、引用の出典に関する別表が作成されました。
They made an appendix for all sources cited in the second volume.

mnemonics.meaning: My comrade who came before me is my senior, my senpai (せんぱい).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well, but just remember that the second kanji is read as ぱい because of the rendaku on はい.

sentences: 俺の先輩、悪い人では無いんだけどさ、ただちょっと俺とは反りが合わないんだよね。
My superior isn’t a bad guy, but he and I just haven’t been able to hit it off.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Just imagine the shadow of a cage (かげ). Lots of long bars. Looks good.

sentences: 「私、もう何週間もフグを見てないわ。」「ほら、見て。ちょうど今フグが来たわよ。」「あら、噂をすれば影がさす、ね。こんにちは。私たち、今ちょうどあなたのことを話していたのよ。」
"I haven’t seen Fugu for weeks." "Oh, look. Here comes Fugu right now." "Well, speak of the devil. Hi, there. We were just talking about you."

mnemonics.meaning: A scene that's as awesome and bright as sunlight is quite the spectacle.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このような絵のように美しい光景は今までみたことがありません。
I’ve never seen such a beautiful sight before.

mnemonics.meaning: The period of time limit is nothing more than a period or term of time. There's a limit there, and that limit is defined by the term.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ビザの期限が切れるので、来月日本を出なくてはいけません。
I have to leave Japan next month because my visa will expire.

mnemonics.meaning: Heaven's climate is the weather.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 繁忙期に旅行をすれば費用が嵩むのは分かっているけど、そうはいっても天候もその時期が一番いいからね。
I know there will be extra costs if we travel during peak season, but the weather will be the best around that time.

mnemonics.meaning: A time limit is a time limit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 時限爆弾がきちんと引き出しの中にしまわれていることを確認した。
I made sure that the time bomb was neatly placed in the drawer.

mnemonics.meaning: If 吸収 is "absorption" the verb version is to absorb.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 全社員が新システムに関する知識を吸収する良い機会です。
This is a great opportunity for all of the workers to absorb knowledge about the new system.

mnemonics.meaning: If 呼ぶ is "to call" then this is something similar. This is when you are called by someone (and you're not doing the calling). This word is to be called.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is shared with 呼ぶ, so remember that and you'll be able to read this too.

sentences: おばちゃんと呼ばれる年になってしまったことがちょっと悲しかった。
I was a little sad to reach an age where I can be called a middle-aged woman.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means catch so the intransitive verb vocab version is to be caught. This is a literal, physical catch. So, for example, you can catch a criminal using this verb but not catch the drift of an idea, which would be 捕える, coming up in level 27.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is つか, so to remember that with to be caught, think about how you're a police officer trying to catch some criminals. Unfortunately, they have split up into two cars (つか) meaning you won't catch both of them, since you only have one car.

sentences: 最初スピード違反で止められたんだけど、その後飲酒運転で捕まっちゃったんだよ。
At first I was just stopped for speeding, but I ended up being caught for drunk driving.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accustomed so the verb vocab version is to become accustomed.
mnemonics.reading: What have you become accustomed to? All the Narwhals (な) you hang out with. They take some getting used to.

sentences: 裾上げをお願いできますか？自分ではあまり縫い物に慣れてなくて。
Could you bring the hem up for me? I’m not really used to sewing.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 割る is "to divide"? Now you're learning the similar intransitive version. Instead of you doing the dividing, something just gets divided. This is to be divided.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is shared with 割る.

sentences: 大便がしたくてたまらなかった彼は、ドアを拳で割れるほど強く叩いた。
He needed to poop so badly that he almost broke the door from pounding on it with his fists.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means effective. The verb vocab version is to be effective (since "to effective" doesn't make sense).
mnemonics.reading: What is particularly effective? It's your key (き). It's effective at opening your house door.

sentences: 肺癌の治療に最も良く効く薬を探しています。
I’m looking for the most effective medicine for treating lung cancer.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means belong so the verb vocab version is to belong to.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. This kanji is going to belong to you.

sentences: 四年生の時は誰のグループに属していたの？
Whose group were you in when you were in grade four?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means care so the verb vocab version is to care about.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you care a lot about grammar? I don't care, unless it has to do with commas (かま). Then I do flip out.

sentences: 「こちらの品は百万円ほどお高くなります。」「それでも構わないよ。それを頂くよ。」
"This one will cost about a million yen more." "I still don’t mind. I’ll take it."

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means catch so the verb version is to catch. Try to remember the mnemonic from the kanji with this one, because this word isn't used for physically catching things, but for ideas or meanings that you are able to grasp, metaphorically speaking.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: コップの半分まで入れられた水は、人によって「半分しかない」とも「半分もある」とも捉えられます。
A glass filled halfway with water can be perceived as "half empty" or "half full," depending on the person.
日本人のクライアントの本音を捉えるのは難しい。
It's hard to grasp what Japanese clients are really thinking.
そのサーカス団は、開演してすぐに観客の心を捉えた。
Immediately after the show started, the circus troupe captivated the audience's hearts.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transit, but when you think about "to transit" this doesn't make too much sense. When you "transit" something, though, you're going across it. That's why this word is to cross or to cross over.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 橋を渡り終わったところで、右に曲がって下さい。
After crossing the bridge, please turn right.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means echo so the verb is to echo.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing...

sentences: おこったコウイチの声が部屋中に響いた。
Koichi's angry voice echoed through the room.
動画が終わった後も、コウイチの歌声は私の心に響いていました。
Even after the video ended, Koichi's voice was still reverberating in my heart.
大きな契約を勝ち取るには、顧客の心に響く素晴らしい提案書が必要だ。
To win a major contract, we’ll need a great business proposition that resonates in our customers’ hearts.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means alive and the verb version means to exist or to be, for anything that is alive and moving, like people and animals.  The kanji isn't used too often for this word, so when you're writing just use the kana. But you'll see the kanji used sometimes so it's important to be able to recognize it!
mnemonics.reading: Do you know the word いる? This is the kanji version! If you've been studying Japanese up to this point you probably already know that word. You can associate these two things together into one and remember the reading at the same time!

sentences: うちの猫は大抵二階の寝室に居るんです。
Our cat is usually in our bedroom upstairs.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extract so the verb vocab version is to extract.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Just go ahead and extract it out of your memory so you can use it here.

sentences: ワサビ抜きにしてもらえますか？
Can you leave out the wasabi?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give so the verb vocab version is to give or to grant.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You go to give a bone to your dog. Atta (あた) boy, Sparky! Atta boy.

sentences: 犬にえさを与える前に座らせてください。
Please make the dog sit before giving it food.
まず初めに、お忙しい中足をお運び頂き誠に有り難うございます。また、このような素晴らしいプレゼンテーションの機会を与えて頂いたことにも、感謝申し上げます。
Let me start off by thanking you all for coming and granting me such a great opportunity to make my presentation.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hang so the verb vocab version is to hang. This is when you hang something, like a picture. You can remember this because you don't really care (ける) about where you hang it, as long as you're the one to do it.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 彼の死後、くれた絵をどこに掛けたらいいかしら。
Since his death, I don’t know where I should hang the picture he gave me.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hide and the verb vocab version is to hide something or to conceal something.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Hide your cock (かく)! You have a ton of roosters but you don't want people to know about them, so you gotta hide your cocks. What did you think I was talking about?

sentences: コウイチはドアにかぎを掛けた後、そのかぎを隠した。
Koichi locked the door and then hid the key.
水戸黄門は本当の身分を隠して旅をしていた。
Mito Komon concealed his true identity while he was traveling.
秘密の花園への入口は隠されている。
The entrance to the Secret Garden is hidden.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means include so the verb vocab version is to include.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  They don't want to include you in their game? Well, "F*** (ふく) you!" you yell at them, because they wouldn't include you.

sentences: アルカリを含む温泉にはどのような効能があるのですか？
What kinds of benefits does a hot spring containing alkali have?

mnemonics.meaning: It's another verb with the kanji 増! This one means to increase too! But! These are unconscious increases, whereas 増やす are usually for conscious increases.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: What increases with time? Your love for your mama (ま)! Your love for her will grow and grow the older you get! I love you, mama!

sentences: 砂糖でさらに甘みが増しますよ。
Sugar will make it much sweeter, you know.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means limit so the verb vocab version is to limit.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: to limit things, you have something called a car (か) guillotine (ぎ) which you drive around limiting everything with.

sentences: やっぱり、日本語の勉強はトーフグに限るよ。
After all, nothing beats Tofugu when it comes to learning Japanese.

meanings: to take an extensive view of

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji mean see and transit, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are going to transit your eyes over an area to take in what you see. So you're really going to look out over everything. This word is usually used when you're looking at landscapes or a really large area.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 見渡す限り、向日葵畑が続いていた。
The sunflower field went on as far as the eye could see.

mnemonics.meaning: 張る is to stretch. You're stubborn and want to stretch out what you're doing right now. Although you're stubborn, you keep doing it. You persevere. That's why this word is to persevere or to do one's best.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is the reading for 頑 and 張る put together but the 張る part gets rendaku'd so keep that in mind.

sentences: 「そのまま頑張って。あなたなら大丈夫よ。」
Hang in there, you can do this.
最近は、自分でシャツのボタンを掛けようと頑張っています。
Recently, he's been trying his best to button his shirts by himself.
医者から規則正しい生活をして規則正しく食事をするようアドバイスされたので、今頑張っているんです。
My doctor advised me to lead a regular life and eat regularly, so I'm working hard on that.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen that 準備 is preparations. This is the verb version, so you get yourself to prepare.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 準備.

sentences: 準備する前に先に朝ご飯食べちゃいなさい。
Finish your breakfast before getting ready.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means replace so the verb vocab version is to replace. You know that you're doing the replacing because of the air (える). You're replacing the air as quickly as you can because if you don't you wouldn't be able to breathe in this small room.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: お父さんに電球を替えるようにもう頼んだよ。
I already asked dad to change the bulb.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scroll. But, you don't "to scroll." What do you do to scrolls, though? You roll them up, making this word "to roll" or "to roll up."
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you are rolling up is your ma (ま). She's going wild again, so you throw her into a blanket and roll her up to hold her down.

sentences: 二時間かけて髪を巻いたが、それでもあまりうまく巻けなかった。
I spend two hours curling my hair, but it still doesn’t curl well.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means search so the verb vocab version is to search for or to seek.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're searching all around for a "sagger" (さが) on your body. This is a flap of skin that is sagging on your body really far, and you probably should get it removed.

sentences: 祖母を捜しているんです。アルツハイマーがあって、昨日から家に帰ってないんです。
I’m searching for my grandmother. She has Alzheimer's and hasn’t come home since yesterday.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means present time, but you can't "to present time." If you try to do present time, the best you can do is try to show it. Kind of a weird connection, but if you think through it a couple times it might get better.
mnemonics.reading: Do you remember learning 現れる? This has the same exact pronunciation!

sentences: 彼女は最後には本性を現すと思ってたよ。
I knew that she would show her true colors in the end.

mnemonics.meaning: When you obtain something you need to keep it safe, so you decide to store it somewhere. Then you can always go back and look at the thing you managed to achieve,  to score, or at least to finish, and no one can take it from you.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with 収まる, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case: You need to store all of the old saws (おさ). You were able to finish and to achieve everything you wanted with them, so it's time to put them away so they'll be safe.

sentences: ビエトの政治犯罪に関する証こをファイルに収めました。
